### 5.1 Properties of the Penalized Empirical Likelihood Estimator

To investigate the asymptotic properties of $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}$ in (3), we assume some regularity conditions.

Condition 1. For any $\varepsilon>0$, it holds that

$$
\inf _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}: \mid \boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0} \mid \infty>\varepsilon}\left|\mathbb{E}\left\{\mathbf{g}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\right)\right\}\right|_{\infty} \geq \Delta(\varepsilon)
$$

where $\Delta(\cdot)$ is a nonnegative function satisfying $\liminf _{\varepsilon \rightarrow 0^{+}} \varepsilon^{-1} \Delta(\varepsilon) \geq K_{1}$ for some universal constant $K_{1}>0$.

Condition 2. (a) There exist universal constants $K_{2}>0$ and $\gamma>4$ such that

$$
\max _{j \in[r]} \mathbb{E}\left\{\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}}\left|g_{j}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\right)\right|^{\gamma}\right\} \leq K_{2}
$$

and $\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}} \max _{j \in[r]} \mathbb{E}_{n}\left\{\left|g_{j}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\right)\right|^{\gamma}\right\}=O_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$. (b) There exist universal constants $0<K_{3}<K_{4}$ such that $K_{3}<\lambda_{\min }\left\{\mathbf{V}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right\} \leq \lambda_{\max }\left\{\mathbf{V}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right\}<K_{4}$. (c) For any $\mathbf{x}$ and $j \in[r], g_{j}(\mathbf{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})$ is twice continuously differentiable with respect to $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}$ satisfying

$$
\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}} \max _{j \in[r], k \in[p]} \mathbb{E}_{n}\left\{\left|\frac{\partial g_{j}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\right)}{\partial \theta_{k}}\right|^{2}\right\}=O_{\mathrm{p}}(1)=\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}} \max _{j \in[r], k_{1}, k_{2} \in[p]} \mathbb{E}_{n}\left\{\left|\frac{\partial^{2} g_{j}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\right)}{\partial \theta_{k_{1}} \partial \theta_{k_{2}}}\right|^{2}\right\}
$$

Detailed discussion on Conditions 1 and 2 are given in Section B of the supplementary material. For any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}$, define

$$
\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{*}=\left\{j \in[r]: \mid \mathbb{E}_{n}\left\{g_{j}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\right)\right\} \mid \geq C_{*} \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)\right\}
$$

for some $C_{*} \in(0,1)$. We assume the existence of a sequence $\ell_{n} \rightarrow \infty$ such that

$$
\mathbb{P}\left(\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}:\left|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right|_{2} \leq c_{n}}\left|\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{*}\right| \leq \ell_{n}\right) \rightarrow 1
$$

as $n \rightarrow \infty$, with some $c_{n} \rightarrow 0$ satisfying $\nu c_{n}^{-1} \rightarrow 0$. Proposition 1 shows that $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}$ is consistent to the true parameter $\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}$, allowing $r$ growing exponentially with the sample size $n$.

Proposition 1. Let $P_{\nu}(\cdot) \in \mathscr{P}$ be a convex function for $\mathscr{P}$ defined as (4). Under Conditions 1 , 2(a) and 2(b), if $\log r \ll n^{1 / 3}$ and $\ell_{n} n^{-1 / 2}(\log r)^{1 / 2} \ll \min \left\{\nu, n^{-1 / \gamma}\right\}$, then the PEL estimator $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}$ defined as (3) satisfies $\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}-\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right|_{\infty}=O_{\mathrm{p}}(\nu)$.

Proposition 1 establishes the consistency of the PEL estimator with diverging $r$, incorporating the impact of the penalty function. In particular, the convergence rate of $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}$ is $\nu$, provided that the tuning parameter $\nu$ in (3) satisfies $\nu \gg \ell_{n} n^{-1 / 2}(\log r)^{1 / 2}$. As a result, the convergence rate of

$\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}$ is slower than $n^{-1 / 2}$, which can be viewed as the price paid for using the penalty in handling exponentially growing dimensionality $r$.

Recall $\rho(t ; \nu)=\nu^{-1} P_{\nu}(t)$. For $P_{\nu}(\cdot) \in \mathscr{P}$ with $\mathscr{P}$ defined as (4), since $\rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+} ; \nu\right)$ is independent of $\nu$, we write it as $\rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)$for simplicity. Let $\mathcal{R}_{n}=\operatorname{supp}\left\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}$ for the Lagrange multiplier $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)=\left(\hat{\lambda}_{1}, \ldots, \hat{\lambda}_{r}\right)^{\top}=\arg \max _{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \hat{\Lambda}_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)} f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)$ with $f_{n}(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})$ defined as (5). Then $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}$ and $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)$ satisfy the score equation:

$$
\mathbf{0}=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\mathbf{g}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i} ; \hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)}{1+\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)^{\top} \mathbf{g}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i} ; \hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)}-\hat{\boldsymbol{\eta}}
$$

where $\hat{\boldsymbol{\eta}}=\left(\hat{\eta}_{1}, \ldots, \hat{\eta}_{r}\right)^{\top}$ with $\hat{\eta}_{j}=\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(\left|\hat{\lambda}_{j}\right| ; \nu\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left(\hat{\lambda}_{j}\right)$ for $\hat{\lambda}_{j} \neq 0$ and $\hat{\eta}_{j} \in\left[-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right), \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)\right]$ for $\hat{\lambda}_{j}=0$. Here, an effective drastic dimension reduction is achieved with the associated sparse $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)$. The use of the penalty function $P_{\nu}(\cdot)$ leads to $\hat{\boldsymbol{\eta}}$ in (11), an extra term compared to that of the conventional EL. While $P_{\nu}(\cdot)$ ensures the consistency of $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}$ as shown in Proposition 1, as we will show in Theorem 1 later, $\hat{\boldsymbol{\eta}}$ leads to a bias of the PEL estimator $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}$.

We further remark that while penalizing the Lagrange multiplier in our PEL does effectively achieve the selection of moments, its properties in terms of the validity of the selected moments remain an interesting research question. On one hand, it is reasonable to expect that under appropriate conditions and with a suitably chosen tuning parameter, our PEL may correctly select the set of valid moments. On the other hand, the major challenge lies in the ambiguity of defining valid moments when the corresponding moment functions are evaluated at broad candidate values of the model parameters rather than the truth. This consideration opens the door to a research question of its own interest in the context of moment selection that we are interested in investigating in our future research.

To study the asymptotic distribution of $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}$, we need the following regularity conditions.
Condition 3. Let $\mathbf{Q}_{\mathcal{F}}=\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{\mathcal{F}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)^{\top, \otimes 2}$ for any $\mathcal{F} \subset[r]$. There exist universal constants $0<K_{5}<$ $K_{6}$ such that $K_{5}<\lambda_{\min }\left(\mathbf{Q}_{\mathcal{F}}\right) \leq \lambda_{\max }\left(\mathbf{Q}_{\mathcal{F}}\right)<K_{6}$ for any $\mathcal{F}$ with $p \leq|\mathcal{F}| \leq \ell_{n}$.

Condition 4. (a) For the PEL estimator $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}$ defined as (3), there exists a constant $\tilde{c} \in\left(C_{*}, 1\right)$ such that

$$
\mathbb{P}\left[\bigcup_{j \in[r]}\left\{\tilde{c} \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \leq\left|\mathbb{E}_{n}\left\{g_{j}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i} ; \hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}\right|<\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)\right\}\right] \rightarrow 0
$$

as $n \rightarrow \infty$. (b) It holds that

$$
\mathbb{P}\left[\bigcup_{j \in \mathcal{R}_{n}^{r}}\left\{\left|\hat{\eta}_{j}\right|=\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)\right\}\right] \rightarrow 0
$$

as $n \rightarrow \infty$.

Discussion of Conditions 3 and 4 are given in Section B of the supplementary material. Write $\widehat{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)=\mathbb{E}_{n}\left\{\mathbf{g}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i} ; \hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)^{\otimes 2}\right\}$ and $\widehat{\boldsymbol{\Gamma}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)=\mathbb{E}_{n}\left\{\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \mathbf{g}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i} ; \hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}$. Define

$$
\widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}=\left\{\widehat{\boldsymbol{\Gamma}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1 / 2}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}^{\otimes 2} \text { and } \hat{\boldsymbol{\psi}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}=\widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1} \widehat{\boldsymbol{\Gamma}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) \hat{\boldsymbol{\eta}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}
$$

where $\hat{\boldsymbol{\eta}}=\left(\hat{\eta}_{1}, \ldots, \hat{\eta}_{r}\right)^{\top}$ is specified in (11). We assume $\left(r, \ell_{n}, \nu\right)$ satisfy the following restrictions:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\log r \ll \min \left\{n^{1 / 3}, n^{(\gamma-2) /(2 \gamma)}\right\}, \quad \ell_{n} \ll \min \left\{n^{(\gamma-2) /(3 \gamma)}(\log r)^{-2 / 3}, n^{1 / 5}(\log r)^{-2 / 5}\right\} \\
\text { and } \ell_{n} n^{-1 / 2}(\log r)^{1 / 2} \ll \nu \ll \ell_{n}^{-1 / 4} n^{-1 / 4}
\end{gathered}
$$

The asymptotic distribution of $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}$ is stated in Theorem 1, where the bias term $\hat{\boldsymbol{\psi}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}$ comes from the penalty function $P_{\nu}(\cdot)$ imposed on the Lagrange multiplier $\boldsymbol{\lambda}$ in (3).

Theorem 1. Let $P_{\nu}(\cdot) \in \mathscr{P}$ be convex with bounded second-order derivative around 0 , where $\mathscr{P}$ is defined as (4). Assume Conditions $1-4$ hold with $\left(r, \ell_{n}, \nu\right)$ satisfying (13). For any $\mathbf{t} \in \mathbb{R}^{p}$ with $|\mathbf{t}|_{2}=1$, the PEL estimator $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}$ defined as (3) satisfies $n^{1 / 2} \mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{1 / 2}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}-\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}-\hat{\boldsymbol{\psi}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\right) \rightarrow \mathcal{N}(0,1)$ in distribution as $n \rightarrow \infty$, where $\widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}$ and $\hat{\boldsymbol{\psi}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}$ are defined in (12).

Here, the estimated bias $\hat{\boldsymbol{\psi}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}$ can be easily calculated based on (12). Theorem 1 indicates that, upon correcting the bias by subtracting it from $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}$, the resulting estimator $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}-\hat{\boldsymbol{\psi}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}$ is $n^{1 / 2}$-consistent and asymptotically normal.

# 5.2 Properties of the Posterior Distribution and Algorithms 

For the proposed BPEL, we establish the Bernstein-von Mises theorem for the posterior distribution $\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)$, as defined in (7). Furthermore, we provide theoretical assurances for the performance of Algorithms 1 and 2 in Section 2.3.

For any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}$, write $\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\operatorname{supp}\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\}$ with

$$
\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\left\{\hat{\lambda}_{1}(\boldsymbol{\theta}), \ldots, \hat{\lambda}_{r}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}^{\top}=\arg \max _{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \Lambda_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta})} f_{n}(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})
$$

where $f_{n}(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})$ is defined as (5). Then $\boldsymbol{\theta}$ and $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ satisfy the score equation:

$$
\mathbf{0}=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\mathbf{g}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\right)}{1+\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\right)}-\hat{\boldsymbol{\eta}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})
$$

where $\hat{\boldsymbol{\eta}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\left\{\hat{\eta}_{1}(\boldsymbol{\theta}), \ldots, \hat{\eta}_{r}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}^{\top}$ with $\hat{\eta}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\nu \rho^{\prime}\left\{\left|\hat{\lambda}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right| ; \nu\right\} \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\hat{\lambda}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}$ for $\hat{\lambda}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \neq 0$ and $\hat{\eta}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \in\left[-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right), \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)\right]$for $\hat{\lambda}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=0$. By the definition of the PEL estimator $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}$, we have $f_{n}\left\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\right\} \geq f_{n}\left\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) ; \hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right\}$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}$. To investigate the asymptotic properties of the posterior distribution $\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)$ defined as (7), we need to first study the asymptotic behavior of $\aleph_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=f_{n}\left\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\right\}-f_{n}\left\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) ; \hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right\}$ for $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}$. Given $\alpha_{n}=n^{-1 / 2}(\log r)^{1 / 2}$ and some $\beta_{n}$ satisfying $\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \nu \ll \beta_{n} \ll \min \left\{\ell_{n}^{-1} n^{-1 / \gamma}, \nu^{2 / 3} \ell_{n}^{-2 / 3} n^{-1 /(3 \gamma)}\right\}$, we split the whole parameter space $\boldsymbol{\Theta}$ into three regions: $\mathcal{C}_{1}=\left\{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}:\left|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right|_{2} \leq \alpha_{n}\right\}, \mathcal{C}_{2}=\left\{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}: \alpha_{n}<\left|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right|_{2} \leq \beta_{n}\right\}$ and $\mathcal{C}_{3}=\left\{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}:\left|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right|_{2}>\beta_{n}\right\}$. Proposition 2 in the supplementary material shows that the asymptotic behavior of $\aleph_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ for $\boldsymbol{\theta}$ in these three regions are different.

Investigating the asymptotic behavior of $\aleph_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ calls some new technical arguments. Write

$$
\tilde{f}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \log \left\{1+\boldsymbol{\lambda}^{\top} \mathbf{g}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\right)\right\} \text { and } \tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\arg \max _{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \hat{\lambda}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta})} \tilde{f}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})
$$

When $r$ is a fixed constant, we know $2 n \tilde{f}_{n}\{\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\}$ is the conventional log-EL ratio in the literature. The asymptotic behavior of $2 n \tilde{f}_{n}\{\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\}$ depends on the magnitude of $\mathbb{E}\left\{\mathbf{g}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\right)\right\}$. More specifically, under some mild conditions, it holds that (i) $2 n \tilde{f}_{n}\{\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\}$ is asymptotically chi-square distributed with degree of freedom $r$ if $\left|\mathbb{E}\left\{\mathbf{g}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\right)\right\}\right|_{2} \ll n^{-1 / 2}$, (ii) $2 n \tilde{f}_{n}\{\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\}$ converges to a noncentral chi-square distribution if $\left|\mathbb{E}\left\{\mathbf{g}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\right)\right\}\right|_{2} \asymp n^{-1 / 2}$, and (iii) $2 n \tilde{f}_{n}\{\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\}$ diverges to $\infty$ in probability if $\left|\mathbb{E}\left\{\mathbf{g}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\right)\right\}\right|_{2} \gg n^{-1 / 2}$. See, for example, Proposition 1 and Theorem 1 of Chang et al. (2013) for such results with $r=1$. In comparison to $\tilde{f}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})$ defined in (15), $f_{n}(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})$ involved in $\aleph_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ includes a penalty term imposed on the Lagrange multiplier $\boldsymbol{\lambda}$. This makes the standard technique for analyzing the conventional log-EL ratio inapplicable. To further establish the Bernstein-von Mises theorem for the posterior distribution $\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)$ defined as (7), we assume the following regularity conditions.

Condition 5. (a) There exists a constant $\bar{c} \in(0,1)$ such that

$$
\mathbb{P}\left\{\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}} \max _{j \in \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\bar{c}}}\left|\hat{\eta}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right| \leq \bar{c} \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)\right\} \rightarrow 1
$$

as $n \rightarrow \infty$, where $\hat{\eta}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ is specified in (14). (b) There exists $\kappa_{n}$ satisfying $\max \left\{\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} n^{-1 / 2}(\log r)^{1 / 2}\right.$, $\left.\ell_{n} \beta_{n}^{3 / 2} n^{1 /(2 \gamma)}\right\} \ll \kappa_{n} \ll \nu$ such that

$$
\mathbb{P}\left[\bigcup_{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{2}} \bigcup_{j \in \mathcal{R}_{n}}\left\{\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)-\kappa_{n}<\left|\mathbb{E}_{n}\left\{g_{j}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\right)\right\}\right|<\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)+\kappa_{n}\right\}\right] \rightarrow 0
$$

as $n \rightarrow \infty$. (c) There exist universal constants $K_{7}, K_{8}>0$ such that

$$
\mathbb{P}\left\{\inf _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}} \lambda_{\min }\left(\left[\mathbb{E}_{n}\left\{\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \mathbf{g}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\right)\right\}\right]^{\top, \otimes 2}\right) \geq K_{7}\right\} \rightarrow 1 \text { and } \mathbb{P}\left[\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{3}} \lambda_{\max }\left\{\tilde{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\} \leq K_{8}\right] \rightarrow 1
$$

as $n \rightarrow \infty$.

Condition 6. The prior density $\pi_{0}(\cdot)$ is continuously differentiable with bounded first-order derivatives and $\pi_{0}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)>0$.

Discussion of Conditions 5 and 6 are given in Section B of the supplementary material. Let $\Pi_{n}^{\dagger}(\cdot)$ be the measure which admits the posterior distribution $\pi^{\dagger}\left(\cdot \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)$. Denote by $\mathcal{N}_{\boldsymbol{\mu}, \boldsymbol{\Sigma}}(\cdot)$ the Gaussian measure with mean $\boldsymbol{\mu}$ and covariance matrix $\boldsymbol{\Sigma}$. To establish the Bernstein-von Mises theorem for the posterior distribution $\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)$ as in Theorem 2, we need to assume $\left(r, \ell_{n}, \nu\right)$ satisfy the following restrictions:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\log r \ll n^{(\gamma-2) /(3 \gamma)}, \quad \ell_{n} \ll \min \left\{n^{(\gamma-2) /(9 \gamma)}(\log r)^{-1 / 9}, n^{1 / 3}(\log r)^{-1}, n^{(\gamma-2) /(2 \gamma)}(\log r)^{-3 / 2}\right\} \\
\text { and } \ell_{n} n^{-1 / 2}(\log r)^{1 / 2} \ll \nu \ll \min \left\{\ell_{n}^{-7 / 2} n^{-1 / \gamma},(\log r)^{-1}\right\}
\end{gathered}
$$

Theorem 2. Let $P_{\nu}(\cdot) \in \mathscr{P}$ be convex and assume $\rho(t ; \nu)=\nu^{-1} P_{\nu}(t)$ has bounded second-order derivative with respect to $t$ around 0 , where $\mathscr{P}$ is defined in (4). Assume Conditions $1-6$ hold with $\left(r, \ell_{n}, \nu\right)$ satisfying (16). The posterior distribution $\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)$ converges in total variation toward a Gaussian distribution $\mathcal{N}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}, n^{-1} \tilde{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1}\right)$ in probability, that is, $\mathcal{D}_{\mathrm{Tv}}\left(\Pi_{n}^{\dagger}, \mathcal{N}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}, n^{-1} \tilde{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1}}\right) \rightarrow 0$ in probability as $n \rightarrow \infty$, where $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}$ is the PEL estimator in (3), and $\tilde{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}$ is defined in (12).

Theorem 2 shows that $\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)$ has a Gaussian limiting distribution and it concentrates on a $n^{-1 / 2}$-ball centered at the PEL estimator $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}$ of interest, which indicates that $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}$ can be approximated by the mean of the posterior distribution $\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)$. More specifically, as shown in Corollary 1, the approximation error is of order smaller than $n^{-1 / 2}$.

Corollary 1. Under the conditions of Theorem 2, we have $\left|\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\theta} \sim \pi^{\dagger}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right|_{\infty}=o_{\mathrm{p}}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)$, where $\overline{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}$ is the PEL estimator defined as (3), and $\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\theta} \sim \pi^{\dagger}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ is defined in (8).

Theorems 3 and 4 state the theoretical guarantees for Algorithms 1 and 2, respectively.

Theorem 3. For the density $\phi(\cdot \mid \cdot)$ of the proposal distribution in Algorithm 1, we assume $\phi(\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \mid \boldsymbol{\theta})$ is positive and continuous on $(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta}) \in \boldsymbol{\Theta} \times \boldsymbol{\Theta}$. Conditional on $\mathcal{X}_{n}$, for any $\boldsymbol{\theta}^{0} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}$ such that $\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{0} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)>0$ with $\pi^{\dagger}\left(\cdot \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)$ defined as (7), it holds that $\mathcal{D}_{\mathrm{Tv}}\left(\mathcal{T}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}^{0}}^{k}, \Pi_{n}^{\dagger}\right) \rightarrow 0$ as $k \rightarrow \infty$, where $\mathcal{T}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}^{0}}^{k}(\cdot)$ is the measure which admits the distribution of the Markov chain determined by Algorithm 1 at $k$-th step with initial point $\boldsymbol{\theta}^{0}$. Furthermore, conditional on $\mathcal{X}_{n},\left|K^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \boldsymbol{\theta}^{k}-\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\theta} \sim \pi^{\dagger}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|_{\infty} \rightarrow$ 0 almost surely as $K \rightarrow \infty$, where $\left\{\boldsymbol{\theta}^{k}\right\}_{k \geq 1}$ are generated via Algorithm 1 with the initial point $\boldsymbol{\theta}^{0}$ satisfying $\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{0} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)>0$.

Theorem 4. For the density $\varphi(\cdot ; \cdot)$ of the proposal distribution and the function $\mathbf{h}: \mathbb{R}^{p} \mapsto$ $\mathbb{R}^{s}$ in Algorithm 2, we assume $\varphi(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta})$ is positive and continuous on $(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\zeta}) \in \boldsymbol{\Theta} \times \mathbb{R}^{s}$ and $\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}}|\mathbf{h}(\boldsymbol{\theta})|_{\infty} \leq K_{9}$ for some universal constant $K_{9}>0$. Conditional on $\mathcal{X}_{n}$, if $\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \exp \left(-C N_{k}\right)<$ $\infty$ for any $C>0$, then $\left|\widehat{\mathbb{E}}_{\pi^{\dagger}, K}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\theta} \sim \pi^{\dagger}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|_{\infty} \rightarrow 0$ almost surely as $K \rightarrow \infty$, where $\widehat{\mathbb{E}}_{\pi^{\dagger}, K}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ is the MAMIS estimator defined as (9).

# 6 Discussion 

In this paper, we explore BPEL and demonstrate its promising performance using MCMC sampling as a competitive alternative to optimization in addressing EL problems. This framework has the potential for further advancements in several areas. To maintain focus and avoid digressions, we have confined our study to fixed-dimensional model parameters and exponentially growing moment conditions. However, there is significant interest in extending this approach to tackle variable and model selection using BPEL, which could accommodate high-dimensional sparse model parameters and potentially a continuum of moment conditions, as considered in Chaussé (2017). Incorporating specific priors in the context of concrete studies, particularly in high-dimensional problems, is another area of interest. Research in this direction presents additional challenges, especially in selecting appropriate priors, developing efficient sampling schemes, and conducting associated analyses.

In the broader context of Bayesian methodology, approximate Bayesian computation (ABC) and Bayesian synthetic likelihood (BSL) are two competitive methods for handling situations where the likelihood is difficult to evaluate or intractable. ABC and BSL have been extensively compared in the literature. We demonstrate that the rationale of ABC integrates well with our BPEL method, achieving both accuracy and computational efficiency. Our Algorithm 2, inspired by ABC , uses importance weights for samples drawn from an alternative distribution to address challenging sampling situations. Empirical evidence shows promising performance, particularly in difficult cases. BSL leverages the limiting distribution, such as the normal distribution, to handle intractable probability distributions, with the advantage of easy sampling from the normal distribution. We view our BPEL as a compelling alternative to BSL: EL uses a multinomial likelihood that incorporates model information without requiring a fully specified parametric model, making it a competitive option when the full likelihood is intractable.

Furthermore, we foresee the use of more sophisticated sampling schemes in conjunction with PEL as highly valuable for addressing complex problems with specific considerations. Examples include the Hamiltonian MCMC method examined in Chaudhuri et al. (2017) and the variational Bayesian approach explored in Yu and Bondell (2024). These avenues of research are part of our plans for future projects.

# A Additional Numerical Results
## A. 1 The Impact of the Prior $\pi_{0}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$

In this section, we investigate the impact of the prior distribution $\pi_{0}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ in (7) on our proposed Bayesian penalized EL methods in estimating the true parameter $\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}$. More specifically, we adopt the data generation process outlined in Section 3.1 with the true parameter $\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}=(0.5,0.5)^{\top}$, and consider three choices for the prior:
(a) the prior distribution $\mathcal{N}\left\{(-1,-1)^{\top}, 0.5^{2} \mathbf{I}_{2}\right\}$, which contains no correct information about the truth.
(b) the prior $\mathcal{N}\left\{(0.6,0.6)^{\top}, 0.5^{2} \mathbf{I}_{2}\right\}$, which concentrates around the true value.
(c) the improper uniform prior, which provides no information about $\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}$.

For the 49 initial points mentioned in Section 3.3, we calculate the measure $\mathrm{MSE}_{2}$ defined in Section 3.4 to evaluate the performance of these estimators. The results for M-H and MAMIS are derived based on the generated samples of size 3500. Table S1 summarizes the performance of our proposed methods with such selected three priors. In particular, we have observed that when the prior is specified "closer" to the truth, the resulting estimator has better performance in comparison to the one using a non-informative prior. Conversely, if a prior is specified "further away" from the truth, the performance of the resulting estimator deteriorates and becomes less competitive.

## A. 2 Non-Gaussian Data Generation Process

In this section, we further validate the efficacy of our proposed methods by conducting some additional simulation studies. For the simulation examples considered in Sections 3.3 and 3.4, we let all instrumental variables (IVs) $z_{i, j}$ be independently and identically distributed following the Student's $t$-distribution with three degrees of freedoms. For the 49 initial points mentioned in Section 3.3, we calculate the measure $\mathrm{MSE}_{1}$ defined in Section 3.3 to evaluate the performance of these methods. The results for Algorithms 1 and 2 based on sample sizes of 1500, 2500, and 3500 are denoted by (M-H-1, M-H-2, M-H-3) and (MAMIS-1, MAMIS-2, MAMIS-3), respectively. The results for $n=120$ and $n=240$ are presented in Tables S2 and S3, respectively. Furthermore, we

# A. 4 Comparison of the Performance of Posteriors Derived by Different Methods 

In this section, we conduct some additional numerical studies to further compare the performance of posteriors derived by different methods. Assume the observations $\mathbf{x}_{1}, \ldots, \mathbf{x}_{n}$ are drawn independently from the distribution $F\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$ with some unknown parameter $\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}$. The likelihood function admits the form $L(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\prod_{i=1}^{n} f\left(\mathbf{x}_{i} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\right)$ where $f(\cdot ; \boldsymbol{\theta})$ is the density function of $F_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$. Write $\mathcal{X}_{n}=\left\{\mathbf{x}_{1}, \ldots, \mathbf{x}_{n}\right\}$. Let $\pi_{0}(\cdot)$ represent a prior distribution for $\boldsymbol{\theta}$. Then the traditional posterior is given by $\pi^{\mathrm{L}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right) \propto \pi_{0}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \times L(\boldsymbol{\theta})$. To estimate the unknown parameter $\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}$, we can also identify it by $\mathbb{E}\left\{\mathbf{g}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right\}=\mathbf{0}$ with some $r$-dimensional estimating function $\mathbf{g}(\cdot ; \cdot)$. For given estimating function $\mathbf{g}(\cdot ; \cdot)$, we can define the empirical likelihood $\operatorname{EL}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ and penalized empirical

likelihood $\operatorname{PEL}_{\nu}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$, respectively, as (1) and (6) in the main paper. Hence, the associated ELbased posterior distribution $\pi^{\mathrm{EL}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)$ and PEL-based posterior distribution $\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)$ satisfy $\pi^{\mathrm{EL}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right) \propto \pi_{0}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \times \operatorname{EL}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ and $\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right) \propto \pi_{0}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \times \operatorname{PEL}_{\nu}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$. We select $\pi_{0}(\cdot)$ as the improper uniform prior and compare these three posteriors via the following two models:

- Model I: Let $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n}$ be independent and identically distributed observations from the normal distribution $\mathcal{N}\left(0, \theta_{0}^{2}\right)$ with $\theta_{0}=1$. We can select $\mathbf{g}(\cdot ; \cdot)=\left\{g_{1}(\cdot ; \cdot), \ldots, g_{r}(\cdot ; \cdot)\}^{\top} \in\right.$ $\mathbb{R}^{r}$ with $g_{j}\left(x_{i} ; \theta\right)=x_{i}^{2 j}-(2 j-1)!!\theta^{2 j}$.
- Model II: Consider the linear regression model $y_{i}=z_{i} \theta_{0}+e_{i}, i \in[n]$, where $\theta_{0}=0.5$, $z_{i} \sim \mathcal{N}(0,1)$ is the covariate variable and $e_{i} \sim \mathcal{N}(0,0.9)$ is the error orthogonal to $z_{i}$. We can select $\mathbf{g}(\cdot ; \cdot)=\left\{g_{1}(\cdot ; \cdot), \ldots, g_{r}(\cdot ; \cdot)\}^{\top} \in \mathbb{R}^{r}\right.$ with $g_{j}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i} ; \theta\right)=\left(y_{i}-z_{i} \theta\right) z_{i}^{j}$ and $\mathbf{x}_{i}=\left(y_{i}, z_{i}\right)^{\top}$.
- Model III: Consider the generalized linear model where the covariates $z_{i}, i \in[n]$, are drawn independently from the gamma distribution with shape parameter 2 and rate parameter 1. The response variables $y_{i}, i \in[n]$, are generated from the Bernoulli distribution such that $\mathbb{P}\left(y_{i}=1 \mid z_{i}\right)=\exp \left(z_{i} \theta_{0}\right) /\left\{1+\exp \left(z_{i} \theta_{0}\right)\right\}$ with the true parameter $\theta_{0}=0.2$. We can select $\mathbf{g}(\cdot ; \cdot)=\left\{g_{1}(\cdot ; \cdot), \ldots, g_{r}(\cdot ; \cdot)\}^{\top} \in \mathbb{R}^{r}\right.$ with $g_{j}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i} ; \theta\right)=\left[y_{i}-\exp \left(z_{i} \theta\right) /\left\{1+\exp \left(z_{i} \theta\right)\right\}\right] z_{i}^{j}$ and $\mathbf{x}_{i}=\left(y_{i}, z_{i}\right)^{\top}$.

We generate 5000 samples from each of these posterior distributions via the M-H algorithm with the burn-in period of 2000 iterations. Based on these samples, we compute the Wasserstein distances between $\pi^{\mathrm{L}}\left(\theta \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)$ and $\pi^{\mathrm{EL}}\left(\theta \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)$, as well as between $\pi^{\mathrm{L}}\left(\theta \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)$ and $\pi^{\dagger}\left(\theta \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)$, using the function wasserstein in the R-package transport. Figure S2 below illustrates the average Wasserstein distances between these posterior distributions across different sample sizes $n$ under 500 replications. Figures S3 and S4 show the density functions of $\pi^{\mathrm{L}}\left(\theta \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right), \pi^{\mathrm{EL}}\left(\theta \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)$ and $\pi^{\dagger}\left(\theta \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)$ across different sample sizes $n$ in one replication.

Overall, the numerical results indicate that the posterior distributions constructed the (unpenalized) empirical likelihood without the penalty on the Lagrange multiplier exhibit significant discrepancies from those derived from the likelihood function. However, this disparity can be markedly reduced through the introduction of a penalty term on the Lagrange multipliers in the

# A. 5 Comparison to ABC and BSL 

In this section, we compare the performance of our proposed methods with the approximate Bayesian computation (ABC) and Bayesian synthetic likelihood (BSL) methods, implemented as described below.

- abc: The R function performs parameter estimation using the approximate Bayesian computation (ABC) algorithm in the R-package abc.

![img-5.jpeg](img-5.jpeg)

Figure S4: Comparison of the density functions of the posterior distributions derived by different methods with $r=70$.

- bsl: The R function for performing Bayesian synthetic likelihood (BSL) to sample from the approximate posterior distribution in the R-package BSL.

We conduct the comparisons using the same three models as described in Section A.4. Both the ABC and BSL methods require the selection of summary statistics. In our numerical experiments, for demonstration purposes, we chose sufficient statistics for the parameters of interest, thereby favoring the ABC and BSL methods. Specifically, for Model I, we selected the sample standard deviation as the summary statistic. For Models II and III, we selected the maximum likelihood

estimator as the summary statistic.

When implementing abc, we set the tolerance levels to $0.05,0.1$, and 0.2 to obtain 5000 valid approximate samples of the traditional posterior distributions for the three models. These tolerance levels correspond to $100,000,50,000$, and $25,000 \mathrm{MCMC}$ iterations, respectively. The results are labeled as (abc-0.05, abc-0.1, abc-0.2). For bsl, we ran the MCMC sampler for 7000 iterations, discarding the first 2000 iterations for burn-in.

To evaluate the performance of abc and bsl, we used the wasserstein function from the R package transport to compute the Wasserstein distances between the approximate samples and those obtained directly via the Metropolis-Hastings (M-H) algorithm from the traditional posterior distribution. For our PEL method, we report results for the case with $r=50$ and also evaluate the corresponding Wasserstein distances relative to those generated by the M-H algorithm. Figure S5 below presents the results, showing the average Wasserstein distances calculated for different sample sizes $n$ under 500 replications.
![img-6.jpeg](img-6.jpeg)

Figure S5: Comparisons of the proposed method, ABC, and BSL. The average Wasserstein distances based on 500 replications are reported for the three models.

Overall, the numerical results indicate that our proposed method, along with abc and bsl, effectively approximates the posterior distribution, with the accuracy of the approximation improving as the sample size $n$ increases. For smaller sample sizes, abc and bsl exhibit better accuracy. However, as the sample size $n$ grows, our proposed method demonstrates substantial improvements, achieving satisfactory approximation accuracy. Additionally, it is notable that the ABC method often requires significantly higher computational costs to achieve comparable

approximation accuracy.
Here, we also note that the settings favor the ABC and BSL methods in the choice of summary statistics, yet our method performs very competitively. Figure S6(b) presents results from a slightly modified setting of Model I, where the data generation process is changed from a normal distribution to a Student's $t$-distribution with 10 degrees of freedom, and we are still interested in estimating the standard deviation parameter. In this case, the summary statistic based on the sample standard deviation for ABC and BSL is no longer sufficient. For side-by-side comparisons, the corresponding case with results from the normal distribution is shown in Figure S6(a). In this scenario, the performance of the PEL-based method is superior, demonstrating the compelling performance of our approach, owing to the merits of using empirical likelihood.

# B Discussion of the Technical Conditions 

Conditions 1 and 2 are commonly used assumptions in the literature. Condition 1 is the identification condition for the unknown true parameter $\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}$. A similar condition can be found in Shi (2016) and Chang et al. (2018). Condition 2(b) requires the covariance matrix of $\mathbf{g}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$ behaves reasonably well. Conditions 2(a) and 2(c) impose the moments requirements on each estimating function $g_{j}(\cdot ; \cdot)$ and its derivatives. If there exist functions $B_{l}(\cdot)$ with $\mathbb{E}\left\{B_{l}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)\right\}<\infty, l=1,2,3$, such that $\left|g_{j}(\mathbf{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})\right|^{\gamma} \leq B_{1}(\mathbf{x}),\left|\partial g_{j}(\mathbf{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}) / \partial \theta_{k}\right|^{2} \leq B_{2}(\mathbf{x})$ and $\left|\partial^{2} g_{j}(\mathbf{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}) / \partial \theta_{k_{1}} \partial \theta_{k_{2}}\right|^{2} \leq B_{3}(\mathbf{x})$ for

any $j \in[r]$ and $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}$, then the second requirement in Condition 2(a) and the two requirements in Condition 2(c) hold automatically. More generally, if there exist functions $B_{l, j}(\cdot)$ such that $\left|g_{j}(\mathbf{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})\right|^{\gamma} \leq B_{1, j}(\mathbf{x}),\left|\partial g_{j}(\mathbf{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}) / \partial \theta_{k}\right|^{2} \leq B_{2, j}(\mathbf{x})$ and $\left|\partial^{2} g_{j}(\mathbf{x} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}) / \partial \theta_{k_{1}} \partial \theta_{k_{2}}\right|^{2} \leq B_{3, j}(\mathbf{x})$ for any $j \in[r]$ and $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}$, and $\max _{j \in[r]} \mathbb{E}\left\{B_{l, j}^{m}\left(\mathbf{x}_{i}\right)\right\} \leq K m!H^{m-2}$ for any $m \geq 2$ and $l=1,2,3$ with two universal constants $K, H>0$, it follows from Theorem 2.8 of Petrov (1995) that the second requirement in Condition 2(a) and the two requirements in Condition 2(c) hold automatically provided $\log (r p)=o(n)$. In fact, the order $O_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$ in Conditions 2(a) and 2(c) can be replaced by $O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\varpi_{n}\right)$ with some diverging sequence $\varpi_{n}$, and our main results remain valid. We use $O_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$ here for ease of presentation. To establish the consistency of the penalized empirical likelihood estimator $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}$, Conditions 1, 2(a) and 2(b) are needed. Condition 2(c) is needed for establishing the asymptotic normality of $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}$.

Condition 3 is standard in the literature. Due to the penalty imposed on the Lagrange multiplier $\boldsymbol{\lambda}$ involved in the optimization (3), the standard theoretical analysis of empirical likelihood cannot be applied here. Condition 4(a) is a technical assumption used to derive the convergence rate of the Lagrange multiplier $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)=\arg \max _{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \hat{\Lambda}_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)} f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)$ associated with $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}$; see the proof of Lemma 3 in the supplementary material for details. Condition 4(b) requires that each $\hat{\eta}_{j}$ $\left(j \in \mathcal{R}_{n}^{c}\right)$ lies in the interior of $\left[-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right), \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)\right]$with probability approaching one, which is realistic in practice. If the distribution function of the random variable $\hat{\eta}_{j}$ is continuous at $\pm \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)$, we then have $\mathbb{P}\left\{\left|\hat{\eta}_{j}\right|=\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)\right\}=0$. Condition 4 makes sure that $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\arg \max _{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \hat{\Lambda}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta})} f_{n}(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})$ is continuously differentiable at $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}$ with probability approaching one; see Lemma 4 in Section D.

Condition 5(a) guarantees that the Lagrange multiplier $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ for $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$ satisfies two properties: (i) $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ is continuously differentiable on $\mathcal{C}_{1}$ with probability approaching one, and (ii) $\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=$ $\mathcal{R}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$ with probability approaching one; see Lemmas 9 and 10 in Section F. When $\boldsymbol{\theta} \notin \mathcal{C}_{1}$, characterizing the asymptotic property of $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ is quite challenging. Due to $f_{n}\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\} \geq f_{n}(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})$ for any $\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \hat{\Lambda}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$, a feasible strategy to construct the lower bound of $f_{n}\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\}$ with $\boldsymbol{\theta} \notin \mathcal{C}_{1}$ is to find a specific $\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{*}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \in \hat{\Lambda}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ and then derive the lower bound of $f_{n}\left\{\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{*}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\right\}$ directly, where the asymptotic behavior of $\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{*}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ can be well characterized even if $\boldsymbol{\theta} \notin \mathcal{C}_{1}$. Such strategy has been also used in Chang et al. $(2013,2016)$ to study the diverging rate

of the conventional empirical likelihood ratio evaluated at a value not near the truth. In current setting, Condition 5(b) is applied to derive the lower bound of $f_{n}\left\{\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{*}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\right\}$ for $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{2}$; see Section F. 2 for details. Condition 5(c) says that the sample covariance matrix of the estimating function and the gradient of the estimating function should behave reasonably well, which will be used to obtain the lower bound of $f_{n}\left\{\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{*}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\right\}$ for $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{3}$. See Section F. 3 for details. Condition 6 is a standard assumption concerning the prior distribution.

# C Proof of Proposition 1 

Write $\mathcal{R}_{0}=\mathcal{R}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\max _{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \hat{\Lambda}_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)} f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right) & =\max _{\boldsymbol{\eta} \in \hat{\Lambda}_{n}^{\prime}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)}\left\{\mathbb{E}_{n}\left[\log \left\{1+\boldsymbol{\eta}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}_{0}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right\}\right]-\sum_{j=1}^{\left|\mathcal{R}_{0}\right|} P_{\nu}\left(\left|\eta_{j}\right|\right)\right\} \\
& \leq \max _{\boldsymbol{\eta} \in \hat{\Lambda}_{n}^{\prime}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)} \mathbb{E}_{n}\left[\log \left\{1+\boldsymbol{\eta}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}_{0}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right\}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\hat{\Lambda}_{n}^{\prime}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)=\left\{\boldsymbol{\eta}=\left(\eta_{1}, \ldots, \eta_{\left|\mathcal{R}_{0}\right)}\right)^{\top} \in \mathbb{R}^{\left|\mathcal{R}_{0}\right|}: \boldsymbol{\eta}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}_{0}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right) \in \mathcal{V}\right.$ for any $\left.i \in[n]\right\}$ for some open interval $\mathcal{V}$ containing zero. Our first step is to show $\max _{\boldsymbol{\eta} \in \hat{\Lambda}_{n}^{\prime}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)} \mathbb{E}_{n}\left[\log \left\{1+\boldsymbol{\eta}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}_{0}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right\}\right]=$ $O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}^{2}\right)$. To do this, we need the following two lemmas whose proofs are given in Sections J. 1 and J.2, respectively.

Lemma 1. Let $\mathscr{F}=\left\{\mathcal{F} \subset[r]:|\mathcal{F}| \leq \ell_{n}\right\}$ and $\mathcal{B}_{\infty, \mathrm{p}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}, \varphi_{n}\right)=\left\{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}:\left|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right|_{\infty} \leq O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\varphi_{n}\right)\right\}$ for $\varphi_{n}=o\left(\ell_{n}^{-1 / 2}\right)$. Under Condition 2, if $\log r=o\left(n^{1 / 3}\right)$ and $\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}=o(1)$, then

$$
\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{B}_{\infty, \mathrm{p}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}, \varphi_{n}\right)} \sup _{\mathcal{F} \in \mathscr{F}}\left\|\widetilde{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{F}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\mathbf{V}_{\mathcal{F}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right\|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \varphi_{n}\right)+O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}\right)
$$

Lemma 2. Let $\log r=o\left(n^{1 / 3}\right), \ell_{n} \alpha_{n}=o\left[\min \left\{\nu, n^{-1 / \gamma}\right\}\right]$, and $P_{\nu}(\cdot) \in \mathscr{P}$ be a convex function for $\mathscr{P}$ defined in (4). Assume Conditions 2(a) and 2(b) hold. For any $c \in\left(C_{*}, 1\right)$, the global maximizer $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$ for $f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$ w.r.t $\boldsymbol{\lambda}$ satisfies $\operatorname{supp}\left\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right\} \subset \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}(c)$ w.p.a.1.

Define $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\eta}}=\arg \max _{\boldsymbol{\eta} \in \hat{\Lambda}_{n}^{\prime}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)} A_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}, \boldsymbol{\eta}\right)$ with $A_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\eta})=\mathbb{E}_{n}\left[\log \left\{1+\boldsymbol{\eta}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}_{0}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}\right]$. By Lemma 2, we have $\left|\mathcal{R}_{0}\right| \leq \ell_{n}$ w.p.a.1. Pick $\delta_{n}$ satisfying $\delta_{n}=o\left(\ell_{n}^{-1 / 2} n^{-1 / \gamma}\right)$ and $\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}=o\left(\delta_{n}\right)$ for $\gamma$ defined in Condition 2(a), which can be guaranteed by $\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}=o\left(n^{-1 / \gamma}\right)$. Let $\Lambda_{0}=\left\{\boldsymbol{\eta} \in \mathbb{R}^{\left|\mathcal{R}_{0}\right|}:|\boldsymbol{\eta}|_{2} \leq \delta_{n}\right\}$ and $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\eta}}=\arg \max _{\boldsymbol{\eta} \in \Lambda_{0}} A_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}, \boldsymbol{\eta}\right)$. Condition 2(a) implies $\max _{i \in[n], \boldsymbol{\eta} \in \Lambda_{0}}\left|\boldsymbol{\eta}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}_{0}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$. Then, by the Taylor expansion, we have

$$
0=A_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}, \mathbf{0}\right) \leq A_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}, \tilde{\boldsymbol{\eta}}\right)=\tilde{\boldsymbol{\eta}}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{\mathcal{R}_{0}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)-\frac{1}{2 n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\tilde{\boldsymbol{\eta}}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}_{0}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)^{\oplus 2} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\eta}}}{\left\{1+C \tilde{\boldsymbol{\eta}}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}_{0}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right\}^{2}}
$$

for some $C \in(0,1)$. By Condition 2(b) and the same arguments for deriving Lemma 1, if $\log r=$ $o\left(n^{1 / 3}\right)$ and $\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}=o(1)$, we have $\lambda_{\min }\left\{\tilde{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\sigma}_{0}}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right\}$ is uniformly bounded away from zero w.p.a.1. Thus $0 \leq|\tilde{\boldsymbol{\eta}}|_{2}\left|\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{R}_{0}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|_{2}-4^{-1} K_{3}|\tilde{\boldsymbol{\eta}}|_{2}^{2}\left\{1+o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)\right\}$ w.p.a.1, where $K_{3}$ is specified in Condition 2(b). By the moderate deviation of self-normalized sums (Jing et al., 2003), we have $\left|\tilde{\mathbf{g}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|_{\infty}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\alpha_{n}\right)$, which implies $\left|\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{R}_{0}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right)$ and $|\tilde{\boldsymbol{\eta}}|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right)=o_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\delta_{n}\right)$. Hence, $\check{\boldsymbol{\eta}} \in \operatorname{int}\left(\Lambda_{0}\right)$ w.p.a.1. Since $\Lambda_{0} \subset \hat{\Lambda}_{n}^{1}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$ w.p.a.1, we have $\check{\boldsymbol{\eta}}=\check{\boldsymbol{\eta}}$ w.p.a. 1 by the concavity of $A_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}, \boldsymbol{\eta}\right)$ w.r.t $\boldsymbol{\eta}$. Then $\max _{\boldsymbol{\eta} \in \hat{\Lambda}_{n}^{1}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)} A_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}, \boldsymbol{\eta}\right)=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}^{2}\right)$. Let $b_{n}^{2}=\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}^{2}$ and $F_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\max _{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \hat{\Lambda}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta})} f_{n}(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}$. Due to $\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}=\arg \min _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}} F_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$, we have $F_{n}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) \leq F_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(b_{n}^{2}\right)$.

Our second step is to show that for any $\epsilon_{n} \rightarrow \infty$ satisfying $b_{n}^{2} \epsilon_{n}^{2} n^{2 / \gamma}=o(1)$, there exists a universal constant $K>0$ independent of $\boldsymbol{\theta}$ such that $\mathbb{P}\left\{F_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta})>K b_{n}^{2} \epsilon_{n}^{2}\right\} \rightarrow 1$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}$ satisfying $\left|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\left.\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right|_{\infty}>\epsilon_{n} \nu\right.$. Thus $\left|\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}-\left.\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right|_{\infty}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\epsilon_{n} \nu\right)\right.$. Due to $b_{n}^{2}=o\left(n^{-2 / \gamma}\right)$, we can select arbitrary slowly diverging $\epsilon_{n}$. We then have $\left|\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}-\left.\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right|_{\infty}=O_{\mathrm{p}}(\nu)\right.$ by a standard result from probability theory. For any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}$ satisfying $\left|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\left.\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right|_{\infty}>\epsilon_{n} \nu\right.$, let $j_{0}=\arg \max _{j \in[r]}\left|\mathbb{E}\left\{g_{i, j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}\right|$ and $\mu_{j_{0}}=\mathbb{E}\left\{g_{i, j_{0}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}$. Define $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}=\tau b_{n} \epsilon_{n} \mathbf{e}_{j_{0}}$, where $\tau>0$ is a constant to be determined later and $\mathbf{e}_{j_{0}}$ is an $r$-dimensional vector with the $j_{0}$-th component being 1 and other components being 0 . Without loss of generality, we assume $\mu_{j_{0}}>0$. Condition 2(a) implies $\max _{i \in[n]}\left|\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|=$ $O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(b_{n} \epsilon_{n} n^{1 / \gamma}\right)=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$. Then $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}} \in \hat{\Lambda}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ w.p.a.1. Write $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}=\left(\tilde{\lambda}_{1}, \ldots, \tilde{\lambda}_{r}\right)^{\top}$. By the Taylor expansion, it holds w.p.a. 1 that

$$
\begin{aligned}
F_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \geq \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \log \left\{1+\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}-P_{\nu}\left(\left|\tilde{\lambda}_{j_{0}}\right|\right) & \geq \tilde{\lambda}_{j_{0}} \bar{g}_{j_{0}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\frac{1}{2 n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\left\{\tilde{\lambda}_{j_{0}} g_{i, j_{0}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}^{2}}{\left\{1+\bar{C} \tilde{\lambda}_{j_{0}} g_{i, j_{0}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}^{2}}-C \nu \tilde{\lambda}_{j_{0}} \\
& \geq \tilde{\lambda}_{j_{0}} \bar{g}_{j_{0}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\tilde{\lambda}_{j_{0}}^{2} \mathbb{E}_{n}\left\{g_{i, j_{0}}^{2}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}-C \nu \tilde{\lambda}_{j_{0}}
\end{aligned}
$$

for some $\bar{C} \in(0,1)$, which implies

$$
\mathbb{P}\left\{F_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \leq K b_{n}^{2} \epsilon_{n}^{2}\right\} \leq \mathbb{P}\left\{\bar{g}_{j_{0}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\mu_{j_{0}} \leq b_{n} \epsilon_{n}\left[K \tau^{-1}+\tau \mathbb{E}_{n}\left\{g_{i, j_{0}}^{2}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}\right]+C \nu-\mu_{j_{0}}\right\}+o(1)
$$

From Condition 2(a) and Jensen's inequality, there exists a universal constant $L>0$ independent of $\boldsymbol{\theta}$ such that $\mathbb{P}\left[\mathbb{E}_{n}\left\{g_{i, j_{0}}^{2}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}>L\right] \rightarrow 0$. Taking $\tau=\left(K L^{-1}\right)^{1 / 2}$, we obtain $\mathbb{P}\left\{F_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \leq K b_{n}^{2} \epsilon_{n}^{2}\right\} \leq$ $\mathbb{P}\left\{\bar{g}_{j_{0}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\mu_{j_{0}} \leq 2 b_{n} \epsilon_{n}(K L)^{1 / 2}+C \nu-\mu_{j_{0}}\right\}+o(1)$. By Condition $1, \mu_{j_{0}} \geq \Delta\left(\epsilon_{n} \nu\right) \geq K_{1} \epsilon_{n} \nu / 2$ with $K_{1}$ defined in Condition 1 for sufficiently large $n$. We select sufficiently small $K>0$. Due to $b_{n}=o(\nu)$, when $n$ is sufficiently large, $2 b_{n} \epsilon_{n}(K L)^{1 / 2}+C \nu-\mu_{j_{0}} \leq-\bar{C} \mu_{j_{0}}$ for some

$\check{C} \in(0,1)$. Hence, we have $\sqrt{n}\left\{2 b_{n} \epsilon_{n}(K L)^{1 / 2}+C \nu-\mu_{j_{0}}\right\} \leq-\check{C} \sqrt{n} \mu_{j_{0}} \rightarrow-\infty$. By the Central Limit Theorem, $\sqrt{n}\left\{\check{g}_{j_{0}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\mu_{j_{0}}\right\} \rightarrow \mathcal{N}\left(0, \sigma^{2}\right)$ in distribution for some $\sigma>0$, which implies that $\mathbb{P}\left\{F_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \leq K b_{n}^{2} \epsilon_{n}^{2}\right\} \rightarrow 0$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}$ satisfying $\left|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right|_{\infty}>\epsilon_{n} \nu$. We complete the proof of Proposition 1.

# D Proof of Theorem 1 

Recall $\check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\arg \max _{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \check{\Lambda}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta})} f_{n}(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})$ and $\mathcal{R}_{n}=\operatorname{supp}\left\{\check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}$. We first present two lemmas whose proofs are given in Sections J. 3 and J.4, respectively.

Lemma 3. Let $P_{\nu}(\cdot) \in \mathscr{P}$ be a convex function with bounded second-order derivative around 0 , where $\mathscr{P}$ is defined in (4). Under the conditions of Proposition 1 and Conditions 2(c) and 4(a), if $\ell_{n} \nu^{2}=o(1)$, it holds w.p.a. 1 that the global maximizer $\check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)=\left(\check{\lambda}_{1}, \ldots, \check{\lambda}_{r}\right)^{\top}$ for $f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)$ w.r.t $\boldsymbol{\lambda}$ satisfies: (i) $\left|\check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right)$, (ii) $\mathcal{R}_{n} \subset \mathcal{M}_{\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}}(\tilde{c})$ with $\tilde{c}$ given in Condition 4(a), and (iii) $\operatorname{sgn}\left(\check{\lambda}_{j}\right)=\operatorname{sgn}\left\{\check{g}_{j}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}$ for any $j \in \mathcal{M}_{\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}}(\tilde{c})$ with $\check{\lambda}_{j} \neq 0$.

Lemma 4. Under the conditions of Lemma 3 and Condition 4(b), it holds w.p.a. 1 that the global maximizer $\check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ for $f_{n}(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})$ w.r.t $\boldsymbol{\lambda}$ is continuously differentiable at $\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}$ and $\left[\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right]_{\mathcal{R}_{\tilde{c}},[p]}=\mathbf{0}$.

For simplicity, we write $\check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)$ as $\check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}=\left(\check{\lambda}_{1}, \ldots, \check{\lambda}_{r}\right)^{\top}$. Then we have

$$
\mathbf{0}=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\mathbf{g}_{i}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)}{1+\boldsymbol{\lambda}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)}-\check{\boldsymbol{\eta}}
$$

where $\check{\boldsymbol{\eta}}=\left(\check{\eta}_{1}, \ldots, \check{\eta}_{r}\right)^{\top}$ with $\check{\eta}_{j}=\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(\left|\check{\lambda}_{j}\right| ; \nu\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left(\check{\lambda}_{j}\right)$ for $\check{\lambda}_{j} \neq 0$ and $\check{\eta}_{j} \in\left[-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right), \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)\right]$for $\check{\lambda}_{j}=0$. By the Taylor expansion, we know that

$$
\mathbf{0}=\check{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)^{\otimes 2} \check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}}{\left\{1+C \check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}^{2}}-\check{\boldsymbol{\eta}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}=: \check{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\mathbf{A}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) \check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}-\check{\boldsymbol{\eta}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}
$$

for some $C \in(0,1)$, which implies $\check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}=\mathbf{A}^{-1}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\left\{\check{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\check{\boldsymbol{\eta}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\right\}$. Since $\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}=\arg \min _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}} f_{n}\{\check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\}$, we have $\mathbf{0}=\left.\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} f_{n}\{\check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\}\right|_{\boldsymbol{\theta}=\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}}$. Notice that $\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} f_{n}\left\{\check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\right\}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}=\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}}=\left\{\frac{\partial f_{n}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}} ; \check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)}{\partial \boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{\top}}\left[\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right]_{\mathcal{R}_{n},[p]}+\frac{\partial f_{n}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}} ; \check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)}{\partial \boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{\top}}\left[\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right]_{\mathcal{R}_{\tilde{c}},[p]}\right\}^{\top}+\frac{\partial f_{n}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}} ; \check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta}}$. By Lemma 4 and (D.1), we have $\left[\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right]_{\mathcal{R}_{\tilde{c}},[p]}=\mathbf{0}$ w.p.a. 1 and $\partial f_{n}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}} ; \check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) / \partial \boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}=\mathbf{0}$. Thus, it holds w.p.a. 1 that

$$
\mathbf{0}=\frac{\partial f_{n}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}} ; \check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta}}=\left\{\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)}{1+\check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)}\right\}^{\top} \check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}=: \mathbf{B}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)^{\top} \check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}
$$

We then obtain $\mathbf{0}=\mathbf{B}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)^{\top} \mathbf{A}^{-1}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\left\{\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\hat{\boldsymbol{\eta}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\right\}$. To derive the limiting distribution of $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}$, we need the following lemmas whose proofs are given in Sections J.5, J. 6 and J.7, respectively.

Lemma 5. Under the conditions of Lemma $3,\left\|\mathbf{A}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\widehat{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n} n^{1 / \gamma} \alpha_{n}\right)$, and $\left|\left\{\mathbf{B}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\widehat{\boldsymbol{\Gamma}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\} \mathbf{t}\right|_{2}=|\mathbf{t}|_{2} \cdot O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}\right)$ holds uniformly over $\mathbf{t} \in \mathbb{R}^{p}$.

Lemma 6. Assume that the conditions of Proposition 1 and Condition 2(c) hold. For $\mathscr{F}$ defined in Lemma 1,

$$
\sup _{\mathcal{F} \in \mathscr{F}}\left|\left\{\widehat{\boldsymbol{\Gamma}}_{\mathcal{F}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{\mathcal{F}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right\} \mathbf{t}\right|_{2}=|\mathbf{t}|_{2} \cdot\left\{O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \nu\right)+O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right)\right\}
$$

holds uniformly over $\mathbf{t} \in \mathbb{R}^{p}$.
Lemma 7. Let $\widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{F}}=\left\{\widehat{\boldsymbol{\Gamma}}_{\mathcal{F}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{F}}^{-1 / 2}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}^{\otimes 2}$ for any $\mathcal{F} \in \mathscr{F}$, where $\mathscr{F}$ is defined in Lemma 1 . Assume that the conditions of Proposition 1 and Conditions 2(c) and 3 hold. If $\ell_{n}^{2} \nu^{2} \log r=o(1)$ and $\ell_{n}^{3} \alpha_{n}^{2} \log r=o(1)$, for any $\mathbf{t} \in \mathbb{R}^{p}$ with $|\mathbf{t}|_{2}=1$, we have

$$
\sup _{\mathcal{F} \in \mathscr{F}} \sup _{u \in \mathbb{R}}\left|\mathbb{P}\left\{n^{1 / 2} \mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{F}}^{-1 / 2} \widehat{\boldsymbol{\Gamma}}_{\mathcal{F}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{F}}^{-1}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) \overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{F}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right) \leq u\right\}-\Phi(u)\right| \rightarrow 0
$$

as $n \rightarrow \infty$, where $\Phi(\cdot)$ is the cumulative distribution function of the standard Gaussian distribution.

For any $\mathbf{t} \in \mathbb{R}^{p}$ with $|\mathbf{t}|_{2}=1$, let $\boldsymbol{\delta}=\widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}$ and $\mathbf{U}=\widehat{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1 / 2}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) \widehat{\boldsymbol{\Gamma}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)$. Then $\widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}=\mathbf{U}^{\top, \otimes 2}$ and $\left|\widehat{\boldsymbol{\Gamma}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) \boldsymbol{\delta}\right|_{2}^{2} \leq \lambda_{\max }\left\{\widehat{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}\left|\mathbf{U}\left(\mathbf{U}^{\top, \otimes 2}\right)^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right|_{2}^{2}=\lambda_{\max }\left\{\widehat{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}$. By Condition 2(b) and Lemma $1,\left|\widehat{\boldsymbol{\Gamma}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) \boldsymbol{\delta}\right|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$. Under Conditions 2(b) and 3, Lemmas 1 and 6 imply $|\boldsymbol{\delta}|_{2}^{2} \leq$ $\lambda_{\max }\left\{\widehat{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\} \lambda_{\min }^{-1}\left\{\widehat{\boldsymbol{\Gamma}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)^{\top, \otimes 2}\right\}=O_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$. By Lemma 3, we have w.p.a. 1 that $\mathcal{R}_{n} \subset \mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}}(\tilde{c})$ and $\operatorname{sgn}\left(\hat{\lambda}_{j}\right)=\operatorname{sgn}\left\{\bar{g}_{j}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}$ for any $j \in \mathcal{R}_{n}$. Since $P_{\nu}(\cdot) \in \mathscr{P}$ has bounded second-order derivative around 0 , by Lemma 3 , it holds w.p.a. 1 that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}-\hat{\boldsymbol{\eta}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\right|_{2}^{2} & =\sum_{j \in \mathcal{R}_{n}}\left\{\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left(\hat{\lambda}_{j}\right)-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(\left|\hat{\lambda}_{j}\right| ; \nu\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left(\hat{\lambda}_{j}\right)\right\}^{2} \\
& =\sum_{j \in \mathcal{R}_{n}}\left\{\nu \rho^{\prime \prime}\left(c_{j}\left|\hat{\lambda}_{j}\right| ; \nu\right)\left|\hat{\lambda}_{j}\right|\right\}^{2} \leq C|\hat{\mathbf{\lambda}}|_{2}^{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

for some $c_{j} \in(0,1)$. As shown in the proof of Lemma $3,\left|\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}}(\tilde{c})\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}}(\tilde{c})\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}\right|_{2}=$ $O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right)$. Then $\left|\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\hat{\boldsymbol{\eta}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\right|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right)$. Due to $\mathbf{B}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)^{\top} \mathbf{A}^{-1}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\left\{\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\hat{\boldsymbol{\eta}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\right\}=\mathbf{0}$,

by the triangle inequality,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\boldsymbol{\delta}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{T}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\left\{\mathbf{g}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\hat{\boldsymbol{\eta}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\right\}\right| \leq & \underbrace{\left|\boldsymbol{\delta}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{T}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)^{\top}\left\{\widehat{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\mathbf{A}^{-1}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}\left\{\mathbf{g}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\hat{\boldsymbol{\eta}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\right\}\right|}_{T_{1}} \\
& +\underbrace{\left|\boldsymbol{\delta}^{\top}\left\{\widehat{\mathbf{T}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\mathbf{B}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}^{\top} \mathbf{A}^{-1}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\left\{\mathbf{g}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\hat{\boldsymbol{\eta}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\right\}\right]}_{T_{2}} .
\end{aligned}
$$

By Lemma 5,

$$
\begin{aligned}
T_{1} \leq & \left|\widehat{\mathbf{T}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) \boldsymbol{\delta}\right|_{2}\left\|\widehat{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\mathbf{A}^{-1}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\|_{2}\left|\mathbf{g}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\hat{\boldsymbol{\eta}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\right|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{3 / 2} n^{1 / \gamma} \alpha_{n}^{2}\right), \\
& T_{2} \leq\left|\left\{\widehat{\mathbf{T}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\mathbf{B}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\} \boldsymbol{\delta}\right|_{2}\left\|\mathbf{A}^{-1}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\|_{2}\left|\mathbf{g}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\hat{\boldsymbol{\eta}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\right|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{3 / 2} \alpha_{n}^{2}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, $\boldsymbol{\delta}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{T}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\left\{\mathbf{g}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\hat{\boldsymbol{\eta}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\right\}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{3 / 2} n^{1 / \gamma} \alpha_{n}^{2}\right)$. By the Taylor expansion, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\boldsymbol{\delta}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{T}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\left\{\widehat{\mathbf{T}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}})\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}-\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)-\hat{\boldsymbol{\eta}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\right\} \\
& =-\boldsymbol{\delta}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{T}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) \mathbf{g}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)+O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{3 / 2} n^{1 / \gamma} \alpha_{n}^{2}\right),
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}$ is on the line joining $\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}$ and $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}$. Write $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}=\left(\hat{\theta}_{n, 1}, \ldots, \hat{\theta}_{n, p}\right)^{\top}, \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}=\left(\theta_{0,1}, \ldots, \theta_{0, p}\right)^{\top}$ and $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}=\left(\hat{\theta}_{1}, \ldots, \hat{\theta}_{p}\right)^{\top}$. By the Taylor expansion, Jensen's inequality and Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, it holds that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\left\{\widehat{\mathbf{T}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}})-\widehat{\mathbf{T}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}-\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|_{2} ^{2} & =\sum_{j \in \mathcal{R}_{n}}\left[\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{k=1}^{p}\left(\hat{\theta}_{n, k}-\theta_{0, k}\right) \sum_{l=1}^{p} \frac{\partial^{2} g_{i, j}\left\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(j, k)}\right\}}{\partial \theta_{k} \partial \theta_{l}}\left(\hat{\theta}_{l}-\hat{\theta}_{n, l}\right)\right]^{2} \\
& \leq \frac{1}{n} \sum_{j \in \mathcal{R}_{n}} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{k=1}^{p} \sum_{l=1}^{p}\left|\frac{\partial^{2} g_{i, j}\left\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(j, k)}\right\}}{\partial \theta_{k} \partial \theta_{l}}\right|^{2} \cdot\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}-\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right|_{2 }^{4},
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{(j, k)}$ lies on the jointing line between $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}$ and $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}$. Recall $p$ is fixed. By Proposition 1, $\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}-\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}(\nu)$. Together with Condition 2(c), we have $\left|\left\{\widehat{\mathbf{T}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}})-\widehat{\mathbf{T}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}-\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|_{2}=$ $O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \nu^{2}\right)$. Recall $\hat{\boldsymbol{\psi}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}=\widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1} \widehat{\mathbf{T}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) \hat{\boldsymbol{\eta}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}$ and $\boldsymbol{\delta}=\widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}$. Then (D.2) leads to

$$
\begin{aligned}
n^{1 / 2} \mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{1 / 2}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}-\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}-\hat{\boldsymbol{\psi}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\right)= & -n^{1 / 2} \mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1 / 2} \widehat{\mathbf{T}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) \mathbf{g}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right) \\
& +O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{3 / 2} n^{1 / 2+1 / \gamma} \alpha_{n}^{2}\right)+O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \nu^{2} n^{1 / 2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

By Lemma 7, we have $n^{1 / 2} \mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{1 / 2}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}-\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}-\hat{\boldsymbol{\psi}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\right) \rightarrow \mathcal{N}(0,1)$ in distribution as $n \rightarrow \infty$.

# E Proof of Theorem 2 

Assume $\left(r, \ell_{n}, \nu\right)$ satisfy the following restrictions:

$$
\log r=o\left(n^{1 / 3}\right), \quad \ell_{n} \ll n^{(\gamma-2) /(9 \gamma)}(\log r)^{-1 / 9} \text { and } \ell_{n} n^{-1 / 2}(\log r)^{1 / 2} \ll \nu \ll \ell_{n}^{-7 / 2} n^{-1 / \gamma}
$$

To construct Theorem 2, we need the following proposition whose proof is given in Section F.

Proposition 2. Let $P_{\nu}(\cdot) \in \mathscr{P}$ be convex and assume $\rho(t ; \nu)=\nu^{-1} P_{\nu}(t)$ has bounded secondorder derivative with respect to $t$ around 0 , where $\mathscr{P}$ is defined as (4). Assume $\left(r, \ell_{n}, \nu\right)$ satisfy (E.1).
(i) Under Conditions 1-3, 4(a) and 5(a), then $\aleph_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=2^{-1}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}-\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}-\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)+\left|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right|_{2}^{2} \cdot$ $O_{p}\left(\varpi_{n}\right)$ holds uniformly over $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$ with $\varpi_{n}=\max \left\{\ell_{n}^{3 / 2} \alpha_{n}, \nu, \ell_{n} n^{1 / \gamma} \alpha_{n}\right\}$, where $\widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}$ is defined in (12) and the term $O_{p}\left(\varpi_{n}\right)$ holds uniformly over $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$.
(ii) Under Conditions 1, 2, 4(a) and 5(b), then $\inf _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{2}} \aleph_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \geq\left(8 K_{4}\right)^{-1} \kappa_{n}^{2}$ with probability approaching one, where $K_{4}$ and $\kappa_{n}$ are specified in Conditions 2(b) and 5(b), respectively.
(iii) Under Conditions 1, 2, 4(a) and 5(c), then $\inf _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{3}} \aleph_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \geq 4^{-1} K_{7}^{1 / 2} \xi_{n} \beta_{n}$ with probability approaching one for any $\xi_{n}$ satisfying $\beta_{n}^{-1} \ell_{n} \alpha_{n}^{2} \ll \xi_{n} \ll \beta_{n}$, where $K_{7}$ is specified in Condition $5(\mathrm{c})$.

Recall the posterior distribution $\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right) \propto \pi_{0}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \times \exp \left[-n \log n-n f_{n}\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\}\right] I(\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta})$. For any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}$, let $w_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=-n \log n-n f_{n}\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\}$ and write $\mathbf{t}=n^{1 / 2}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}-\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)$. Define $\mathcal{T}_{n}=\left\{\mathbf{t} \in \mathbb{R}^{p}: \mathbf{t}=n^{1 / 2}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}-\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right), \boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}\right\}$. Denote by $\pi_{0, \mathbf{t}}(\cdot)$ and $\pi_{\mathbf{t}}^{\dagger}\left(\cdot \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)$ the prior and the posterior distributions of $\mathbf{t}$, respectively. Then, $\pi_{0, \mathbf{t}}(\mathbf{t})=n^{-p / 2} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)$ and

$$
\begin{aligned}
