\pi_{\mathbf{t}}^{\dagger}\left(\mathbf{t} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right) & =\frac{\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right) \exp \left\{w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)-w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\} I\left(\mathbf{t} \in \mathcal{T}_{n}\right)}{\int_{\mathbb{R}^{p}} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{s}\right) \exp \left\{w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{s}\right)-w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\} I\left(\mathbf{s} \in \mathcal{T}_{n}\right) \mathrm{d} \mathbf{s}} \\
& =: C_{n}^{-1} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right) \exp \left\{w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)-w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\} I\left(\mathbf{t} \in \mathcal{T}_{n}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

To prove Theorem 2, it is equivalent to show

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{\mathbb{R}^{p}} \mid C_{n}^{-1} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right. & \left.+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right) \exp \left\{w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)-w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\} I\left(\mathbf{t} \in \mathcal{T}_{n}\right) \\
& \left.-(2 \pi)^{-p / 2}\left|\widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\right|^{1 / 2} \exp \left(-\mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mathbf{t} / 2\right)\right] \mathrm{d} \mathbf{t} \rightarrow 0
\end{aligned}
$$

in probability. It follows from the triangle inequality that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\mathbb{R}^{p}}\left|C_{n}^{-1} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right) \exp \left\{w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)-w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\} I\left(\mathbf{t} \in \mathcal{T}_{n}\right)\right. \\
& \left.-(2 \pi)^{-p / 2}\left|\widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\right|^{1 / 2} \exp \left(-\mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mathbf{t} / 2\right)\right] \mathrm{dt} \\
& \leq C_{n}^{-1} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{p}}\left|\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right) \exp \left\{w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)-w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\} I\left(\mathbf{t} \in \mathcal{T}_{n}\right)\right. \\
& \underbrace{-\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) \exp \left(-\mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mathbf{t} / 2\right) \mid \mathrm{dt}}_{\mathrm{I}} \\
& +C_{n}^{-1} \underbrace{\int_{\mathbb{R}^{p}}\left|\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) \exp \left(-\mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mathbf{t} / 2\right)-C_{n}(2 \pi)^{-p / 2}\left|\widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\right|^{1 / 2} \exp \left(-\mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mathbf{t} / 2\right) \mid \mathrm{dt}}_{\text {II }} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Notice that $\mathrm{I} \geq\left|C_{n}-(2 \pi)^{p / 2} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right| \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mid^{-1 / 2} \mid=\mathrm{II}$. To show (E.3), it suffices to show $C_{n}^{-1} \mathrm{I}=$ $o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$. Recall $\widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}=\left\{\widehat{\mathbf{\Gamma}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1 / 2}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}^{\otimes 2}$. Under Conditions 2(b) and 3, by Proposition 1, Lemmas 1 and 6 , if $\log r=o\left(n^{1 / 3}\right), \ell_{n} \alpha_{n}=o\left[\min \left\{\nu, n^{-1 / \gamma}\right\}\right]$ and $\ell_{n} \nu^{2}=o(1)$, we know that the eigenvalues of $\widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}$ are uniformly bounded away from zero and infinity w.p.a.1. Notice that $\widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}$ is a $p \times p$ matrix with fixed $p$. Thus, $\left|\widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\right|^{-1 / 2}$ is uniformly bounded away from zero w.p.a.1. Since $\pi_{0}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ is bounded away from zero around $\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}$ and $\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}-\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right|_{\infty}=O_{\mathrm{p}}(\nu)$, we know $\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)$ is bounded away from zero w.p.a.1. If $\mathrm{I}=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$, then $\left|C_{n}-(2 \pi)^{p / 2} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right| \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mid^{-1 / 2} \mid=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$, which implies $C_{n}^{-1}=O_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$. Hence, to show (E.3), we only need to show $\mathrm{I}=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$. Recall $\ell_{n} \ll \min \left\{n^{(\gamma-2) /(9 \gamma)}(\log r)^{-1 / 9}, n^{1 / 3}(\log r)^{-1}, n^{(\gamma-2) /(2 \gamma)}(\log r)^{-3 / 2}\right\}$ and $\ell_{n} n^{-1 / 2}(\log r)^{1 / 2} \ll \nu \ll$ $\min \left\{\ell_{n}^{-7 / 2} n^{-1 / \gamma},(\log r)^{-1}\right\}$. We break the domain of integration into four regions:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\mathcal{D}_{1}=\left\{\mathbf{t} \in \mathcal{T}_{n}:\left|\mathbf{t}\right|_{2} \leq n^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right\}, \quad \mathcal{D}_{2}=\left\{\mathbf{t} \in \mathcal{T}_{n}: n^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}<\left|\mathbf{t}\right|_{2} \leq n^{1 / 2} \beta_{n}\right\}, \\
\mathcal{D}_{3}=\left\{\mathbf{t} \in \mathcal{T}_{n}:|\mathbf{t}|_{2}>n^{1 / 2} \beta_{n}\right\}, \quad \mathcal{D}_{4}=\mathcal{T}_{n}^{c} .
\end{gathered}
$$

Then $\mathrm{I}=\mathrm{I}(1)+\mathrm{I}(2)+\mathrm{I}(3)+\mathrm{I}(4)$ with
$\mathrm{I}(k)=\int_{\mathcal{D}_{k}}\left|\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right) \exp \left\{w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)-w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\} I\left(\mathbf{t} \in \mathcal{T}_{n}\right)-\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) \exp \left(-\mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mathbf{t} / 2\right) \mid \mathrm{dt}$.
In the sequel, we will show each $\mathrm{I}(k)=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$.
For $\mathrm{I}(3)$, by the triangle inequality, we have
$\mathrm{I}(3) \leq \int_{\mathcal{D}_{3}} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right) \exp \left\{w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)-w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\} \mathrm{dt}+\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) \int_{\mathcal{D}_{3}} \exp \left(-\mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mathbf{t} / 2\right) \mathrm{dt}$.

Due to $\int_{\mathcal{D}_{3}} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right) \mathrm{dt} \leq n^{p / 2} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{p}} \pi_{0}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{\theta} \leq n^{p / 2}$, Proposition 2(iii) implies that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\mathcal{D}_{3}} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right) \exp \left\{w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)-w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\} \mathrm{dt} \\
& \quad \leq \sup _{\mathbf{t} \in \mathcal{D}_{3}} \exp \left\{w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)-w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\} \cdot \int_{\mathcal{D}_{3}} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right) \mathrm{dt} \leq n^{p / 2} \exp \left(-C n \xi_{n} \beta_{n}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

w.p.a. 1 for any $\beta_{n}^{-1} \ell_{n} \alpha_{n}^{2} \ll \xi_{n} \ll \beta_{n}$. Since $r \gg n$, we can select suitable $\xi_{n}$ satisfying $n \beta_{n} \xi_{n} \gg$ $\log n$. Then

$$
\int_{\mathcal{D}_{3}} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right) \exp \left\{w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)-w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\} \mathrm{dt}=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)
$$

Due to $n \beta_{n}^{2} \rightarrow \infty$, Proposition 1.1 of Hsu et al. (2012) implies that

$$
\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) \int_{\mathcal{D}_{3}} \exp \left(-\mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mathbf{t} / 2\right) \mathrm{dt} \leq(2 \pi)^{p / 2} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\left|\widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\right|^{-1 / 2} \exp \left(-\bar{C} n \beta_{n}^{2}\right)=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)
$$

Therefore, $\mathrm{I}(3)=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$.
For $\mathrm{I}(2)$, it holds that
$\mathrm{I}(2) \leq \int_{\mathcal{D}_{2}} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right) \exp \left\{w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)-w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\} \mathrm{dt}+\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) \int_{\mathcal{D}_{2}} \exp \left(-\mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mathbf{t} / 2\right) \mathrm{dt}$.
Since $n o_{n}^{2} \rightarrow \infty$, using the same arguments given above, we have $\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) \int_{\mathcal{D}_{2}} \exp \left(-\mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mathbf{t} / 2\right) \mathrm{dt}=$ $o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$. By Proposition 2(ii), it then holds w.p.a. 1 that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\mathcal{D}_{2}} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right) \exp \left\{w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)-w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\} \mathrm{dt} \\
& \quad \leq \sup _{\mathbf{t} \in \mathcal{D}_{2}} \exp \left\{w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)-w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\} \cdot \int_{\mathcal{D}_{2}} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right) \mathrm{dt} \leq n^{p / 2} \exp \left(-C n \kappa_{n}^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $\log n \ll n \kappa_{n}^{2}$, we have

$$
\int_{\mathcal{D}_{2}} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right) \exp \left\{w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)-w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\} \mathrm{dt}=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)
$$

Therefore, $\mathrm{I}(2)=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$.
For $\mathrm{I}(1)$, by the triangle inequality, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{I}(1) \leq & \int_{\mathcal{D}_{1}} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)\left|\exp \left\{w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)-w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\} I\left(\mathbf{t} \in \mathcal{T}_{n}\right)-\exp \left(-\mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mathbf{t} / 2\right) I\left(\mathbf{t} \in \mathcal{T}_{n}\right)\right| \mathrm{dt} \\
& +\int_{\mathcal{D}_{1}}\left|\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right) I\left(\mathbf{t} \in \mathcal{T}_{n}\right)-\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right| \exp \left(-\mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mathbf{t} / 2\right) \mathrm{dt}
\end{aligned}
$$

Due to $\mathcal{D}_{1} \subset \mathcal{T}_{n}$, by Proposition 2(i), it holds that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathrm{I}(1) \leq & \int_{\mathcal{D}_{1}} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)\left|\exp \left\{-\mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mathbf{t} / 2+|\mathbf{t}|_{2}^{2} \cdot O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\varpi_{n}\right)\right\}-\exp \left(-\mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mathbf{t} / 2\right)\right| \mathrm{dt} \\
& +\int_{\mathcal{D}_{1}}\left|\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)-\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right| \exp \left(-\mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mathbf{t} / 2\right) \mathrm{dt}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\varpi_{n}=\max \left\{\ell_{n}^{3 / 2} \alpha_{n}, \nu, \ell_{n} n^{1 / \gamma} \alpha_{n}\right\}$. By Condition 6 , we have $\sup _{\mathbf{t} \in \mathcal{D}_{1}}\left|\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)-\right.$ $\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) \mid=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$, which implies

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\mathcal{D}_{1}}\left|\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)-\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right| \exp \left(-\mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mathbf{t} / 2\right) \mathrm{dt} \\
& \quad \leq(2 \pi)^{p / 2}\left|\widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\right|^{-1 / 2} \sup _{\mathbf{t} \in \mathcal{D}_{1}}\left|\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)-\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right|=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)
\end{aligned}
$$

Due to $\varpi_{n} n \alpha_{n}^{2}=o(1)$, then $\sup _{\mathbf{t} \in \mathcal{D}_{1}}\left\{|\mathbf{t}|_{2}^{2} \cdot O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\varpi_{n}\right)\right\}=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$. Notice that $\left|e^{x}-1\right| \leq|x| e^{x}$ for any $x \in \mathbb{R}$. Then $\sup _{\mathbf{t} \in \mathcal{D}_{1}}|\exp \left\{|\mathbf{t}|_{2}^{2} \cdot O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\varpi_{n}\right)\right\}-1|=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$, which implies that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\mathcal{D}_{1}} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right) \exp \left(-\mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mathbf{t} / 2\right)\left|\exp \left\{|\mathbf{t}|_{2}^{2} \cdot O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\varpi_{n}\right)\right\}-1\right| \mathrm{dt} \\
& \quad \leq o_{\mathrm{p}}(1) \cdot \sup _{\mathbf{t} \in \mathcal{D}_{1}} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right) \int_{\mathcal{D}_{1}} \exp \left(-\mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mathbf{t} / 2\right) \mathrm{dt}=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, $\mathrm{I}(1)=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$.
For $\mathrm{I}(4)$, due to $\mathcal{D}_{4} \cap \mathcal{T}_{n}=\emptyset$, we have $\mathrm{I}(4)=\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) \int_{\mathcal{D}_{4}} \exp \left(-\mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mathbf{t} / 2\right) \mathrm{dt}$. Since $\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}$ is an interior point of $\boldsymbol{\Theta}$, there exists a constant $\iota>0$ such that $\boldsymbol{\Theta} \supset \mathcal{B}_{2}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}, \iota\right):=\left\{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathbb{R}^{p}:\left|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right|_{2} \leq\right.$ $\iota\}$, which implies $\mathcal{D}_{4}=\mathcal{T}_{n}^{c} \subset \mathcal{T}_{n}^{s, c}$ with $\mathcal{T}_{n}^{s}=\left\{\mathbf{t} \in \mathbb{R}^{p}: \mathbf{t}=n^{1 / 2}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}-\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right), \boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{B}_{2}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}, \iota\right)\right\}$. By Proposition 1, it holds w.p.a. 1 that $n^{-1 / 2}|\mathbf{t}|_{2} \geq\left|n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}+\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}-\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right|_{2}-\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}-\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right|_{2} \geq \iota / 2$ for any $\mathbf{t} \in \mathcal{D}_{4}$. Together with Proposition 1.1 of Hsu et al. (2012), we have w.p.a. 1 that

$$
\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) \int_{\mathcal{D}_{4}} \exp \left(-\mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mathbf{t} / 2\right) \mathrm{dt} \leq(2 \pi)^{p / 2} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\left|\widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\right|^{-1 / 2} \exp (-\tilde{C} n)=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)
$$

Therefore, $\mathrm{I}(4)=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$.

# F Proof of Proposition 2
## F. 1 Proof of part (i) of Proposition 2

Recall $\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\operatorname{supp}\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\}$ and $\mathcal{C}_{1}=\left\{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}:\left|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right|_{2} \leq \alpha_{n}\right\}$ with $\alpha_{n}=n^{-1 / 2}(\log r)^{1 / 2}$. To prove part (i) of Proposition 2, we need the following lemmas whose proofs are given in Sections J.8, J. 9 and J. 10 , respectively.

Lemma 8. Let $c \in(\tilde{c}, 1)$ be some constant with $\tilde{c}$ given in Condition 4(a). Under the conditions of Lemma 3, it holds w.p.a. 1 that the global maximizer $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\left\{\hat{\lambda}_{1}(\boldsymbol{\theta}), \ldots, \hat{\lambda}_{r}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}^{\top}$ for $f_{n}(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})$ w.r.t $\boldsymbol{\lambda}$ satisfies the results: (i) $\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}}|\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})|_{2}=O_{p}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right)$, (ii) $\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \subset \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(c)$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$, and (iii) $\operatorname{sgn}\left\{\hat{\lambda}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}=\operatorname{sgn}\left\{\bar{g}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$ and $j \in \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(c)$ with $\hat{\lambda}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \neq 0$.

Lemma 9. Under the conditions of Lemma 3 and Condition 5(a), it holds w.p.a. 1 that the global maximizer $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ for $f_{n}(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})$ w.r.t $\boldsymbol{\lambda}$ is continuously differentiable in $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$ with $\left[\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right]_{\mathcal{R}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{c} ; p\right]}=$ 0 and

$$
\begin{aligned}
{\left[\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right]_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ;[p]}=} & \left(\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\otimes 2}}{\left\{1+\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}^{2}}+\nu \operatorname{diag}\left[\rho^{\prime \prime}\left\{\left|\hat{\lambda}_{1}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right| ; \nu\right\}, \ldots, \rho^{\prime \prime}\left\{\left|\hat{\lambda}_{|\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})|}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right| ; \nu\right\}\right]\right)^{-1} \\
& \times\left\{\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\left[\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \mathbf{g}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right]_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; p]}}{1+\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}-\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top}\left[\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \mathbf{g}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right]_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; p]}}{\left\{1+\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}^{2}}\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\left\{\hat{\lambda}_{1}(\boldsymbol{\theta}), \ldots, \hat{\lambda}_{|\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})|}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}^{\top}$.
Lemma 10. Under the conditions of Lemma 3 and Condition 5(a), it holds that $\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=$ $\operatorname{supp}\left\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$ w.p.a.1.

Notice that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} f_{n}\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\}= & \left\{\frac{\partial f_{n}\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\}}{\partial \boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}^{\top}}\left[\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right]_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; p]}+\frac{\partial f_{n}\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\}}{\partial \boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\prime}}^{\top}}\left[\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right]_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{c} ; p]}\right\}^{\top} \\
& +\left.\frac{\partial f_{n}(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})}{\partial \boldsymbol{\theta}}\right|_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}=\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}
\end{aligned}
$$

for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$. Due to $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\arg \max _{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta})} f_{n}(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})$, then $\partial f_{n}\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\} / \partial \boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}=\mathbf{0}$. By Lemma 9 , we have $\left[\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right]_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{c}, p]}=\mathbf{0}$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$ w.p.a.1. Thus, it holds w.p.a. 1 that

$$
\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} f_{n}\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\}=\left\{\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \mathbf{g}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{1+\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}\right\}^{\top} \hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})
$$

for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$. By Lemma 9,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{2} f_{n}\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\}= & -\underbrace{\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\left\{\left[\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \mathbf{g}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right]_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; p]}^{\top} \hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}^{\otimes 2}}{\left\{1+\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}^{2}}\right.} \\
& -\underbrace{\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\left[\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \mathbf{g}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right]_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; p]}^{\top} \hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top}\left[\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right]_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; p]}}{\left\{1+\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}^{2}}}\)
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
+\underbrace{\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\sum_{j \in \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})} \hat{\lambda}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{2} g_{i, j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{1+\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}}_{T_{\boldsymbol{\theta}, 3}}+\underbrace{\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\left[\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \mathbf{g}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right]_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta}),[p]}^{\top}\left[\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right]_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta}),[p]}}_{1+\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})} \boldsymbol{T}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}, 4}
$$

for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$. Lemma 11 specifies the leading term of $\mathbf{t}^{\top}\left[\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{2} f_{n}\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\}\right] \mathbf{t}$ for $\mathbf{t} \in \mathbb{R}^{p}$, whose proof is given in Section J.11.

Lemma 11. Let $P_{\nu}(\cdot) \in \mathscr{P}$ be convex and assume $\rho(t ; \nu)=\nu^{-1} P_{\nu}(t)$ has bounded second-order derivative w.r.t $t$ around 0 , where $\mathscr{P}$ is defined in (4). Under the conditions of Lemma 3 and Conditions 3 and 5(a), then
$\mathbf{t}^{\top}\left[\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{2} f_{n}\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\}\right] \mathbf{t}=\mathbf{t}^{\top}\left\{\widehat{\mathbf{\Gamma}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}^{-1 / 2}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}^{\otimes 2} \mathbf{t}+|\mathbf{t}|_{2}^{2} \cdot\left\{O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{3 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right)+O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n} n^{1 / \gamma} \alpha_{n}\right)+O_{\mathrm{p}}(\nu)\right\}$ holds uniformly over $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$ and $\mathbf{t} \in \mathbb{R}^{p}$.

Let $\mathbf{t}=\boldsymbol{\theta}-\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$. Since $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}=\arg \min _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}} f_{n}\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\}$, then $\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} f_{n}\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\}\left.\right|_{\boldsymbol{\theta}=\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}}=$ 0 . By the Taylor expansion, it holds that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\aleph_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) & =f_{n}\left\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\right\}-f_{n}\left\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) ; \hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right\} \\
& =\left[\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} f_{n}\left\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\right\}\right]_{\boldsymbol{\theta}=\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}}\left]^{\top} \mathbf{t}+\frac{1}{2} \mathbf{t}^{\top}\left[\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{2} f_{n}\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\}\right]_{\boldsymbol{\theta}=\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}\right] \mathbf{t}=\frac{1}{2} \mathbf{t}^{\top} \nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{2} f_{n}\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}) ; \tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\} \mathbf{t}
\end{aligned}
$$

for some $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}$ lying on the jointing line between $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}$ and $\boldsymbol{\theta}$. Let $\widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}=\left\{\widehat{\mathbf{\Gamma}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}^{-1 / 2}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}^{\otimes 2}$ and recall $\widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}=\left\{\widehat{\mathbf{\Gamma}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1 / 2}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}^{\otimes 2}$. By Lemma 10, we know $\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\mathcal{R}_{n}$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$ w.p.a.1. Under Conditions 2(b) and 3, by Lemmas 1 and 6, if $\log r=o\left(n^{1 / 3}\right), \ell_{n} \nu^{2}=o(1)$ and $\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}=o\left[\min \left\{\nu, n^{-1 / \gamma}\right\}\right]$, we have $\left\|\widehat{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}(1),\left\|\widehat{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$ and $\left\|\widehat{\mathbf{T}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\|_{2}=$ $O_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$. Using the same arguments in the proof of Lemmas 1 and 6 , if $\log r=o\left(n^{1 / 3}\right), \ell_{n} \alpha_{n}=$ $o\left[\min \left\{\nu, n^{-1 / \gamma}\right\}\right]$ and $\ell_{n} \nu^{2}=o(1)$, we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}}\left\|\widehat{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\widehat{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right), \\
\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}}\left|\left\{\widehat{\mathbf{T}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\widehat{\mathbf{T}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\} \mathbf{t}\right|_{2}=|\mathbf{t}|_{2} \cdot O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right),
\end{gathered}
$$

which implies $\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}}\left\|\widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}-\widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\right\|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right)$. Together with Lemma 11, (F.2) yields that $\aleph_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-2^{-1}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}-\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}-\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)=\left|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right|_{2}^{2} \cdot O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\varpi_{n}\right)$ with $\varpi_{n}=\max \left\{\ell_{n}^{3 / 2} \alpha_{n}, \nu, \ell_{n} n^{1 / \gamma} \alpha_{n}\right\}$, where $O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\varpi_{n}\right)$ holds uniformly over $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$.

# F. 2 Proof of part (ii) of Proposition 2 

Recall $\mathcal{R}_{n}=\operatorname{supp}\left\{\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n})\right\}$ and $\mathcal{C}_{2}=\left\{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}: \alpha_{n}<\left|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right|_{2} \leq \beta_{n}\right\}$. Select $\delta_{n}$ satisfying $\delta_{n}=o\left(\ell_{n}^{-1 / 2} n^{-1 / \gamma}\right)$ and $\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \beta_{n}=o\left(\delta_{n}\right)$, which can be guaranteed by $\ell_{n} \beta_{n}=o\left(n^{-1 / \gamma}\right)$. For any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{2}$, let $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\arg \max _{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \tilde{\Lambda}} f_{n}(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})$ and $\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\operatorname{supp}\{\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\}$, where $\tilde{\Lambda}=\left\{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \mathbb{R}^{r}:\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\right|_{2} \leq\right.$ $\left.\delta_{n}, \boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}^{\prime}}=\mathbf{0}\right\}$. Write $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\left\{\tilde{\lambda}_{1}(\boldsymbol{\theta}), \ldots, \tilde{\lambda}_{\nu}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}^{\top}$. By the Taylor expansion, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
0=f_{n}(\mathbf{0} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}) & \leq f_{n}\{\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\} \\
& =\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\frac{1}{2 n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\otimes 2} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{\left\{1+C \tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}^{2}}-\sum_{j \in \tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})} P_{\nu}\left\{\left|\tilde{\lambda}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|\right\} \\
& =: \tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\frac{1}{2} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\sum_{j \in \tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})} P_{\nu}\left\{\left|\tilde{\lambda}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

for some $C \in(0,1)$. By Lemma 3, we have $|\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})| \leq\left|\mathcal{R}_{n}\right| \leq \ell_{n}$ w.p.a.1. Notice that $\nu=o\left(\beta_{n}\right)$. By Proposition 1, Lemma 1 and Condition 2(b), if $\log r=o\left(n^{1 / 3}\right), \ell_{n} \alpha_{n}=o\left[\min \left\{\nu, n^{-1 / \gamma}\right\}\right]$ and $\ell_{n} \beta_{n}=o\left(n^{-1 / \gamma}\right)$, we have $\inf _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{2}} \lambda_{\min }\{\tilde{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\} \geq K_{3} / 2$ w.p.a.1, where $K_{3}$ is specified in Condition 2(b). Recall $\rho(t ; \nu)$ is convex w.r.t $t$. Thus

$$
0 \leq \tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top}\left[\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}\right]-4^{-1} K_{3}\left|\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|_{2}^{2}
$$

w.p.a.1. Then $\left|\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|_{2} \leq 4 K_{3}^{-1}\left|\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}\right|_{2}$ w.p.a.1. By the Taylor expansion and Condition 2(c), $\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{2}}\left|\overline{\mathbf{g}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\overline{\mathbf{g}}\left(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right|_{\infty}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\beta_{n}\right)$. Together with the fact $|\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})| \leq$ $\ell_{n}$ w.p.a.1, we have $\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{2}}\left|\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}\left(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \beta_{n}\right)$. By the triangle inequality, Lemma 3 and (J.8), since $\alpha_{n}=o(\nu)$, it holds that $\left|\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}\left(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \nu\right)$. Due to $\nu=o\left(\beta_{n}\right)$, we then have

$$
\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{2}}\left|\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}\right|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \beta_{n}\right)
$$

which implies $\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{2}}\left|\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \beta_{n}\right)=o_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\delta_{n}\right)$. Recall $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\arg \max _{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \tilde{\Lambda}} f_{n}(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})$ and $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \in \operatorname{int}(\tilde{\Lambda})$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{2}$ w.p.a.1. Write $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\left\{\dot{\lambda}_{1}(\boldsymbol{\theta}), \ldots, \dot{\lambda}_{\left|\mathcal{R}_{n}\right|}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}^{\top}$. Restricted on $\tilde{\Lambda}$, by the first-order condition, we have

$$
\mathbf{0}=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{1+\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}-\tilde{\boldsymbol{\eta}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})
$$

holds for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{2}$ w.p.a.1, where $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\eta}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\left\{\tilde{\eta}_{1}(\boldsymbol{\theta}), \ldots, \tilde{\eta}_{\left[\mathcal{R}_{n}\right]}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}^{\top}$ with $\tilde{\eta}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\nu \rho^{\prime}\left\{\left|\hat{\lambda}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right| ; \nu\right\} \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\hat{\lambda}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}$ for $\hat{\lambda}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \neq 0$ and $\tilde{\eta}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \in\left[-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right), \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)\right]$for $\hat{\lambda}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=0$. By the Taylor expansion, we have

$$
\mathbf{0}=\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\mathbf{g}_{i, \tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\otimes 2} \tilde{\mathbf{A}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{\left\{1+\tilde{C} \tilde{\mathbf{A}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\wedge} \mathbf{g}_{i, \tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}^{2}}-\tilde{\boldsymbol{\eta}}_{*}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=: \tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\hat{\mathbf{A}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \tilde{\mathbf{A}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\tilde{\boldsymbol{\eta}}_{*}(\boldsymbol{\theta})
$$

for some $\tilde{C} \in(0,1)$, where $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\eta}}_{*}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \in \mathbb{R}^{|\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})|}$ includes all elements $\tilde{\eta}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ 's in $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\eta}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ such that the associated $\hat{\lambda}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \neq 0$. Hence, $\tilde{\mathbf{A}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\hat{\mathbf{A}}^{-1}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\left\{\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\tilde{\boldsymbol{\eta}}_{*}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}$. Using the same arguments in the proof of Lemma 5, we have $\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{2}}\|\hat{\mathbf{A}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\tilde{\mathbf{V}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n} \beta_{n} n^{1 / \gamma}\right)=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$. Applying Proposition 1, Lemma 1 and Condition 2(b), we know $\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{2}} \lambda_{\max }\{\hat{\mathbf{A}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\} \leq 2 K_{4}$ w.p.a. 1 for $K_{4}$ specified in Condition 2(b). For $\hat{\mathbf{A}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ specified in (F.3), we can show $\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{2}}\|\hat{\mathbf{A}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\hat{\mathbf{A}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\|_{2}=$ $O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n} \beta_{n} n^{1 / \gamma}\right)$. By (F.3) and Condition 5(b), we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
f_{n}\{\hat{\mathbf{A}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\}= & \frac{1}{2}\left[\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\tilde{\mathbf{A}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}\right]^{\top} \hat{\mathbf{A}}^{-1}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\left[\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\tilde{\mathbf{A}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}\right] \\
& +O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{2} \beta_{n}^{3} n^{1 / \gamma}\right) \\
\geq & \left.\frac{1}{4 K_{4}}\left|\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\tilde{\mathbf{A}}_{\tilde{\mathcal{R}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}\right|_{2} ^{2}+O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{2} \beta_{n}^{3} n^{1 / \gamma}\right) \geq \frac{\kappa_{n}^{2}}{4 K_{4}}+O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{2} \beta_{n}^{3} n^{1 / \gamma}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

holds uniformly over $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{2}$ w.p.a.1, where the term $O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{2} \beta_{n}^{3} n^{1 / \gamma}\right)$ holds uniformly over $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in$ $\mathcal{C}_{2}$. As we have shown in the proof of Proposition 1, $f_{n}\left\{\hat{\mathbf{A}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) ; \hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right\}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}^{2}\right)$. Notice that $f_{n}\{\hat{\mathbf{A}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\} \geq f_{n}\{\tilde{\mathbf{A}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\}$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{2}$. If $\max \left\{\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}^{2}, \ell_{n}^{2} \beta_{n}^{3} n^{1 / \gamma}\right\}=o\left(\kappa_{n}^{2}\right)$, then

$$
\mathbb{P}\left\{\inf _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{2}} \mathbb{R}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \geq \frac{\kappa_{n}^{2}}{8 K_{4}}\right\} \geq \mathbb{P}\left\{\frac{\kappa_{n}^{2}}{4 K_{4}}+O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{2} \beta_{n}^{3} n^{1 / \gamma}\right)-O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}^{2}\right) \geq \frac{\kappa_{n}^{2}}{8 K_{4}}\right\}-o(1) \rightarrow 1
$$

as $n \rightarrow \infty$. We complete the proof of part (ii) of Proposition 2.

# F. 3 Proof of part (iii) of Proposition 2 

Recall $\mathcal{R}_{n}=\operatorname{supp}\left\{\hat{\mathbf{A}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}$ and $\mathcal{C}_{3}=\left\{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}:\left|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right|_{2}>\beta_{n}\right\}$. For any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{3}$, we consider $\hat{\mathbf{A}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\left\{\hat{\lambda}_{1}(\boldsymbol{\theta}), \ldots, \hat{\lambda}_{r}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}^{\top} \in \mathbb{R}^{r}$ with $\hat{\mathbf{A}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}^{\prime}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\mathbf{0}$ and

$$
\hat{\mathbf{A}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\frac{\xi_{n}\left\{\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}}{\left|\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right|_{2}}
$$

Due to $\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \xi_{n}=o\left(n^{-1 / \gamma}\right)$, Condition 2(a) yields $\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{3}} \max _{i \in[n]}\left|\hat{\mathbf{A}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\wedge} \mathbf{g}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$, which implies the event $\bigcap_{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{3}}\left\{\hat{\mathbf{A}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \in \hat{\lambda}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}$ holds w.p.a.1. Then

$$
\mathbb{P}\left[\inf _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{3}} f_{n}\{\hat{\mathbf{A}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\} \geq \inf _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{3}} f_{n}\{\hat{\mathbf{A}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\}\right]=1-o(1)
$$

Recall $\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{3}} \lambda_{\max }\left\{\widehat{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\} \leq K_{8}$ w.p.a. 1 for $K_{8}$ specified in Condition 5(c). By the Taylor expansion, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
f_{n}\{\check{\mathbf{A}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\}= & \check{\mathbf{A}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\frac{1}{2 n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\check{\mathbf{A}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\otimes 2} \check{\mathbf{A}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{\left\{1+\check{C} \check{\mathbf{A}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}^{2}} \\
& -\sum_{j \in \mathcal{R}_{n}} P_{\nu}\left\{\left|\check{\lambda}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|\right\} \\
\geq & \check{\mathbf{A}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top}\left[\mathbf{g}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\check{\mathbf{A}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}\right]-\frac{K_{8} \xi_{n}^{2}}{2}\left\{1+o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)\right\} \\
& -\frac{1}{2} \sum_{j \in \mathcal{R}_{n}} \nu \rho^{\prime \prime}\left\{c_{j}\left|\check{\lambda}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right| ; \nu\right\}\left|\check{\lambda}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|^{2} \\
\geq & \xi_{n}\left|\mathbf{g}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\mathbf{g}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right|_{2}+\check{\mathbf{A}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top}\left[\mathbf{g}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\check{\mathbf{A}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}\right] \\
& -C \xi_{n}^{2}\left\{1+o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

holds uniformly over $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{3}$ w.p.a.1, where $\check{C}, c_{j} \in(0,1)$. By Condition 5(c), we have $\inf _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{3}}\left|\mathbf{g}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right.$ $\left.\mathbf{g}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right|_{2}=\inf _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{3}}\left|\left\{\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \mathbf{g}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}(\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}})\right\}^{\top}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}-\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right|_{2} \geq K_{7}^{1 / 2} \beta_{n}$ w.p.a.1. Since $\alpha_{n}=o(\nu)$, by Lemma 3 and (J.8), we have $\left|\mathbf{g}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \nu\right)$. Due to $\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \nu=o\left(\beta_{n}\right)$ and $\xi_{n}=o\left(\beta_{n}\right)$, it holds that

$$
\inf _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{3}} f_{n}\{\check{\mathbf{A}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\} \geq K_{7}^{1 / 2} \xi_{n} \beta_{n}+O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\xi_{n} \ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \nu\right)+O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\xi_{n}^{2}\right) \geq \frac{1}{2} K_{7}^{1 / 2} \xi_{n} \beta_{n}
$$

w.p.a.1. Since $f_{n}\left\{\check{\mathbf{A}}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) ; \check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right\}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}^{2}\right)=o_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\xi_{n} \beta_{n}\right)$, then

$$
\mathbb{P}\left\{\inf _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{3}} \mathbb{R}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \geq \frac{K_{7}^{1 / 2} \xi_{n} \beta_{n}}{4}\right\} \geq \mathbb{P}\left[\inf _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{3}} f_{n}\{\check{\mathbf{A}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\}-f_{n}\left\{\check{\mathbf{A}}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) ; \check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right\} \geq \frac{K_{7}^{1 / 2} \xi_{n} \beta_{n}}{4}\right]-o(1) \rightarrow 1
$$

as $n \rightarrow \infty$. We complete the proof of part (iii) of Proposition 2.

# G Proof of Corollary 1 

Let $\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{t} \sim \pi_{\mathbf{t}}^{1}}(\mathbf{t})=\int_{\mathbb{R}^{p}} \mathbf{t} \pi_{\mathbf{t}}^{1}\left(\mathbf{t} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right) \mathrm{d} \mathbf{t}$ for $\pi_{\mathbf{t}}^{1}\left(\mathbf{t} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)$ given in (E.2). Notice that $\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{t} \sim \pi_{\mathbf{t}}^{1}}(\mathbf{t})=n^{1 / 2}\left\{\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\theta} \sim \pi^{1}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\right.$ $\left.\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right\}$ and $\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{t} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(\mathbf{0}, \check{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1}\right)}(\mathbf{t})=\mathbf{0}$. To prove Corollary 1, it is equivalent to show $\left|\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{t} \sim \pi_{\mathbf{t}}^{1}}(\mathbf{t})-\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{t} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(\mathbf{0}, \check{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1}\right.}(\mathbf{t})\right|_{\infty}=$ $o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$. It follows from the triangle inequality that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{t} \sim \pi_{\mathbf{t}}^{1}}(\mathbf{t})-\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{t} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(\mathbf{0}, \check{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1}\right.}(\mathbf{t})\right|_{\infty} \\
& \quad \leq \int_{\mathbb{R}^{p}}|\mathbf{t}|_{\infty}\left|C_{n}^{-1} \pi_{0}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right) \exp \left\{w_{n}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)-w_{n}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\} I\left(\mathbf{t} \in \mathcal{T}_{n}\right)\right. \\
& \left.\quad-(2 \pi)^{-p / 2}\left|\check{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\right|^{1 / 2} \exp \left(-\mathbf{t}^{\top} \check{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mathbf{t} / 2\right)\right| \mathrm{d} \mathbf{t} \\
& \quad \leq C_{n}^{-1} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{p}}|\mathbf{t}|_{\infty}\left|\pi_{0}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right) \exp \left\{w_{n}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)-w_{n}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\} I\left(\mathbf{t} \in \mathcal{T}_{n}\right)\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

As shown in Section E, we have $C_{n}^{-1}=O_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$. It suffices to show $\operatorname{III}=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$ and IV $=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$. Notice that

$$
\text { IV }=\left|(2 \pi)^{p / 2} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right| \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mid^{-1 / 2}-C_{n} \mid \cdot \mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{t} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(\mathbf{0}, \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1}\right)}\left(\left|\mathbf{t}\right|_{\infty}\right)
$$

Recall $\widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}=\left\{\widehat{\mathbf{T}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1 / 2}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}^{\otimes 2}$. Under Conditions 2(b) and 3, by Proposition 1, Lemmas 1 and 6 , if $\log r=o\left(n^{1 / 3}\right), \ell_{n} \alpha_{n}=o\left[\min \left\{\nu, n^{-1 / \gamma}\right\}\right]$ and $\ell_{n} \nu^{2}=o(1)$, we know that the eigenvalues of $\widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}$ are uniformly bounded away from zero and infinity w.p.a.1. Since $\widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}$ is a $p \times p$ matrix with fixed $p$, then

$$
\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{t} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(\mathbf{0}, \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1}\right)}\left(\left|\mathbf{t}\right|_{\infty}\right) \leq \mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{t} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(\mathbf{0}, \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1}\right)}\left(\left|\mathbf{t}\right|_{1}\right)=O_{\mathrm{p}}(1)
$$

As shown in the proof of Theorem 2, we have $\left|C_{n}-(2 \pi)^{p / 2} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right| \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mid^{-1 / 2} \mid \leq \mathrm{I}=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$ for I defined in (E.4), which implies IV $\leq \mathrm{I} \cdot \mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{t} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(\mathbf{0}, \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1}\right)}\left(\left|\mathbf{t}\right|_{\infty}\right)=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$. In the sequel, we will show that III $=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$. Recall $\ell_{n} \ll \min \left\{n^{(\gamma-2) /(9 \gamma)}(\log r)^{-1 / 9}, n^{1 / 3}(\log r)^{-1}, n^{(\gamma-2) /(2 \gamma)}(\log r)^{-3 / 2}\right\}$ and $\ell_{n} n^{-1 / 2}(\log r)^{1 / 2} \ll \nu \ll \min \left\{\ell_{n}^{-7 / 2} n^{-1 / \gamma},(\log r)^{-1}\right\}$. For $\left(\mathcal{D}_{1}, \mathcal{D}_{2}, \mathcal{D}_{3}, \mathcal{D}_{4}\right)$ defined as (E.5), it holds that III $=\operatorname{III}(1)+\operatorname{III}(2)+\operatorname{III}(3)+\operatorname{III}(4)$ with

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{III}(k)=\int_{\mathcal{D}_{k}}\left|\mathbf{t}\right|_{\infty} \mid \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right) \exp \left\{w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)-w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\} I\left(\mathbf{t} \in \mathcal{T}_{n}\right) \\
& \quad-\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) \exp \left(-\mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mathbf{t} / 2\right) \mid \mathrm{dt}
\end{aligned}
$$

For III(3), by the triangle inequality, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{III}(3) \leq \int_{\mathcal{D}_{3}}\left|\mathbf{t}\right|_{\infty} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right) \exp \left\{w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)-w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\} \mathrm{dt} \\
& \quad+\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) \int_{\mathcal{D}_{3}}\left|\mathbf{t}\right|_{\infty} \exp \left(-\mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mathbf{t} / 2\right) \mathrm{dt}
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $\boldsymbol{\Theta} \subset \mathbb{R}^{p}$ is a compact set, then

$$
\int_{\mathcal{D}_{3}}\left|\mathbf{t}\right|_{\infty} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right) \mathrm{dt} \leq \check{C} n^{(p+1) / 2} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{p}} \pi_{0}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{\theta} \leq \check{C} n^{(p+1) / 2}
$$

By Proposition 2(iii),

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\mathcal{D}_{3}}|\mathbf{t}|_{\infty} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right) \exp \left\{w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)-w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\} \mathrm{dt} \\
& \quad \leq \sup _{\mathbf{t} \in \mathcal{D}_{3}} \exp \left\{w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)-w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\} \cdot \int_{\mathcal{D}_{3}}|\mathbf{t}|_{\infty} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right) \mathrm{dt} \\
& \quad \leq \bar{C} n^{(p+1) / 2} \exp \left(-C n \xi_{n} \beta_{n}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

w.p.a. 1 for any $\beta_{n}^{-1} \ell_{n} \alpha_{n}^{2} \ll \xi_{n} \ll \beta_{n}$. Since $r \gg n$, we can select suitable $\xi_{n}$ satisfying $n \beta_{n} \xi_{n} \gg$ $\log n$. Then

$$
\int_{\mathcal{D}_{3}}|\mathbf{t}|_{\infty} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right) \exp \left\{w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)-w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\} \mathrm{dt}=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)
$$

Recall that the eigenvalues of $\widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}$ are uniformly bounded away from zero and infinity w.p.a.1. Since $n \beta_{n}^{2} \rightarrow \infty$ and $p$ is fixed, by the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality and Proposition 1.1 of Hsu et al. (2012), we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{t} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(\mathbf{0}, \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1}\right)}\left\{|\mathbf{t}|_{\infty} I\left(\mathbf{t} \in \mathcal{D}_{3}\right)\right\} & \leq \mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{t} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(\mathbf{0}, \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1}\right)}^{-1}\left(|\mathbf{t}|_{\infty}^{2}\right) \mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{t} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(\mathbf{0}, \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1}\right)}^{-1}\left\{I^{2}\left(\mathbf{t} \in \mathcal{D}_{3}\right)\right\} \\
& \leq \mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{t} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(\mathbf{0}, \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1}\right)}^{-1}\left(|\mathbf{t}|_{2}^{2}\right) \exp \left(-\bar{C} n \beta_{n}^{2}\right)=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)
\end{aligned}
$$

which implies

$$
\begin{aligned}
\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) \int_{\mathcal{D}_{3}}|\mathbf{t}|_{\infty} \exp \left(-\mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mathbf{t} / 2\right) \mathrm{dt} & =(2 \pi)^{p / 2} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\left|\widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\right|^{-1 / 2} \mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{t} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(\mathbf{0}, \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1}\right)}\left\{|\mathbf{t}|_{\infty} I\left(\mathbf{t} \in \mathcal{D}_{3}\right)\right\} \\
& =o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, $\operatorname{III}(3)=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$.
For III(2), it holds that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{III}(2) \leq & \int_{\mathcal{D}_{2}}|\mathbf{t}|_{\infty} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right) \exp \left\{w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)-w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\} \mathrm{dt} \\
& +\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) \int_{\mathcal{D}_{2}}|\mathbf{t}|_{\infty} \exp \left(-\mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mathbf{t} / 2\right) \mathrm{dt}
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $n \alpha_{n}^{2} \rightarrow \infty$, using the same arguments for (G.2), we have

$$
\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) \int_{\mathcal{D}_{2}}|\mathbf{t}|_{\infty} \exp \left(-\mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mathbf{t} / 2\right) \mathrm{dt}=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)
$$

Due to $\log n \ll n \kappa_{n}^{2}$, by Proposition 2(ii), it then holds w.p.a. 1 that

$$
\int_{\mathcal{D}_{2}}|\mathbf{t}|_{\infty} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right) \exp \left\{w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)-w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\} \mathrm{dt}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \leq \sup _{\mathbf{t} \in \mathcal{D}_{2}} \exp \left\{w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)-w_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\} \cdot \int_{\mathcal{D}_{2}}|\mathbf{t}|_{\infty} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right) \mathrm{dt} \\
& \leq \tilde{C} n^{(p+1) / 2} \exp \left(-C n \kappa_{n}^{2}\right)=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, $\operatorname{III}(2)=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$.
For III(1), by Proposition 2(i), we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{III}(1) \leq & \int_{\mathcal{D}_{1}}|\mathbf{t}|_{\infty} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)\left|\exp \left\{-\mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mathbf{t} / 2+|\mathbf{t}|_{2}^{2} \cdot O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\varpi_{n}\right)\right\}-\exp \left(-\mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mathbf{t} / 2\right)\right| \mathrm{dt} \\
& +\int_{\mathcal{D}_{1}}|\mathbf{t}|_{\infty}\left|\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)-\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right| \exp \left(-\mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mathbf{t} / 2\right) \mathrm{dt}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\varpi_{n}=\max \left\{\ell_{n}^{3 / 2} \alpha_{n}, \nu, \ell_{n} n^{1 / \gamma} \alpha_{n}\right\}$. Under Condition 6 , we know $\sup _{\mathbf{t} \in \mathcal{D}_{1}}\left|\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)-\right.$ $\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) \mid=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$. By (G.1), we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\mathcal{D}_{1}}|\mathbf{t}|_{\infty}\left|\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)-\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right| \exp \left(-\mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mathbf{t} / 2\right) \mathrm{dt} \\
& \quad \leq \sup _{\mathbf{t} \in \mathcal{D}_{1}}\left|\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right)-\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right| \cdot(2 \pi)^{p / 2}\left|\widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\right|^{-1 / 2} \mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{t} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(\mathbf{0}, \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1}\right)}\left(|\mathbf{t}|_{\infty}\right)=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)
\end{aligned}
$$

Due to $\varpi_{n} n \alpha_{n}^{2}=o(1)$, then $\sup _{\mathbf{t} \in \mathcal{D}_{1}}\left\{|\mathbf{t}|_{2}^{2} \cdot O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\varpi_{n}\right)\right\}=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$. Notice that $\left|e^{x}-1\right| \leq|x| e^{x}$ for any $x \in \mathbb{R}$. Then $\sup _{\mathbf{t} \in \mathcal{D}_{1}}|\exp \left\{|\mathbf{t}|_{2}^{2} \cdot O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\varpi_{n}\right)\right\}-1 \mid=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$, which implies that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\mathcal{D}_{1}}|\mathbf{t}|_{\infty} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right) \exp \left(-\mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mathbf{t} / 2\right) \mid \exp \left\{|\mathbf{t}|_{2}^{2} \cdot O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\varpi_{n}\right)\right\}-1 \mid \mathrm{dt} \\
& \quad \leq o_{\mathrm{p}}(1) \cdot \sup _{\mathbf{t} \in \mathcal{D}_{1}} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}+n^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right) \int_{\mathcal{D}_{1}}|\mathbf{t}|_{\infty} \exp \left(-\mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mathbf{t} / 2\right) \mathrm{dt}=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, $\operatorname{III}(1)=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$.
For III(4), due to $\mathcal{D}_{4} \cap \mathcal{T}_{n}=\emptyset$, we have $\operatorname{III}(4)=\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) \int_{\mathcal{D}_{4}}|\mathbf{t}|_{\infty} \exp \left(-\mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mathbf{t} / 2\right) \mathrm{dt}$. As shown in Section E, it holds w.p.a. 1 that $n^{-1 / 2}|\mathbf{t}|_{2} \geq \iota / 2$ for any $\mathbf{t} \in \mathcal{D}_{4}$. Using the same arguments for (G.2), we have $\mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{t} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(\mathbf{0}, \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1}\right)}\left\{|\mathbf{t}|_{\infty} I\left(\mathbf{t} \in \mathcal{D}_{4}\right)\right\}=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$, which implies

$$
\begin{aligned}
\pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) \int_{\mathcal{D}_{4}}|\mathbf{t}|_{\infty} \exp \left(-\mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}} \mathbf{t} / 2\right) \mathrm{dt} & =(2 \pi)^{p / 2} \pi_{0}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\left|\widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\right|^{-1 / 2} \mathbb{E}_{\mathbf{t} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(\mathbf{0}, \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}^{-1}\right)}\left\{|\mathbf{t}|_{\infty} I\left(\mathbf{t} \in \mathcal{D}_{4}\right)\right\} \\
& =o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, $\operatorname{III}(4)=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$.

# H Proof of Theorem 3 

To prove Theorem 3, we first introduce the following two concepts.

Definition 1 (П-irreducibility). For a distribution $\Pi$ on $\mathcal{D}$, a Markov chain is called $\Pi$-irreducible if for each $A \in \mathscr{B}(\mathcal{D})$ with $\Pi(A)>0$ and $\mathbf{x} \in \mathcal{D}$, there exists $k \in \mathbb{N}$ such that $\Psi^{k}(\mathbf{x}, A)>0$, where $\mathscr{B}(\mathcal{D})$ is the Borel $\sigma$-algebra on $\mathcal{D}$, and $\Psi^{k}$ is the $k$-step transition probability defined recursively as $\Psi^{k}(\mathbf{x}, \mathrm{d} \mathbf{y})=\int_{\mathbf{z} \in \mathcal{D}} \Psi^{k-1}(\mathbf{x}, \mathrm{d} \mathbf{z}) \Psi(\mathbf{z}, \mathrm{d} \mathbf{y})$.

Definition 2 (Aperiodic). A Markov chain with stationary distribution $\Pi$ on $\mathcal{D}$ and transition probability $\Psi(\cdot, \cdot)$ is aperiodic if there do not exist $T \geq 2$ and disjoint subsets $\mathcal{D}_{1}, \ldots, \mathcal{D}_{T} \subset \mathcal{D}$ with each $\Pi\left(\mathcal{D}_{i}\right)>0$ such that (i) $\Psi\left(\mathbf{x}, \mathcal{D}_{i+1}\right)=1$ for all $\mathbf{x} \in \mathcal{D}_{i}$ and $i=1, \ldots, T-1$, and (ii) $\Psi\left(\mathbf{x}, \mathcal{D}_{1}\right)=1$ for all $\mathbf{x} \in \mathcal{D}_{T}$.

Denote by $\Psi(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \cdot)$ the transition probability of the Markov chain determined by Algorithm 1 at $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}$. For given $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}, \alpha_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})=\min \left\{1, R_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})\right\}$ is the acceptance probability at $\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \in \mathbb{R}^{p}$, where

$$
R_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})= \begin{cases}\frac{\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right) \phi(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \boldsymbol{\vartheta})}{\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right) \phi(\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \mid \boldsymbol{\theta})}, & \text { if } \boldsymbol{\vartheta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta} \text { with } \pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right) \phi(\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \mid \boldsymbol{\theta}) \neq 0 \\ 1, & \text { if } \boldsymbol{\vartheta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta} \text { with } \pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right) \phi(\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \mid \boldsymbol{\theta})=0 \\ 0, & \text { if } \boldsymbol{\vartheta} \notin \boldsymbol{\Theta}\end{cases}
$$

Then the transition probability of the associated Markov chain at $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}$ has a probability mass $\psi_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}=1-\int_{\boldsymbol{\Theta}} \phi(\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \mid \boldsymbol{\theta}) \alpha_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}) \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{\vartheta}$. Define $\psi(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})=\phi(\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \mid \boldsymbol{\theta}) \alpha_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})$ for any $\boldsymbol{\vartheta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}$. We have $\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right) \psi(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})=\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right) \psi(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})$ for any $\boldsymbol{\vartheta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}$. Since the Markov chain determined by Algorithm 1 always stays in $\boldsymbol{\Theta}$, its transition probability $\Psi(\cdot, \cdot): \boldsymbol{\Theta} \times \mathscr{B}(\boldsymbol{\Theta}) \mapsto \mathbb{R}_{+}$satisfies $\Psi(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{\vartheta})=\psi_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \delta_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{\vartheta})+\psi(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta}) \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{\vartheta}$, where $\mathscr{B}(\boldsymbol{\Theta})$ is the Borel $\sigma$-algebra on $\boldsymbol{\Theta}$, and $\delta_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}$ is the Dirac-delta function at $\boldsymbol{\theta}$ with $\delta_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(A)=I(\boldsymbol{\theta} \in A)$. For any $A, B \in \mathscr{B}(\boldsymbol{\Theta})$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{A} \pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right) \Psi(\boldsymbol{\theta}, B) \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{\theta} & =\int_{A \cap B} \pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right) \psi_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{\theta}+\int_{(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta}) \in A \times B} \pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right) \psi(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta}) \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{\theta} \mathrm{~d} \boldsymbol{\vartheta} \\
& =\int_{B} \pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right) \psi_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \delta_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(A) \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{\theta}+\int_{(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta}) \in A \times B} \pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right) \psi(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta}) \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{\theta} \mathrm{~d} \boldsymbol{\vartheta} \\
& =\int_{B} \pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right) \Psi(\boldsymbol{\theta}, A) \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{\theta}
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, $\Pi_{n}^{\dagger}(A)=\int_{A} \pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right) \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{\theta}=\int_{A} \pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right) \Psi(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\Theta}) \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{\theta}=\int_{\boldsymbol{\Theta}} \pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right) \Psi(\boldsymbol{\theta}, A) \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{\theta}$ for any $A \in \mathscr{B}(\boldsymbol{\Theta})$, which implies that $\Pi_{n}^{\dagger}$ is the stationary distribution of such Markov chain with transition probability $\Psi(\cdot, \cdot)$.

Denote by $\mathbb{L}(\cdot)$ the Lebesgue measure on $\mathbb{R}^{p}$. For any $A \in \mathscr{B}(\boldsymbol{\Theta})$ with $\Pi_{n}^{\dagger}(A)>0$, due to $\Pi_{n}^{\dagger}(A)=\int_{A} \pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right) \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{\theta}$, we know $\mathbb{L}(A)>0$. Recall that $\boldsymbol{\Theta} \subset \mathbb{R}^{p}$ is a compact set. Since $\phi(\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \mid \boldsymbol{\theta})$ is positive and continuous on $(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta}) \in \boldsymbol{\Theta} \times \boldsymbol{\Theta}$, there exists a constant $C>0$ such that $\inf _{\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}} \phi(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \boldsymbol{\vartheta})>C$. On one hand, for any $A \in \mathscr{B}(\boldsymbol{\Theta})$ and $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}$ such that $\Pi_{n}^{\dagger}(A)>0$ and $\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)=0$, we have $\Psi(\boldsymbol{\theta}, A) \geq \int_{A} \psi(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta}) \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{\vartheta}=\int_{A} \phi(\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \mid \boldsymbol{\theta}) \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{\vartheta}>0$. On the other hand, for any $A \in \mathscr{B}(\boldsymbol{\Theta})$ and $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}$ such that $\Pi_{n}^{\dagger}(A)>0$ and $\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)>0$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Psi(\boldsymbol{\theta}, A)= & \psi_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \delta_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(A)+\int_{A} \psi(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta}) \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{\vartheta} \geq \int_{A} \phi(\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \mid \boldsymbol{\theta}) \min \left\{1, \frac{\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right) \phi(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \boldsymbol{\vartheta})}{\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right) \phi(\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \mid \boldsymbol{\theta})}\right\} \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{\vartheta} \\
= & \int_{\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \in A: \pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right) \geq \pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)} \min \left\{\phi(\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \mid \boldsymbol{\theta}), \frac{\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)}{\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)} \phi(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \boldsymbol{\vartheta})\right\} \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{\vartheta} \\
& +\int_{\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \in A: \pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)<\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)} \frac{1}{\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)} \min \left\{\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right) \phi(\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \mid \boldsymbol{\vartheta}), \pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right) \phi(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \boldsymbol{\vartheta})\right\} \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{\vartheta} \\
\geq & C \mathbb{L}\left(\left\{\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \in A: \pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right) \geq \pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)\right\}\right)+\frac{C}{\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)} \int_{\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \in A: \pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)<\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)} \pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right) \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{\vartheta} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $\mathbb{L}\left(\left\{\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \in A: \pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right) \geq \pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)\right\}\right)$ and $\int_{\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \in A: \pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)<\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)} \pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right) \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{\vartheta}$ cannot be zero simultaneously for any $A \in \mathscr{B}(\boldsymbol{\Theta})$ with $\Pi_{n}^{\dagger}(A)>0$, then $\Psi(\boldsymbol{\theta}, A)>0$ for any $A \in \mathscr{B}(\boldsymbol{\Theta})$ and $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}$ such that $\Pi_{n}^{\dagger}(A)>0$ and $\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)>0$. Therefore, it holds that $\Psi(\boldsymbol{\theta}, A)>0$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}$ and $A \in \mathscr{B}(\boldsymbol{\Theta})$ with $\Pi_{n}^{\dagger}(A)>0$. By Definition 1, the Markov chain with transition probability $\Psi(\cdot, \cdot)$ is $\Pi_{n}^{\dagger}$-irreducible. Furthermore, by Definition 2, we know the Markov chain $\left\{\boldsymbol{\theta}^{k}\right\}_{k \geq 1}$ with transition probability $\Psi(\cdot, \cdot)$ and initial point $\boldsymbol{\theta}^{0}$ is aperiodic. Notice that $\mathscr{B}(\boldsymbol{\Theta})$ is a countably generated $\sigma$-algebra. Denote by $\mathcal{T}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}^{0}}^{k}(\cdot)$ the measure which admits the distribution of such Markov chain at $k$-th step with initial point $\boldsymbol{\theta}^{0}$. Conditional on $\mathcal{X}_{n}$, for any $\boldsymbol{\theta}^{0} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}$ such that $\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{0} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)>0$, by Theorem 4 of Roberts and Rosenthal (2004), we have $\mathcal{D}_{\mathrm{rv}}\left(\mathcal{T}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}^{0}}^{k}, \Pi_{n}^{\dagger}\right) \rightarrow 0$ as $k \rightarrow \infty$. Furthermore, notice that $\boldsymbol{\Theta} \subset \mathbb{R}^{p}$ is a compact set with fixed $p$. Conditional on $\mathcal{X}_{n}$, for any $\boldsymbol{\theta}^{0} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}$ such that $\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{0} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)>0$, it follows from Fact 5 of Roberts and Rosenthal (2004) that $\left|K^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \boldsymbol{\theta}^{k}-\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\theta} \sim \pi^{\dagger}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|_{\infty} \leq\left|K^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \boldsymbol{\theta}^{k}-\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\theta} \sim \pi^{\dagger}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|_{1} \rightarrow 0$ almost surely as $K \rightarrow \infty$, where $\left\{\boldsymbol{\theta}^{k}\right\}_{k \geq 1}$ are generated via Algorithm 1 with the initial $\boldsymbol{\theta}^{0}$ and $\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\theta} \sim \pi^{\dagger}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ is defined in (8). We complete the proof of Theorem 3.

# I Proof of Theorem 4 

For the function $\mathbf{h}: \mathbb{R}^{p} \mapsto \mathbb{R}^{s}$ involved in Algorithm 2, let $\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}=\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\theta} \sim \pi^{\dagger}}\{\mathbf{h}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\}$. Define

$$
\widehat{\mathbb{E}}_{\pi^{\dagger}, K}^{*}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\frac{1}{S_{K}} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i=1}^{N_{k}} \frac{\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}^{k} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)}{\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}^{k} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right)} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}^{k}
$$

with $S_{K}=N_{1}+\cdots+N_{K}$, where $\left\{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}^{1}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{\theta}_{N_{1}}^{1}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}^{K}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{\theta}_{N_{K}}^{K}\right\}$ are generated via Algorithm 2. To construct Theorem 4, we need the following two lemmas whose proofs are given in Sections J. 12 and J.13, respectively.

Lemma 12. Assume that the conditions of Theorem 4 hold. Conditional on $\mathcal{X}_{n},\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}-\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right|_{\infty} \rightarrow 0$ almost surely as $k \rightarrow \infty$, where $\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}$ is defined in Algorithm 2.

Lemma 13. Assume that the conditions of Theorem 4 hold. Conditional on $\mathcal{X}_{n},\left|\widehat{\mathbb{E}}_{\pi^{\dagger}, K}^{*}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\right.$ $\left.\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\theta} \sim \pi^{\dagger}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|_{\infty} \rightarrow 0$ almost surely as $K \rightarrow \infty$, where $\widehat{\mathbb{E}}_{\pi^{\dagger}, K}^{*}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ is defined in (I.1).

Denote by $\mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}(\cdot)$ the conditional probability given $\mathcal{X}_{n}$. For some sufficiently large $M>0$, by Lemma 12, we have that for any $\epsilon>0$, there exists a sufficiently large integer $k_{\epsilon}$ such that $\mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}(\mathcal{A}) \leq \epsilon$ with $\mathcal{A}=\bigcup_{t=k_{\epsilon}}^{\infty}\left\{\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{t}-\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right|_{\infty}>M\right\}$. Define a compact set $\mathcal{B}=\left\{\boldsymbol{\zeta} \in \mathbb{R}^{s}\right.$ : $\left.\left|\boldsymbol{\zeta}-\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right|_{\infty} \leq M\right\}$. Recall $\boldsymbol{\Theta} \subset \mathbb{R}^{p}$ is a compact set with fixed $p$. Since $\varphi(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta})$ is positive and continuous on $(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\zeta}) \in \boldsymbol{\Theta} \times \mathbb{R}^{s}$, then $\inf _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}, \boldsymbol{\zeta} \in \mathcal{B}} \varphi(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta}) \geq C_{M}$ for some constant $C_{M}>0$ and $\varphi(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta})$ is uniformly continuous on $(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta}) \in \boldsymbol{\Theta} \times \mathcal{B}$. For any $\varepsilon>0$, there exists $\delta(\varepsilon)>0$ such that $\left|\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta}_{1}\right)-\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{2} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta}_{2}\right)\right|<C_{M}\left(2+2 C_{M}\right)^{-1} \varepsilon$ for any $\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}, \boldsymbol{\zeta}_{1}\right),\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{2}, \boldsymbol{\zeta}_{2}\right) \in \boldsymbol{\Theta} \times \mathcal{B}$ satisfying $\left|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}-\boldsymbol{\theta}_{2}\right|_{\infty} \leq \delta(\varepsilon)$ and $\left|\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{1}-\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{2}\right|_{\infty} \leq \delta(\varepsilon)$. For any $K \geq k_{\epsilon}$, it holds that

$$
\inf _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}} \frac{1}{S_{K}} \sum_{k=1}^{K} N_{k} \varphi(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta}) \geq \inf _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}} \frac{1}{S_{K}} \sum_{k=k_{\epsilon}}^{K} N_{k} \varphi(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta}) \geq \frac{C_{M}}{S_{K}}\left(S_{K}-\sum_{k=1}^{k_{\epsilon}-1} N_{k}\right)
$$

for any $\boldsymbol{\zeta} \in \mathcal{B}$. Notice that $S_{K} \rightarrow \infty$ as $K \rightarrow \infty$.
