Given $k_{\epsilon}$, there exists a sufficiently large integer $K^{*}$ such that $S_{K} /\left(S_{K}-\sum_{k=1}^{k_{\epsilon}-1} N_{k}\right) \leq 1+C_{M}$ for all $K>K^{*}$. Recall $N_{k} \leq N_{k+1}$ for any $k \geq 1$ and $N_{k} \rightarrow \infty$ as $k \rightarrow \infty$. Since $\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}, \boldsymbol{\zeta} \in \mathbb{R}^{s}} \varphi(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta})<\infty$, we have

$$
\frac{1}{S_{t}} \sum_{k=1}^{\lfloor\sqrt{t}\rfloor} N_{k} \sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}}\left|\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right)-\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)\right| \lesssim \frac{1}{S_{t}} \sum_{k=1}^{\lfloor\sqrt{t}\rfloor} N_{k} \rightarrow 0
$$

as $t \rightarrow \infty$. For given $\varepsilon>0$, there exists some sufficiently large integer $\tilde{K}$ such that

$$
\frac{1}{\tilde{S}_{t}} \sum_{k=1}^{|\sqrt{t}|} N_{k} \sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}}\left|\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right)-\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)\right| \leq \frac{C_{M} \varepsilon}{2\left(1+C_{M}\right)}
$$

for any $t \geq \tilde{K}$. It holds that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\{\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}}\left|\frac{\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right)}{S_{t}^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{t} N_{k} \varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)}-1\right|>\varepsilon, \mathcal{A}^{c}\right\} \\
& \quad \subset\left\{\frac{1}{S_{t}} \sum_{k=1}^{t} N_{k} \sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}}\left|\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right)-\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)\right|>\frac{C_{M} \varepsilon}{1+C_{M}}, \mathcal{A}^{c}\right\} \\
& \quad \subset\left\{\frac{1}{\tilde{S}_{t}} \sum_{k=|\sqrt{t}|+1}^{t} N_{k} \sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}}\left|\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right)-\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)\right|>\frac{C_{M} \varepsilon}{2+2 C_{M}}, \mathcal{A}^{c}\right\} \\
& \quad \subset \bigcup_{k=|\sqrt{t}|+1}^{t}\left\{\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}-\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right|_{\infty}>\delta(\varepsilon), \mathcal{A}^{c}\right\} \subset \bigcup_{k=|\sqrt{t}|+1}^{t}\left\{\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}-\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right|_{\infty}>\delta(\varepsilon)\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

for any $t>\max \left(K^{*}, k_{\epsilon}, \tilde{K}\right)$. We then have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \limsup _{m \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left[\bigcup_{t=m}^{\infty}\left\{\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}}\left|\frac{\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right)}{S_{t}^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{t} N_{k} \varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)}-1\right|>\varepsilon\right\}\right] \\
& \quad \leq \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}(\mathcal{A})+\limsup _{m \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left[\bigcup_{k=\lfloor m\rfloor+1}^{\infty}\left\{\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}-\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right|_{\infty}>\delta(\varepsilon)\right\}\right]=\mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}(\mathcal{A}) \leq \epsilon
\end{aligned}
$$

where the second step is due to the fact that conditional on $\mathcal{X}_{n}$ we have $\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}-\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right|_{\infty} \rightarrow 0$ almost surely as $k \rightarrow \infty$. Letting $\epsilon \rightarrow 0$, we know that conditional on $\mathcal{X}_{n}$,

$$
\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}}\left|\frac{\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right)}{S_{K}^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} N_{k} \varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)}-1\right| \rightarrow 0
$$

almost surely as $K \rightarrow \infty$.
Define

$$
\widehat{\mathbb{E}}_{\pi^{\dagger}, K}^{*}\left(|\boldsymbol{\theta}|_{\infty}\right)=\frac{1}{S_{K}} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i=1}^{N_{k}} \frac{\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}^{k} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)}{\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}^{k} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right)}\left|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}^{k}\right|_{\infty} \text { and } \mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\theta} \rightarrow \pi^{\dagger}}\left(|\boldsymbol{\theta}|_{\infty}\right)=\int_{\mathbb{R}^{p}}|\boldsymbol{\theta}|_{\infty} \pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right) \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{\theta}
$$

where $\left\{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}^{1}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{\theta}_{N_{1}}^{1}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}^{K}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{\theta}_{N_{K}}^{K}\right\}$ are generated via Algorithm 2. For $\widehat{\mathbb{E}}_{\pi^{\dagger}, K}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ defined in (9) and $\widehat{\mathbb{E}}_{\pi^{\dagger}, K}^{*}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ defined in (I.1), since $\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)|\boldsymbol{\theta}|_{\infty} / \varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right)=0$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \notin \boldsymbol{\Theta}$, we then have

$$
\left|\widehat{\mathbb{E}}_{\pi^{\dagger}, K}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\widehat{\mathbb{E}}_{\pi^{\dagger}, K}^{*}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|_{\infty} \leq \frac{1}{S_{K}} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i=1}^{N_{k}} \frac{\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}^{k} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)\left|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}^{k}\right|_{\infty}}{\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}^{k} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right)}\left|\frac{\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}^{k} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right)}{S_{K}^{-1} \sum_{l=1}^{K} N_{l} \varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}^{k} ; \hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{l}\right)}-1\right|
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \leq \widehat{\mathbb{E}}_{\pi^{1}, K}^{*}\left(|\boldsymbol{\theta}|_{\infty}\right) \sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}}\left|\frac{\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}: \boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right)}{S_{K}^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} N_{k} \varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}: \hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)}-1\right| \\
& \leq \mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\theta} \sim \pi^{1}}\left(|\boldsymbol{\theta}|_{\infty}\right) \sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}}\left|\frac{\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}: \boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right)}{S_{K}^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} N_{k} \varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}: \hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)}-1\right| \\
& +\left|\widehat{\mathbb{E}}_{\pi^{1}, K}^{*}\left(|\boldsymbol{\theta}|_{\infty}\right)-\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\theta} \sim \pi^{1}}\left(|\boldsymbol{\theta}|_{\infty}\right)\right| \sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}}\left|\frac{\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}: \boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right)}{S_{K}^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{K} N_{k} \varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}: \hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)}-1\right|
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the same arguments for the proof of Lemma 13 in Section J.13, it holds that conditional on $\mathcal{X}_{n}$ we have $\left|\widehat{\mathbb{E}}_{\pi^{1}, K}^{*}\left(|\boldsymbol{\theta}|_{\infty}\right)-\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\theta} \sim \pi^{1}}\left(|\boldsymbol{\theta}|_{\infty}\right)\right| \rightarrow 0$ almost surely as $K \rightarrow \infty$. Notice that $\boldsymbol{\Theta} \subset \mathbb{R}^{p}$ is a compact set with fixed $p$. Then $\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\theta} \sim \pi^{1}}\left(|\boldsymbol{\theta}|_{\infty}\right)<\infty$. Together with (I.2), it holds that conditional on $\mathcal{X}_{n}$ we have $\left|\widehat{\mathbb{E}}_{\pi^{1}, K}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\widehat{\mathbb{E}}_{\pi^{1}, K}^{*}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|_{\infty} \rightarrow 0$ almost surely as $K \rightarrow \infty$. By the triangle inequality and Lemma 13, conditional on $\mathcal{X}_{n},\left|\widehat{\mathbb{E}}_{\pi^{1}, K}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\theta} \sim \pi^{1}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|_{\infty} \leq\left|\widehat{\mathbb{E}}_{\pi^{1}, K}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\widehat{\mathbb{E}}_{\pi^{1}, K}^{*}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|_{\infty}+\left|\widehat{\mathbb{E}}_{\pi^{1}, K}^{*}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\right.$ $\left.\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\theta} \sim \pi^{1}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|_{\infty} \rightarrow 0$ almost surely as $K \rightarrow \infty$. We complete the proof of Theorem 4.

# J Proofs of auxiliary lemmas
## J. 1 Proof of Lemma 1

The proof is almost identical to that of Lemma 1 in Chang et al. (2018). Recall $p$ is fixed. We only need to replace $\left\{\varrho_{n}, \omega_{n}, \xi_{n}, b_{n}^{1 /(2 \beta)}, s\right\}$ appeared in the proof of Lemma 1 in Chang et al. (2018) by $(1,1,1, \varphi_{n}, p)$ and all the arguments still hold.

## J.2.1 Case 1: $\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}} \neq \emptyset$

Restricted on $\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}$, we select $\delta_{n}$ satisfying $\delta_{n}=o\left(\ell_{n}^{-1 / 2} n^{-1 / \gamma}\right)$ and $\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}=o\left(\delta_{n}\right)$, which can be guaranteed by $\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}=o\left(n^{-1 / \gamma}\right)$. Let $\Lambda_{0}=\left\{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \mathbb{R}^{r}:\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}}\right|_{2} \leq \delta_{n}\right.$ and $\left.\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*}}=\mathbf{0}\right\}$ and $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}=\arg \max _{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \Lambda_{0}} f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$. By Condition 2(a), we have $\max _{i \in[n], j \in[r]}\left|g_{i, j}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(n^{1 / \gamma}\right)$, which implies $\max _{i \in[n]}\left|\mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} n^{1 / \gamma}\right)$. Then $\max _{i \in[n]}\left|\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$. Write $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}=$

$\left(\tilde{\lambda}_{0,1}, \ldots, \tilde{\lambda}_{0, r}\right)^{\top}$. By the Taylor expansion, we have

$$
0=f_{n}\left(\mathbf{0} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right) \leq f_{n}\left(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)=\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}^{\top} \overline{\mathbf{g}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)-\frac{1}{2 n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}^{\top} \overline{\mathbf{g}}_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)^{\otimes 2} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}}{\left\{1+C \tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0} \overline{\mathbf{g}}_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right\}^{2}}-\sum_{j=1}^{r} P_{\nu}\left(\left|\tilde{\lambda}_{0, j}\right|\right)
$$

for some $C \in(0,1)$. By Condition 2(b) and the same arguments for deriving Lemma 1, if $\log r=$ $o\left(n^{1 / 3}\right)$ and $\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}=o(1)$, we have $\lambda_{\min }\left\{\tilde{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right\}$ is uniformly bounded away from zero w.p.a.1. Thus $0 \leq\left|\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0, \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}}\right|_{2}\left|\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|_{2}-4^{-1} K_{3}\left|\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0, \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}}\right|_{2}^{2}$ w.p.a.1, where $K_{3}$ is specified in Condition 2(b). By the moderate deviation of self-normalized sums (Jing et al., 2003), $\left|\overline{\mathbf{g}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|_{\infty}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\alpha_{n}\right)$. Then $\left|\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right)$ and $\left|\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0, \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}}\right|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right)=o_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\delta_{n}\right)$. Write $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0, \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}}=\left(\tilde{\lambda}_{1}, \ldots, \tilde{\lambda}_{\left|\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}\right|}\right)^{\top}$. We then have w.p.a. 1 that

$$
\mathbf{0}=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)}{1+\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0, \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)}-\tilde{\boldsymbol{\eta}}
$$

where $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\eta}}=\left(\tilde{\eta}_{1}, \ldots, \tilde{\eta}_{\left|\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}\right|}\right)^{\top}$ with $\tilde{\eta}_{j}=\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(\left|\tilde{\lambda}_{j}\right| ; \nu\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left(\tilde{\lambda}_{j}\right)$ for $\tilde{\lambda}_{j} \neq 0$ and $\tilde{\eta}_{j} \in\left[-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right), \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)\right]$ for $\tilde{\lambda}_{j}=0$. In the sequel, we will show that $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}$ is a local maximizer for $f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$ w.p.a.1.

Firstly, define $\Lambda_{0}^{*}=\left\{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \mathbb{R}^{r}:\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*}}\right|_{2} \leq \varepsilon, \boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*}}=\mathbf{0}\right\}$ for some sufficiently small constant $\varepsilon>0$. For $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}$ defined before, we will prove $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}=\arg \max _{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \Lambda_{0}^{*}} f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$ w.p.a.1. Since $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0} \in \Lambda_{0}$ and $\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}} \subset \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*}$, we know $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0} \in \Lambda_{0}^{*}$ for sufficiently large $n$. Restricted on $\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \Lambda_{0}^{*}$, by the concavity of $f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$ w.r.t $\boldsymbol{\lambda}$, it suffices to show that $\mathbf{w}=\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0, \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*}}=:\left(w_{1}, \ldots, w_{\left|\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}\right|}\right)^{\top} \in \mathbb{R}^{\left|\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*}\right|}$ satisfies the equation

$$
\mathbf{0}=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)}{1+\mathbf{w}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)}-\tilde{\boldsymbol{\eta}}^{*}}
$$

w.p.a.1, where $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\eta}}^{*}=\left(\tilde{\eta}_{1}^{*}, \ldots, \tilde{\eta}_{\left|\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*}\right|}^{*}\right)^{\top}$ with $\tilde{\eta}_{j}^{*}=\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(\left|w_{j}\right| ; \nu\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left(w_{j}\right)$ for $w_{j} \neq 0$ and $\tilde{\eta}_{j}^{*} \in$ $\left[-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right), \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)\right]$for $w_{j}=0$. By (J.1), we know $0=n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n} g_{i, j}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right) /\left\{1+\mathbf{w}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right\}-\tilde{\eta}_{j}^{*}$ holds for any $j \in \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}$. For any $j \in \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*}\left\lceil\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}\right.$, since $\max _{i \in[n]}\left|\mathbf{w}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|=\max _{i \in[n]}\left|\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|=$ $o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$, it holds that

$$
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{g_{i, j}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)}{1+\mathbf{w}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)}=\bar{g}_{j}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)+R_{j}
$$

with

$$
\left|R_{j}\right|^{2}=\left|\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\mathbf{w}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right) g_{i, j}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)}{1+\mathbf{w}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)}\right|^{2} \leq \max _{j \in[r]}\left\{\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left|\mathbf{w}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|\left|g_{i, j}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|\right\}^{2} \cdot\left\{1+o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)\right\}
$$

$$
\leq \mathbf{w}^{\top} \tilde{\mathbf{\nabla}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right) \mathbf{w} \cdot \max _{j \in[r]} \mathbb{E}_{n}\left\{\left|g_{i, j}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|^{2}\right\} \cdot\left\{1+o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)\right\}
$$

Due to $|\mathbf{w}|_{2}=\left|\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0, \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}}\right|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right)$, by Conditions 2(a) and 2(b), $\max _{j \in[r]}\left|R_{j}\right|=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(|\mathbf{w}|_{2}\right)=$ $O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\left.\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right)$. Notice that $C_{*} \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \leq\left|\bar{g}_{j}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|<c \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)$for any $j \in \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*} \backslash \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}$, and $\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}=$ $o(\nu)$. Then

$$
\max _{j \in \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*} \backslash \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}}\left|\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{g_{i, j}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)}{1+\mathbf{w}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)}\right| \leq \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)
$$

w.p.a.1, which implies (J.2) holds. Thus $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}=\arg \max _{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \Lambda_{0}^{*}} f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$ w.p.a.1.

Secondly, define $\tilde{\Lambda}_{0}=\left\{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \mathbb{R}^{r}:\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*}}-\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0, \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*}}\right|_{2} \leq O\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right),\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*}}\right|_{1} \leq O\left(\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}\right)\right\}$. We will show $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}=\arg \max _{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \tilde{\Lambda}_{0}} f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$ w.p.a.1. Recall $\max _{i \in[n], j \in[r]}\left|g_{i, j}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(n^{1 / \gamma}\right)$ and $\left|\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}\right|_{2}=$ $O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right)$. Since $\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}=o\left(n^{-1 / \gamma}\right)$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sup _{i \in[n], \boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \tilde{\Lambda}_{0}}\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right| & \leq \sup _{i \in[n], \boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \tilde{\Lambda}_{0}}\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*}}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|+\sup _{i \in[n], \boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \tilde{\Lambda}_{0}}\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*}}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*, o}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right| \\
& \leq \sup _{i \in[n], \boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \tilde{\Lambda}_{0}}\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*}}\right|_{2}\left|\mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|_{2}+\sup _{i \in[n], \boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \tilde{\Lambda}_{0}} \max _{j \in[r]}\left|g_{i, j}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*}}^{\top}\right|_{1}=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)
\end{aligned}
$$

For any $\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \tilde{\Lambda}_{0}$, denote by $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}=\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*}}^{\top}, \mathbf{0}^{\top}\right)^{\top}$ the projection of $\boldsymbol{\lambda}=\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*}}^{\top}, \boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*, o}}^{\top}\right)^{\top}$ onto $\Lambda_{0}^{*}$. Write $\boldsymbol{\lambda}=\left(\lambda_{1}, \ldots, \lambda_{r}\right)^{\top}$. By the Taylor expansion, it holds that

$$
f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)-f_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\mathbf{g}_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)^{\top}(\boldsymbol{\lambda}-\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}})}{1+\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{*}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)}-\sum_{j \in \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*, o}} P_{\nu}\left(\left|\lambda_{j}\right|\right)
$$

where $\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{*}$ is on the jointing line between $\boldsymbol{\lambda}$ and $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}$. Let $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}=\arg \max _{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \tilde{\Lambda}_{0}} f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$. Due to $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0} \in$ $\operatorname{int}\left(\tilde{\Lambda}_{0}\right)$, then $f_{n}\left(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right) \leq f_{n}\left(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$. For any $\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \tilde{\Lambda}_{0}$, due to $\sum_{j \in \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*, o}} P_{\nu}\left(\left|\lambda_{j}\right|\right) \geq \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*}}\right|_{1}$ and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\mathbf{g}_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)^{\top}(\boldsymbol{\lambda}-\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}})}{1+\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{*}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)}\right| & =\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*}}^{\top} \tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*, o}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)-\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{*}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right) \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*, o}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)^{\top} \boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*, o}}}{1+\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{*}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)}\right| \\
& \leq\left|\mathbf{g}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*, o}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|_{\infty}\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*, o}}\right|_{1}+\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{r} \sum_{k \in \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*}} \mid \lambda_{*, j} g_{i, j}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right) \lambda_{k} g_{i, k}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right) \mid\left\{1+o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)\right\} \\
& \leq C_{*} \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*, o}}\right|_{1}+\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*, o}}\right|_{1}\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{*}\right|_{1}\left\{1+o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)\right\} \max _{j \in[r]} \mathbb{E}_{n}\left\{\left|g_{i, j}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|^{2}\right\} \\
& \leq\left\{C_{*} \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)+O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}\right)\right\}\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*, o}}\right|_{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

then $f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)-f_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right) \leq\left\{-\left(1-C_{*}\right) \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)+O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}\right)\right\}\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*, o}}\right|_{1}$ for any $\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \tilde{\Lambda}_{0}$, where the term $O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}\right)$ holds uniformly over $\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \tilde{\Lambda}_{0}$. Since $\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}=o(\nu)$, we have $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0, \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}^{*, o}}=\mathbf{0}$

w.p.a.1, which implies $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0} \in \operatorname{int}\left(\Lambda_{0}^{*}\right)$ w.p.a.1. Recall $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}=\arg \max _{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \Lambda_{0}^{*}} f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$ w.p.a.1. Then $f_{n}\left(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right) \geq f_{n}\left(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$ w.p.a.1. Therefore, $f_{n}\left(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)=f_{n}\left(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$ w.p.a.1. By the concavity of $f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$ w.r.t $\boldsymbol{\lambda}$, we have $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}=\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}$ w.p.a.1, which indicates that $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}$ is a local maximizer for $f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$ w.p.a.1. Then $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)=\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}$ and $\operatorname{supp}\left\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right\} \subset \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}$ w.p.a.1.

# J.2.2 Case 2: $\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}=\emptyset$ 

In this case, we will show $\mathbf{0} \in \mathbb{R}^{r}$ is a local maximizer for $f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$ w.p.a.1. Due to the concavity of $f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$ w.r.t $\boldsymbol{\lambda}$, we then have $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)=\mathbf{0}$ w.p.a.1, which implies $\operatorname{supp}\left\{\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right\} \subset \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}}$ w.p.a.1. Let $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}=\arg \max _{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \hat{\lambda}_{0}} f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$, where $\hat{\Lambda}_{0}=\left\{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \mathbb{R}^{r}:\left|\lambda_{j_{0}}\right| \leq(\log n)^{-1} n^{-1 / \gamma}, \boldsymbol{\lambda}_{[r] \backslash\{j_{0}\}}=\mathbf{0}\right\}$ with $j_{0}=\arg \max _{j \in[r]} \mathbb{E}\left\{g_{i, j}^{2}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right\}$. It follows from Condition 2(a) that $\max _{i \in[n]}\left|g_{i, j_{0}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(n^{1 / \gamma}\right)$. Hence, $\max _{i \in[n]}\left|\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left\{(\log n)^{-1}\right\}=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$. Write $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}=\left(\bar{\lambda}_{0,1}, \ldots, \bar{\lambda}_{0, r}\right)^{\top}$. By the Taylor expansion, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
0=f_{n}\left(\mathbf{0} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right) \leq f_{n}\left(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right) & =\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}^{\top} \overline{\mathbf{g}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)-\frac{1}{2 n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)^{\otimes 2} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}}{\left\{1+C \tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right\}^{2}}-\sum_{j=1}^{r} P_{\nu}\left(\left|\bar{\lambda}_{0, j}\right|\right) \\
& \leq\left|\tilde{\lambda}_{0, j_{0}}\right|\left|\bar{g}_{j_{0}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|-2^{-1}\left|\tilde{\lambda}_{0, j_{0}}\right|^{2} \mathbb{E}_{n}\left\{g_{i, j_{0}}^{2}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right\}\left\{1+o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

for some $C \in(0,1)$. Notice that $\left|\mathbb{E}_{n}\left\{g_{i, j_{0}}^{2}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right\}-\mathbb{E}\left\{g_{i, j_{0}}^{2}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right\}\right|=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)$. By Condition 2(b), we have $\mathbb{E}_{n}\left\{g_{i, j_{0}}^{2}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right\} \geq \mathbb{E}\left\{g_{i, j_{0}}^{2}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right\}-o_{\mathrm{p}}(1) \geq 2 K_{3} / 3$ w.p.a. 1 for $K_{3}$ specified in Condition 2(b). Thus $0 \leq\left|\tilde{\lambda}_{0, j_{0}}\right|\left|\bar{g}_{j_{0}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|-4^{-1} K_{3}\left|\tilde{\lambda}_{0, j_{0}}\right|^{2}$ w.p.a.1. Since $\left|\bar{g}_{j_{0}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)$, then $\left|\tilde{\lambda}_{0, j_{0}}\right|=$ $O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)=o_{\mathrm{p}}\left\{(\log n)^{-1} n^{-1 / \gamma}\right\}$. It then holds w.p.a. 1 that

$$
0=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{g_{i, j_{0}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)}{1+\bar{\lambda}_{0, j_{0}} g_{i, j_{0}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)}-\bar{\eta}_{j_{0}}
$$

where $\bar{\eta}_{j_{0}}=\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(\left|\bar{\lambda}_{j_{0}}\right| ; \nu\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left(\bar{\lambda}_{j_{0}}\right)$ if $\bar{\lambda}_{j_{0}} \neq 0$ and $\bar{\eta}_{j_{0}} \in\left[-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right), \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)\right]$if $\bar{\lambda}_{j_{0}}=0$. Due to $\left|\bar{\lambda}_{0, j_{0}} g_{i, j_{0}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$, then

$$
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{g_{i, j_{0}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)}{1+\bar{\lambda}_{0, j_{0}} g_{i, j_{0}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)}=\bar{g}_{j_{0}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)+R_{j_{0}}
$$

with

$$
\left|R_{j_{0}}\right|=\left|\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\bar{\lambda}_{0, j_{0}} g_{i, j_{0}}^{2}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)}{1+\bar{\lambda}_{0, j_{0}} g_{i, j_{0}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)}\right| \leq\left|\bar{\lambda}_{0, j_{0}}\right| \mathbb{E}_{n}\left\{g_{i, j_{0}}^{2}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right\}\left\{1+o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)\right\}
$$

By Conditions 2(a), we have $\left|R_{j_{0}}\right|=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\left|\bar{\lambda}_{0, j_{0}}\right|\right)=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)$. Together with $\left|\bar{g}_{j_{0}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)$, (J.5) leads to $\left|\bar{\eta}_{j_{0}}\right|=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)=o_{\mathrm{p}}(\nu)$. Then $\bar{\lambda}_{j_{0}}=0$ w.p.a.1, which implies $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}=\mathbf{0}$ w.p.a.1. In the sequel, we will show that $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}$ is a local maximizer for $f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$ w.p.a.1.

Firstly, define $\check{\Lambda}_{0}^{*}=\left\{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \mathbb{R}^{r}:\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{H}}\right|_{2} \leq \varepsilon, \boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{H}^{c}}=\mathbf{0}\right\}$ for some sufficiently small constant $\varepsilon>0$, where $j_{0} \in \mathcal{H} \subset[r]$ with $1<|\mathcal{H}| \leq \ell_{n}$. For $\check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}$ defined before, we will prove $\check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}=$ $\arg \max _{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \check{\Lambda}_{0}^{*}} f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$ w.p.a.1. Since $\check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0} \in \check{\Lambda}_{0}$ and $j_{0} \in \mathcal{H}$, we know $\check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0} \in \check{\Lambda}_{0}^{*}$ for sufficiently large $n$. Restricted on $\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \check{\Lambda}_{0}^{*}$, by the concavity of $f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$ w.r.t $\boldsymbol{\lambda}$, it suffices to show that $\check{\mathbf{w}}=\check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0, \mathcal{H}}=:\left(\breve{w}_{1}, \ldots, \breve{w}_{|\mathcal{H}|}\right)^{\top} \in \mathbb{R}^{|\mathcal{H}|}$ satisfies the equation

$$
\mathbf{0}=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{H}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)}{1+\check{\mathbf{w}}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{H}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)}-\check{\boldsymbol{\eta}}^{*}
$$

w.p.a.1, where $\check{\boldsymbol{\eta}}^{*}=\left(\check{\eta}_{1}^{*}, \ldots, \check{\eta}_{|\mathcal{H}|}^{*}\right)^{\top}$ with $\check{\eta}_{j}^{*}=\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(\left|\breve{w}_{j}\right| ; \nu\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left(\breve{w}_{j}\right)$ for $\breve{w}_{j} \neq 0$ and $\check{\eta}_{j}^{*} \in\left[-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right), \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)\right]$ for $\breve{w}_{j}=0$. Recall $j_{0} \in \mathcal{H}$. Without loss of generality, we assume $j_{0}$ is the first component in $\mathcal{H}$. By (J.5), we know $0=n^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{n} g_{i, j_{0}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right) /\left\{1+\check{\mathbf{w}}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{H}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right\}-\check{\eta}_{1}^{*}$ holds. Since $\check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}=\mathbf{0}$ w.p.a.1, then $\check{\mathbf{w}}=\mathbf{0}$ w.p.a.1, which implies it holds w.p.a. 1 that

$$
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{g_{i, j}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)}{1+\check{\mathbf{w}}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{H}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)}=\check{g}_{j}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)
$$

for any $j \in \mathcal{H} \backslash\left\{j_{0}\right\}$. By the moderate deviation of self-normalized sums (Jing et al., 2003), $\left|\check{\mathbf{g}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|_{\infty}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\alpha_{n}\right)$. Due to $\alpha_{n}=o(\nu)$, then

$$
\max _{j \in \mathcal{H} \backslash\left\{j_{0}\right\}}\left|\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{g_{i, j}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)}{1+\check{\mathbf{w}}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{H}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)}\right| \leq \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)
$$

w.p.a.1, which implies (J.6) holds. Thus $\check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}=\arg \max _{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \check{\Lambda}_{0}^{*}} f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$ w.p.a.1.

Secondly, define $\check{\Lambda}_{0}=\left\{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \mathbb{R}^{r}:\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{H}}-\check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0, \mathcal{H}}\right|_{2} \leq O\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right),\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{H}^{c}}\right|_{1} \leq O\left(\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}\right)\right\}$. We will show $\check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}=\arg \max _{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \check{\Lambda}_{0}} f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$ w.p.a.1. Recall $\max _{i \in[n], j \in[r]}\left|g_{i, j}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(n^{1 / \gamma}\right)$ and $\left|\check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}\right|_{2}=\left|\check{\Lambda}_{0, j_{0}}\right|=$ $O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(n^{-1 / 2}\right)$. Since $\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}=o\left(n^{-1 / \gamma}\right)$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sup _{i \in[n], \boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \Lambda_{0}}\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right| & \leq \sup _{i \in[n], \boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \Lambda_{0}}\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{H}}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{H}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|+\sup _{i \in[n], \boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \Lambda_{0}}\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{H}^{c}}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{H}^{c}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right| \\
& \leq \sup _{i \in[n], \boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \Lambda_{0}}\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{H}}\right|_{2}\left|\mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{H}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|_{2}+\sup _{i \in[n], \boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \Lambda_{0}} \max _{j \in[r]}\left|g_{i, j}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{H}^{c}}^{\top}\right|_{1}=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)
\end{aligned}
$$

For any $\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \check{\Lambda}_{0}$, denote by $\check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}=\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{H}}^{\top}, \mathbf{0}^{\top}\right)^{\top}$ the projection of $\boldsymbol{\lambda}=\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{H}}^{\top}, \boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{H}^{c}}^{\top}\right)^{\top}$ onto $\check{\Lambda}_{0}^{*}$. Write $\boldsymbol{\lambda}=\left(\lambda_{1}, \ldots, \lambda_{r}\right)^{\top}$. By the Taylor expansion, it holds that

$$
f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)-f_{n}\left(\check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\mathbf{g}_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)^{\top}(\boldsymbol{\lambda}-\check{\boldsymbol{\lambda}})}{1+\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{*}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)}-\sum_{j \in \mathcal{H}^{c}} P_{\nu}\left(\left|\lambda_{j}\right|\right)
$$

where $\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{*}$ is on the jointing line between $\boldsymbol{\lambda}$ and $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}$. Let $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}=\arg \max _{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \Lambda_{0}} f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$. Due to $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0} \in$ $\operatorname{int}\left(\hat{\Lambda}_{0}\right)$, then $f_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right) \leq f_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$. For any $\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \hat{\Lambda}_{0}$, due to $\sum_{j \in \mathcal{H}^{c}} P_{\nu}\left(\left|\lambda_{j}\right|\right) \geq \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{H}^{c}}\right|_{1}$ and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\mathbf{g}_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)^{\top}(\boldsymbol{\lambda}-\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}})}{1+\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{*}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)}\right| & =\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{H}^{c}}^{\top} \overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{H}^{c}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)-\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{*}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right) \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{H}^{c}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)^{\top} \boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{H}^{c}}}{1+\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{*}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)}\right| \\
& \leq\left|\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{H}^{c}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|_{\infty}\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{H}^{c}}\right|_{1}+\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{j=1}^{r} \sum_{k \in \mathcal{H}^{c}}\left|\lambda_{*, j} g_{i, j}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right) \lambda_{k} g_{i, k}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|\left\{1+o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)\right\} \\
& \leq O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\alpha_{n}\right) \cdot\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{H}^{c}}\right|_{1}+\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{H}^{c}}\right|_{1}\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{*}\right|_{1}\left\{1+o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)\right\} \max _{j \in[r]} \mathbb{E}_{n}\left\{\left|g_{i, j}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|^{2}\right\} \\
& \leq O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}\right) \cdot\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{H}^{c}}\right|_{1}
\end{aligned}
$$

then $f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)-f_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right) \leq\left\{-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)+O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}\right)\right\}\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{H}^{c}}\right|_{1}$ for any $\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \hat{\Lambda}_{0}$, where the term $O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}\right)$ holds uniformly over $\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \hat{\Lambda}_{0}$. Since $\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}=o(\nu)$, we have $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0, \mathcal{H}^{c}}=\mathbf{0}$ w.p.a.1, which implies $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0} \in \operatorname{int}\left(\hat{\Lambda}_{0}^{*}\right)$ w.p.a.1. Recall $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}=\arg \max _{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \hat{\Lambda}_{0}^{*}} f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$ w.p.a.1. Then $f_{n}\left(\overline{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right) \geq$ $f_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$ w.p.a.1. Therefore, $f_{n}\left(\overline{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)=f_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$ w.p.a.1. By the concavity of $f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$ w.r.t $\boldsymbol{\lambda}$, we have $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}=\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}$ w.p.a.1, which indicates that $\mathbf{0}$ is a local maximizer for $f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$ w.p.a.1.

# J. 3 Proof of Lemma 3 

Same as the proof of Lemma 2, we only need to show that there exists a local maximizer satisfying the results stated in the lemma. Recall $\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n}}^{*}=\left\{j \in[r]: \left|\bar{g}_{j}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right| \geq C_{*} \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)\right\}$for some $C_{*} \in(0,1)$, and $\mathbb{P}\left(\max _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta} ;\left|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right|_{2} \leq c_{n}}\left|\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{*}\right| \leq \ell_{n}\right) \rightarrow 1$ for some $c_{n} \rightarrow 0$ satisfying $\nu c_{n}^{-1} \rightarrow 0$. For $\tilde{c} \in\left(C_{*}, 1\right)$ given in Condition 4(a), write $\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n}}:=\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}}(\tilde{c})=\left\{j \in[r]: \left|\bar{g}_{j}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right| \geq \tilde{c} \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)\right\}$. By Proposition 1, $\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}-\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right|_{\infty}=O_{\mathrm{p}}(\nu)$. Notice that $p$ is fixed. Then $\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}-\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}(\nu)$ which implies $\ell_{n} \geq\left|\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}}^{*}\right| \geq\left|\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}}\right|$ w.p.a.1. Restricted on $\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}}$, we select $\delta_{n}$ satisfying $\delta_{n}=o\left(\ell_{n}^{-1 / 2} n^{-1 / \gamma}\right)$ and $\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}=o\left(\delta_{n}\right)$, which can be guaranteed by $\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}=o\left(n^{-1 / \gamma}\right)$. Let $\Lambda_{n}=\left\{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \mathbb{R}^{r}:\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}}\right|_{2} \leq\right.$ $\left.\delta_{n}, \boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}_{n}}=\mathbf{0}\right\}$ and $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{n}=\left(\tilde{\lambda}_{n, 1}, \ldots, \tilde{\lambda}_{n, r}\right)^{\top}=\arg \max _{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \Lambda_{n}} f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)$. By the Taylor expansion, we have

$$
0=f_{n}\left(\mathbf{0} ; \hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) \leq f_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{n} ; \hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)=\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{n}^{\top} \tilde{\mathbf{g}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\frac{1}{2 n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{n}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)^{\otimes 2} \tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{n}}{\left\{1+C \tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{n}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}^{2}}-\sum_{j=1}^{r} P_{\nu}\left(\left|\tilde{\lambda}_{n, j}\right|\right)
$$

for some $C \in(0,1)$. By Proposition 1, Lemma 1 and Condition 2(b), if $\log r=o\left(n^{1 / 3}\right), \ell_{n} \nu^{2}=o(1)$ and $\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}=o\left[\min \left\{\nu, n^{-1 / \gamma}\right\}\right]$, we have $\lambda_{\min }\left\{\widehat{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}$ is uniformly bounded away from zero

w.p.a.1. Therefore, it holds w.p.a. 1 that

$$
0 \leq \tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{n, \mathcal{M}_{\hat{\theta}_{n}}}\left[\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\theta}_{n}}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\theta}_{n}}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}\right]-4^{-1} K_{3}\left|\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{n, \mathcal{M}_{\hat{\theta}_{n}}}\right|_{2}^{2}
$$

with $K_{3}$ specified in Condition 2(b), which implies $\left|\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{n, \mathcal{M}_{\hat{\theta}_{n}}}\right|_{2} \leq 4 K_{3}^{-1}\left|\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\theta}_{n}}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\theta}_{n}}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}\right|_{2}$ w.p.a.1.

Select $\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{n}^{*} \in \mathbb{R}^{r}$ satisfying $\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{n, \mathcal{M}_{\hat{\theta}_{n}}}^{*}=\mathbf{0}$ and

$$
\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{n, \mathcal{M}_{\hat{\theta}_{n}}}^{*}=\frac{\delta_{n}\left[\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\theta}_{n}}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\theta}_{n}}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}\right]}{\left|\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\theta}_{n}}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\theta}_{n}}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}\right|_{2}}
$$

Then $\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{n}^{*} \in \Lambda_{n}$. As shown in the proof of Proposition 1, $\max _{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \Lambda_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)} f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}^{2}\right)=$ $o_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\delta_{n}^{2}\right)$, which implies $\max _{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \Lambda_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)} f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)=o_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\delta_{n}^{2}\right)$. Write $\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{n}^{*}=\left(\lambda_{n, \Lambda}^{*}, \ldots, \lambda_{n, r}^{*}\right)^{\top}$. Notice that $\Lambda_{n} \subset \hat{\Lambda}_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)$ w.p.a.1. By the Taylor expansion, it holds w.p.a. 1 that

$$
\begin{aligned}
o_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\delta_{n}^{2}\right)=\max _{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \hat{\Lambda}_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)} f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) & \geq \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \log \left\{1+\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{n, \mathcal{M}_{\hat{\theta}_{n}}}^{*, \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{M}_{\hat{\theta}_{n}}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}-\sum_{j \in \mathcal{M}_{\hat{\theta}_{n}}} P_{\nu}\left(\left|\lambda_{n, j}^{*}\right|\right) \\
= & \boldsymbol{\lambda}_{n, \mathcal{M}_{\hat{\theta}_{n}}}^{*, \overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\theta}_{n}}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\frac{1}{2 n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{n, \mathcal{M}_{\hat{\theta}_{n}}}^{*, \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{M}_{\hat{\theta}_{n}}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)^{\otimes 2} \boldsymbol{\lambda}_{n, \mathcal{M}_{\hat{\theta}_{n}}}^{*}}{\left\{1+\bar{C} \boldsymbol{\lambda}_{n, \mathcal{M}_{\hat{\theta}_{n}}}^{*, \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{M}_{\hat{\theta}_{n}}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}^{2}} \\
& -\sum_{j \in \mathcal{M}_{\hat{\theta}_{n}}} \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)\left|\lambda_{n, j}^{*}\right|-\frac{1}{2} \sum_{j \in \mathcal{M}_{\hat{\theta}_{n}}} \nu \rho^{\prime \prime}\left(c_{j}\left|\lambda_{n, j}^{*}\right| ; \nu\right)\left|\lambda_{n, j}^{*}\right|^{2} \\
\geq & \boldsymbol{\lambda}_{n, \mathcal{M}_{\hat{\theta}_{n}}}^{*, \overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\theta}_{n}}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{n, \mathcal{M}_{\hat{\theta}_{n}}}^{*}\right)\right\}-C \delta_{n}^{2}\left\{1+o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

for some $\bar{C}, c_{j} \in(0,1)$, where the last inequality follows from the condition that $P_{\nu}(\cdot)$ has bounded second-order derivative around 0 . For any $j \in \mathcal{M}_{\hat{\theta}_{n}}$, we have $\operatorname{sgn}\left(\lambda_{n, j}^{*}\right)=\operatorname{sgn}\left\{\bar{g}_{j}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}$ if $\left|\bar{g}_{j}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right|>$ $\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)$, and $\bar{g}_{j}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\bar{g}_{j}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}=0=\lambda_{n, j}^{*}$ if $\left|\bar{g}_{j}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right|=\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)$. Thus,

$$
\lambda_{n, j}^{*}\left\{\bar{g}_{j}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left(\lambda_{n, j}^{*}\right)\right\}=\lambda_{n, j}^{*}\left[\bar{g}_{j}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\bar{g}_{j}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}\right]
$$

for any $j \in \mathcal{M}_{\hat{\theta}_{n}}$ with $\left|\bar{g}_{j}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right| \geq \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)$. By Condition 4(a), $\left\{j \in[r]: \bar{c} \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \leq\left|\bar{g}_{j}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right|<\right.$ $\left.\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)\right\}=\emptyset$ w.p.a.1. Recall $\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\theta}_{n}}=\left\{j \in[r]:\left|\bar{g}_{j}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right| \geq \bar{c} \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)\right\}$. We then have w.p.a. 1 that

$$
\begin{aligned}
o_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\delta_{n}^{2}\right) & \geq \boldsymbol{\lambda}_{n, \mathcal{M}_{\hat{\theta}_{n}}}^{*, \overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\theta}_{n}}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\theta}_{n}}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}-C \delta_{n}^{2}\left\{1+o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)\right\} \\
& =\delta_{n}\left|\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\theta}_{n}}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\theta}_{n}}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}\right|_{2}-C \delta_{n}^{2}\left\{1+o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, $\left|\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}\right|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\delta_{n}\right)$. For any $\epsilon_{n} \rightarrow 0$, select $\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{n}^{* *}$ such that $\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{n, \mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}_{n}}^{*}=\epsilon_{n}\left[\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}\right]$ and $\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{n, \mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}_{n}}^{* *}=\mathbf{0}$. Then $\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{n}^{* *}\right|_{2}=o_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\delta_{n}\right)$. Due to $f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{n}^{* *} ; \hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) \leq \max _{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \hat{\Lambda}_{n}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)} f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) \leq \max _{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \hat{\Lambda}_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)} f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}^{2}\right)$, using the same arguments given above, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\epsilon_{n}\left|\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right. & \left.-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}\right|_{2} ^{2} \\
& -C \epsilon_{n}^{2}\left|\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}\right|_{2}^{2}\left\{1+o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)\right\}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, $\epsilon_{n}\left|\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}\right|_{2} ^{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}^{2}\right)$. Since we can select arbitrary slow $\epsilon_{n} \rightarrow 0$, it holds that

$$
\left|\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}\right|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right)
$$

which implies $\left|\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{n}\right|_{2}=\left|\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{n, \mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}_{n}}\right|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right)=o_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\delta_{n}\right)$. Write $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{n, \mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}_{n}}=\left(\tilde{\lambda}_{n, 1}, \ldots, \tilde{\lambda}_{n,\left|\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}_{n}\right|}\right)^{\top}$. We have w.p.a. 1 that

$$
\mathbf{0}=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)}{1+\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{n, \mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}_{n}}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)}-\tilde{\boldsymbol{\eta}}
$$

where $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\eta}}=\left(\tilde{\eta}_{1}, \ldots, \tilde{\eta}_{\left|\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}_{n}\right|}\right)^{\top}$ with $\tilde{\eta}_{j}=\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(\left|\hat{\lambda}_{n, j}\right| ; \nu\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left(\hat{\lambda}_{n, j}\right)$ for $\hat{\lambda}_{n, j} \neq 0$ and $\tilde{\eta}_{j} \in\left[-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right), \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)\right]$ for $\tilde{\lambda}_{n, j}=0$. Identical to (J.3), we have $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\eta}}=\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)+\mathbf{R}$ for some $\left|\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}_{n}\right|$-dimensional vector $\mathbf{R}$. Applying the same arguments for deriving the rate of $R_{j}$ in (J.4), it holds that $|\mathbf{R}|_{\infty}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right)$. Since $\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}=o(\nu)$, we then have $\operatorname{sgn}\left(\tilde{\lambda}_{n, j}\right)=\operatorname{sgn}\left\{\bar{g}_{j}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}$ for any $j \in \mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}_{n}$ with $\tilde{\lambda}_{n, j} \neq 0$ w.p.a.1. Using the arguments in Section J. 2 for showing $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}$ is a local maximizer for $f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$ w.p.a.1, we can prove $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{n}$ is a local maximizer for $f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)$ w.p.a.1, which implies $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)=\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{n}$ w.p.a.1. We then have Lemma 3.

# J. 4 Proof of Lemma 4 

Recall $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\arg \max _{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \hat{\Lambda}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta})} f_{n}(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})$. Then $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}$ and $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)=\left(\hat{\lambda}_{1}, \ldots, \hat{\lambda}_{r}\right)^{\top}$ satisfy

$$
\mathbf{0}=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\mathbf{g}_{i}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)}{1+\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)}-\hat{\boldsymbol{\eta}}
$$

where $\hat{\boldsymbol{\eta}}=\left(\hat{\eta}_{1}, \ldots, \hat{\eta}_{r}\right)^{\top}$ with $\hat{\eta}_{j}=\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(\left|\hat{\lambda}_{j}\right| ; \nu\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left(\hat{\lambda}_{j}\right)$ for $\hat{\lambda}_{j} \neq 0$ and $\hat{\eta}_{j} \in\left[-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right), \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)\right]$for $\hat{\lambda}_{j}=0$. Recall $\mathcal{R}_{n}=\operatorname{supp}\left\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}$. Restricted on $\mathcal{R}_{n}$, for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}$ and $\boldsymbol{\zeta}=\left(\zeta_{1}, \ldots, \zeta_{\left|\mathcal{R}_{n}\right|}\right)^{\top} \in$

$\mathbb{R}^{\left|\mathcal{R}_{n}\right|}$ with each $\zeta_{j} \neq 0$, define

$$
\mathbf{m}(\boldsymbol{\zeta}, \boldsymbol{\theta})=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{1+\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}-\mathbf{w}
$$

where $\mathbf{w}=\left(w_{1}, \ldots, w_{\left|\mathcal{R}_{n}\right|}\right)^{\top}$ with $w_{j}=\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(\left|\zeta_{j}\right| ; \nu\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left(\zeta_{j}\right)$. From (J.9), we know $\hat{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)$ and $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}$ satisfy $\mathbf{m}\left\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right), \hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right\}=\mathbf{0}$. By the implicit function theorem [Theorem 9.28 of Rudin (1976)], for all $\boldsymbol{\theta}$ in a small neighborhood of $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}$, denoted by $\mathcal{U}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)$, there exists a $\boldsymbol{\zeta}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ such that $\mathbf{m}\{\boldsymbol{\zeta}(\boldsymbol{\theta}), \boldsymbol{\theta}\}=\mathbf{0}, \boldsymbol{\zeta}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)=\hat{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)$ and $\boldsymbol{\zeta}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ is continuously differentiable in $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{U}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)$. By Condition 4(b), the event $\mathcal{E}=\left\{\max _{j \in \mathcal{R}_{n}^{c}}\left|\hat{\eta}_{j}\right|<\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)\right\}$holds w.p.a.1. Restricted on $\mathcal{E}$, let $\varsigma_{n}=$ $\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)-\max _{j \in \mathcal{R}_{n}^{c}}\left|\hat{\eta}_{j}\right|$ and define $\boldsymbol{\Theta}_{*}=\left\{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{U}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right):\left|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right|_{1} \leq o\left[\min \left\{\varsigma_{n}, \chi_{n}\right\}\right],\left|\boldsymbol{\zeta}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\boldsymbol{\zeta}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right|_{1} \leq\right.$ $\left.o\left[\min \left\{\varsigma_{n}, \ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right\}\right]\right\}$ for some $\chi_{n}>0$. Since all the components of $\boldsymbol{\zeta}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)$ are nonzero and $\boldsymbol{\zeta}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ is continuously differentiable in $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}$, we can select sufficiently small $\chi_{n}$ such that all the components of $\boldsymbol{\zeta}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ are nonzero for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}_{*}$. For any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}_{*}$, let $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\left\{\tilde{\lambda}_{1}(\boldsymbol{\theta}), \ldots, \tilde{\lambda}_{r}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}^{\top} \in \mathbb{R}^{r}$ satisfy $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\boldsymbol{\zeta}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ and $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}^{c}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\mathbf{0}$. Since $\mathbf{m}\{\boldsymbol{\zeta}(\boldsymbol{\theta}), \boldsymbol{\theta}\}=\mathbf{0}, \tilde{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\boldsymbol{\zeta}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ and $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}^{c}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\mathbf{0}$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}_{*}$, then

$$
0=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{g_{i, j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{1+\tilde{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left\{\left|\tilde{\lambda}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right| ; \nu\right\} \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\tilde{\lambda}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}
$$

for any $j \in \mathcal{R}_{n}$. For any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}_{*}$ and $j \in \mathcal{R}_{n}^{c}$, by the Taylor expansion, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{g_{i, j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{1+\tilde{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})} \\
= & \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{g_{i, j}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)}{1+\tilde{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)}+\left[\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\left\{\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} g_{i, j}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}})\right\}^{\top}}{1+\tilde{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}})}-\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{g_{i, j}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}) \tilde{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \mathbf{g}_{i}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}})}{\left\{1+\tilde{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}})\right\}^{2}}\right]\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}-\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) \\
= & \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{g_{i, j}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)}{1+\tilde{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)}-\left[\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{g_{i, j}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) \mathbf{g}_{i}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)^{\top}}{\left\{1+\tilde{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}^{2}}\right]\left\{\tilde{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\hat{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\} \\
& +\left[\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\left\{\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} g_{i, j}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}})\right\}^{\top}}{1+\tilde{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}})}-\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{g_{i, j}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}) \tilde{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \mathbf{g}_{i}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}})}{\left\{1+\tilde{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}})\right\}^{2}}\right]\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}-\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}$ is lying on the jointing line between $\boldsymbol{\theta}$ and $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}$, and $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}$ is lying on the jointing line between $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ and $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)$. By Lemma $3,\left|\tilde{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right)$ and $\left|\mathcal{R}_{n}\right| \leq \ell_{n}$ w.p.a.1. Then $\left|\tilde{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|_{2}=$ $\left|\boldsymbol{\zeta}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|_{2} \leq\left|\boldsymbol{\zeta}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right|_{2}+\left|\boldsymbol{\zeta}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\boldsymbol{\zeta}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right)$, which implies $\left|\tilde{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}\right|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right)$. Together with Condition 2(a) and $\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}=o\left(n^{-1 / \gamma}\right)$, it yields that $\max _{i \in[n]}\left\{\left|\tilde{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}})\right|+\left|\tilde{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right|\right\}=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$. By Conditions 2(a) and 2(c), we have

$$
\max _{j \in \mathcal{R}_{n}^{c}}\left|\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{g_{i, j}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) \mathbf{g}_{i}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)}{\left\{1+\tilde{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}^{2}}\right|_{\infty}=O_{\mathrm{p}}(1)=\max _{j \in \mathcal{R}_{n}^{c}}\left|\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} g_{i, j}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}})}{1+\tilde{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}})}\right|_{\infty}
$$

It follows from the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \max _{j \in \mathcal{R}_{n}^{c}}\left|\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{g_{i, j}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}) \hat{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \mathbf{g}_{i}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}})}{\left\{1+\hat{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}})\right\}^{2}}\right|_{\infty} \\
\leqslant & \left\{1+o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)\right\} \cdot \max _{j \in \mathcal{R}_{n}^{c}, k \in[p]}\left\{\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \sum_{l \in \mathcal{R}_{n}}|g_{i, j}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}})||\tilde{\lambda}_{l}(\boldsymbol{\theta})|\left|\frac{\partial g_{i, j}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}})}{\partial \theta_{k}}\right|\right\} \\
\leqslant & \left\{1+o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)\right\} \cdot \max _{j \in \mathcal{R}_{n}^{c}, k \in[p]}\left[\mathbb{E}_{n}^{1 / 2}\left\{g_{i, j}^{2}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}})\right\} \sum_{l \in \mathcal{R}_{n}}\left|\hat{\lambda}_{l}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right| \mathbb{E}_{n}^{1 / 2}\left\{\left|\frac{\partial g_{i, j}(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}})}{\partial \theta_{k}}\right|^{2}\right\}\right] \\
\leqslant & \left.|\hat{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})|_{1} \cdot O_{\mathrm{p}}(1) \leq \ell_{n}^{1 / 2}|\hat{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})|_{2} \cdot O_{\mathrm{p}}(1)=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}\right)=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

By (J.10), for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}_{*}$, we know

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{g_{i, j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{1+\hat{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})} & =\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{g_{i, j}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)}{1+\hat{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)}+O_{\mathrm{p}}(1) \cdot\left|\boldsymbol{\zeta}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\boldsymbol{\zeta}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right|_{1}+O_{\mathrm{p}}(1) \cdot\left|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right|_{1} \\
& =\hat{\eta}_{j}+\varsigma_{n} \cdot o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)
\end{aligned}
$$

holds uniformly over $j \in \mathcal{R}_{n}^{c}$. Due to $\mathbb{P}(\mathcal{E}) \rightarrow 1$, we have

$$
\max _{j \in \mathcal{R}_{n}^{c}}\left|\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{g_{i, j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{1+\hat{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}\right| \leq \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)
$$

w.p.a.1. Therefore, $\hat{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ and $\boldsymbol{\theta}$ satisfy the score equation $\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}} f_{n}\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\}=\mathbf{0}$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}_{*}$ w.p.a.1. By the concavity of $f_{n}(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})$ w.r.t $\boldsymbol{\lambda}$, we have $\hat{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\arg \max _{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \hat{\lambda}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta})} f_{n}(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})=\hat{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}_{*}$ w.p.a.1. Hence, $\hat{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ is continuously differentiable at $\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}$ and $\left[\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \hat{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right]_{\mathcal{R}_{n}^{c},[p]}=\mathbf{0}$ w.p.a.1.

# J. 5 Proof of Lemma 5 

The proof is almost identical to that of Lemma 2 in Chang et al. (2018). From Lemma 3, we have $|\hat{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right)$. Recall $p$ is fixed in our current setting. We only need to replace the convergence rate of $|\hat{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}|_{2}$ in the proof of Lemma 2 in Chang et al. (2018) by $O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right)$ and also set $\left(s, \omega_{n}\right)$ there as $(p, 1)$ and all the arguments still hold.

## J. 6 Proof of Lemma 6

The proof is almost identical to that of Lemma 3 in Chang et al. (2018). Since $p$ is fixed, we only need to replace $\left\{\omega_{n}, \varpi_{n}, b_{n}^{1 /(2 \beta)}, s\right\}$ in the proof of Lemma 3 in Chang et al. (2018) by $(1,1, \nu, p)$ and all the arguments still hold.

# J. 7 Proof of Lemma 7 

Recall $\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{\mathcal{F}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)=\mathbb{E}\left\{\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{F}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right\}$ and $\mathbf{V}_{\mathcal{F}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)=\mathbb{E}\left\{\mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{F}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)^{\otimes 2}\right\}$. For any $\mathbf{t} \in \mathbb{R}^{p}$ with $|\mathbf{t}|_{2}=1$, let $Z_{i, \mathcal{F}}=\mathbf{t}^{\top} \mathbf{H}_{\mathcal{F}}^{-1 / 2} \boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{\mathcal{F}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)^{\top} \mathbf{V}_{\mathcal{F}}^{-1}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right) \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{F}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$ with $\mathbf{H}_{\mathcal{F}}=\left\{\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{\mathcal{F}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)^{\top} \mathbf{V}_{\mathcal{F}}^{-1 / 2}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right\}^{\otimes 2}$. Write $G_{\mathcal{F}}=$ $\mathbb{E}_{n}\left(Z_{i, \mathcal{F}}\right)$ and $\hat{G}_{\mathcal{F}}=\mathbf{t}^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{H}}_{\mathcal{F}}^{-1 / 2} \widehat{\boldsymbol{\Gamma}}_{\mathcal{F}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)^{\top} \widehat{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{F}}^{-1}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right) \hat{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{F}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$. It follows from the Berry-Esseen inequality that

$$
\sup _{u \in \mathbb{R}}\left|\mathbb{P}\left(n^{1 / 2} G_{\mathcal{F}} \leq u\right)-\Phi(u)\right| \leq C n^{-1 / 2} \mathbb{E}\left(\left|Z_{i, \mathcal{F}}\right|^{3}\right)
$$

for some universal constant $C>0$. By the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|Z_{i, \mathcal{F}}\right|^{2} & \leq\left|\mathbf{V}_{\mathcal{F}}^{-1 / 2}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right) \boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{\mathcal{F}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right) \mathbf{H}_{\mathcal{F}}^{-1 / 2} \mathbf{t}\right|_{2}^{2} \cdot\left|\mathbf{V}_{\mathcal{F}}^{-1 / 2}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right) \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{F}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|_{2}^{2} \\
& \leq \lambda_{\min }^{-1}\left\{\mathbf{V}_{\mathcal{F}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right\}\left|\mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{F}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|_{2}^{2} \leq K_{3}^{-1}\left|\mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{F}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|_{2}^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

for $K_{3}$ given in Condition 2(b). By the Jensen's inequality, Condition 2(a) yields $\mathbb{E}\left\{\left|\mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{F}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|_{2}^{3}\right\} \leq$ $K_{2}^{3 / \gamma} \ell_{n}^{3 / 2}$ for $K_{2}$ and $\gamma$ given in Condition 2(a), which implies $\mathbb{E}\left(\left|Z_{i, \mathcal{F}}\right|^{3}\right) \leq K_{3}^{-3 / 2} \mathbb{E}\left\{\left|\mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{F}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)\right|_{2}^{3}\right\} \leq$ $K_{2}^{3 / \gamma} K_{3}^{-3 / 2} \ell_{n}^{3 / 2}$. If $\ell_{n}=o\left(n^{1 / 3}\right)$, we have

$$
\sup _{\mathcal{F} \in \mathscr{F}} \sup _{u \in \mathbb{R}}\left|\mathbb{P}\left(n^{1 / 2} G_{\mathcal{F}} \leq u\right)-\Phi(u)\right| \rightarrow 0
$$

as $n \rightarrow \infty$. By Conditions 2(b) and 3 and Lemmas 1 and 6, it holds that $\sup _{\mathcal{F} \in \mathscr{F}}\left|n^{1 / 2}\left(\hat{G}_{\mathcal{F}}-G_{\mathcal{F}}\right)\right|=$ $O_{\mathrm{p}}\left\{\ell_{n} \nu(\log r)^{1 / 2}\right\}+O_{\mathrm{p}}\left\{\ell_{n}^{3 / 2} \alpha_{n}(\log r)^{1 / 2}\right\}$. For any constant $\delta>0$, due to $\mathbb{P}\left(n^{1 / 2} \hat{G}_{\mathcal{F}} \leq u\right)-\Phi(u) \leq$ $\mathbb{P}\left(n^{1 / 2} G_{\mathcal{F}} \leq u+\delta\right)+\mathbb{P}\left\{\left|n^{1 / 2}\left(\hat{G}_{\mathcal{F}}-G_{\mathcal{F}}\right)\right| \geq \delta\right\}-\Phi(u)$ and $\mathbb{P}\left(n^{1 / 2} \hat{G}_{\mathcal{F}} \leq u\right)-\Phi(u) \geq \mathbb{P}\left(n^{1 / 2} G_{\mathcal{F}} \leq\right.$ $u-\delta)-\mathbb{P}\left\{\left|n^{1 / 2}\left(\hat{G}_{\mathcal{F}}-G_{\mathcal{F}}\right)\right| \geq \delta\right\}-\Phi(u)$, it holds that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sup _{\mathcal{F} \in \mathscr{F}} \sup _{u \in \mathbb{R}}\left|\mathbb{P}\left(n^{1 / 2} \hat{G}_{\mathcal{F}} \leq u\right)-\Phi(u)\right| \leq & \sup _{\mathcal{F} \in \mathscr{F}} \sup _{u \in \mathbb{R}}\left|\mathbb{P}\left(n^{1 / 2} G_{\mathcal{F}} \leq u\right)-\Phi(u)\right|+\sup _{\mathcal{F} \in \mathscr{F}} \mathbb{P}\left\{\left|n^{1 / 2}\left(\hat{G}_{\mathcal{F}}-G_{\mathcal{F}}\right)\right| \geq \delta\right\} \\
& +\sup _{u \in \mathbb{R}}|\Phi(u+\delta)-\Phi(u-\delta)| .
\end{aligned}
$$

Notice that $\sup _{\mathcal{F} \in \mathscr{F}}\left|n^{1 / 2}\left(\hat{G}_{\mathcal{F}}-G_{\mathcal{F}}\right)\right|=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$ and $\sup _{u \in \mathbb{R}}|\Phi(u+\delta)-\Phi(u-\delta)| \leq\left(2 \pi^{-1}\right)^{1 / 2} \delta$. Then it holds that $\lim \sup _{n \rightarrow \infty} \sup _{\mathcal{F} \in \mathscr{F}} \sup _{u \in \mathbb{R}}\left|\mathbb{P}\left(n^{1 / 2} \hat{G}_{\mathcal{F}} \leq u\right)-\Phi(u)\right| \leq\left(2 \pi^{-1}\right)^{1 / 2} \delta$. Due to the arbitrary selection of $\delta>0$, we have $\sup _{\mathcal{F} \in \mathscr{F}} \sup _{u \in \mathbb{R}}\left|\mathbb{P}\left(n^{1 / 2} \hat{G}_{\mathcal{F}} \leq u\right)-\Phi(u)\right| \rightarrow 0$ as $n \rightarrow \infty$.

## J. 8 Proof of Lemma 8

Recall $\mathcal{C}_{1}=\left\{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}:\left|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right|_{2} \leq \alpha_{n}\right\}$. For any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$, same as the proof of Lemma 2, we only need to show that there exists a local maximizer satisfying the results stated in the lemma.

For $\tilde{c}$ specified in Condition 4(a), we select $c \in(\tilde{c}, 1)$. We select $\delta_{n}$ satisfying $\delta_{n}=o\left(\ell_{n}^{-1 / 2} n^{-1 / \gamma}\right)$ and $\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}=o\left(\delta_{n}\right)$, which can be guaranteed by $\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}=o\left(n^{-1 / \gamma}\right)$. For each $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$, define $\Lambda_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}=\left\{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \mathbb{R}^{r}:\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(c)}\right|_{2} \leq \delta_{n}, \boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(c)^{c}}=\mathbf{0}\right\}$ and $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}=\arg \max _{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \Lambda_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}} f_{n}(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})$. Similar to (J.7) and the arguments below (J.7), if $\log r=o\left(n^{1 / 3}\right), \ell_{n} \nu^{2}=o(1)$ and $\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}=o\left[\min \left\{\nu, n^{-1 / \gamma}\right\}\right]$, we have $\left|\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}, \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(c)}\right|_{2} \leq 4 K_{3}^{-1}\left|\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(c)}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(c)}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}\right|_{2}$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$ w.p.a.1, where $K_{3}$ is specified in Condition 2(b). Notice that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(c)}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(c)}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}\right|_{2} \leq & \underbrace{\left|\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(c) \bigcap \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n}}(\tilde{c})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(c) \bigcap \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n}}(\tilde{c})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}\right|_{2}}_{T_{1, \boldsymbol{\theta}}} \\
