& +\underbrace{\left|\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(c) \bigcap \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n}}(\tilde{c})^{c}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(c) \bigcap \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n}}(\tilde{c})^{c}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}\right|_{2}}_{T_{2, \boldsymbol{\theta}}}
\end{aligned}
$$

By the Taylor expansion and Condition 2(c), we have $\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}}|\overline{\mathbf{g}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\overline{\mathbf{g}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)|_{\infty}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\alpha_{n}\right)$, which implies $\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}}\left|\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n}}(\tilde{c})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{n}}(\tilde{c})}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right)$. Due to $\alpha_{n}=o(\nu)$ and $\left|\bar{g}_{j}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right| \geq$ $\tilde{c} \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)$for any $j \in \mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}}(\tilde{c})$, we then have $\operatorname{sgn}\left\{\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}_{n}}(\tilde{c})(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}=\operatorname{sgn}\left\{\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}_{n}}(\tilde{c})\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$ w.p.a.1. By the triangle inequality and (J.8), we have w.p.a. 1 that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}} T_{1, \boldsymbol{\theta}} \leq & \sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}}\left|\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}_{n}}(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}})\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}_{n}}(\tilde{c})\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}\right|_{2} \\
& +\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}}\left|\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}_{n}}(\tilde{c})(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}_{n}}(\tilde{c})\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right|_{2} \\
= & O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

For any $j \in \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(c) \bigcap \mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}}(\tilde{c})^{c}$, we have $\left|\bar{g}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right| \geq c \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)$and $\left|\bar{g}_{j}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right|<\tilde{c} \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)$. Due to $c \in(\tilde{c}, 1)$ and $\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}}|\overline{\mathbf{g}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\overline{\mathbf{g}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)|_{\infty}=o_{\mathrm{p}}(\nu)$, then $\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(c) \bigcap \mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}}(\tilde{c})^{c}=\emptyset$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$ w.p.a.1, which implies $T_{2, \boldsymbol{\theta}}=0$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$ w.p.a.1. Hence,

$$
\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}}\left|\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(c)}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(c)}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}\right|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right)
$$

Then $\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}}\left|\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\right|_{2}=\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}}\left|\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}, \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(c)}\right|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right)=o_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\delta_{n}\right)$. Write $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}=\left(\tilde{\lambda}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}, 1}, \ldots, \tilde{\lambda}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}, r}\right)^{\top}$. Our next step is to show $\operatorname{sgn}\left(\tilde{\lambda}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}, j}\right)=\operatorname{sgn}\left\{\bar{g}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$ and $j \in \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(c)$ with $\tilde{\lambda}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}, j} \neq 0$ w.p.a.1. Its proof is almost identical to that in Section J. 3 for proving $\operatorname{sgn}\left(\tilde{\lambda}_{n, j}\right)=\operatorname{sgn}\left\{\bar{g}_{j}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}$ for any $j \in \mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}}(\tilde{c})$ with $\tilde{\lambda}_{n, j} \neq 0$ w.p.a.1. We only need to replace $\left\{\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{n}, \mathcal{M}_{\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}}(\tilde{c})\right\}$ there by $\left\{\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}, \mathcal{M}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(c)\right\}$ and all the arguments still hold uniformly over $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$. Using the same arguments stated in the proof of Lemma 2 for showing $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{0}$ is a local maximizer for $f_{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}_{0}\right)$ w.p.a.1, we can

also prove $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}$ is a local maximizer of $f_{n}(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$ w.p.a.1, which implies $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$ w.p.a.1. We then have Lemma 8.

# J. 9 Proof of Lemma 9 

Recall $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\arg \max _{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \hat{\lambda}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta})} f_{n}(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})$ and $\mathcal{C}_{1}=\left\{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}:\left|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right|_{2} \leq \alpha_{n}\right\}$. Then $\boldsymbol{\theta}$ and $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\left\{\hat{\lambda}_{1}(\boldsymbol{\theta}), \ldots, \hat{\lambda}_{r}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}^{\top}$ satisfy

$$
\mathbf{0}=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\mathbf{g}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{1+\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}-\hat{\boldsymbol{\eta}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})
$$

where $\hat{\boldsymbol{\eta}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\left\{\hat{\eta}_{1}(\boldsymbol{\theta}), \ldots, \hat{\eta}_{r}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}^{\top}$ with $\hat{\eta}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\nu \rho^{\prime}\left\{\left|\hat{\lambda}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right| ; \nu\right\} \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\hat{\lambda}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}$ for $\hat{\lambda}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \neq 0$ and $\hat{\eta}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \in\left[-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right), \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)\right]$for $\hat{\lambda}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=0$. Recall $\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\operatorname{supp}\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\}$. For any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$, restricted on $\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$, define

$$
\mathbf{m}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\zeta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})}{1+\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})}-\mathbf{w}
$$

for any $\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}$ and $\boldsymbol{\zeta}=\left\{\zeta_{1}, \ldots, \zeta_{|\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})|}\right\}^{\top} \in \mathbb{R}^{|\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})|}$ with each $\zeta_{j} \neq 0$, where $\mathbf{w}=\left\{w_{1}, \ldots, w_{|\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})|}\right\}^{\top}$ with $w_{j}=\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(\left|\zeta_{j}\right| ; \nu\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left(\zeta_{j}\right)$. From (J.12), we know $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ and $\boldsymbol{\theta}$ satisfy $\mathbf{m}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\left\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta}), \boldsymbol{\theta}\right\}=\mathbf{0}$. By the implicit function theorem [Theorem 9.28 of Rudin (1976)], for all $\boldsymbol{\vartheta}$ in a small neighborhood of $\boldsymbol{\theta}$, denoted by $\mathcal{U}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$, there exists a $\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})$ such that $\mathbf{m}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\left\{\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}), \boldsymbol{\vartheta}\right\}=\mathbf{0}, \boldsymbol{\zeta}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=$ $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ and $\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})$ is continuously differentiable in $\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \in \mathcal{U}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$. By Condition 5(a), the event $\mathcal{E}=\bigcap_{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}}\left\{\max _{j \in \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\circ}}\left|\hat{\eta}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|<\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)\right\}$holds w.p.a.1. Restricted on $\mathcal{E}$, let $\varsigma_{n}=\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)-$ $\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}} \max _{j \in \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\circ}}\left|\hat{\eta}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|$ and define $\boldsymbol{\Theta}_{*}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\left\{\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \in \mathcal{U}(\boldsymbol{\theta}):\left|\boldsymbol{\vartheta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}\right|_{1} \leq o\left[\min \left\{\varsigma_{n}, \chi_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}\right],\left|\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})-\right.\right.$ $\left.\left.\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|_{1} \leq o\left[\min \left\{\varsigma_{n}, \ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right\}\right]\right\}$ for some $\chi_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta})>0$. Since all the components of $\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ are nonzero and $\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})$ is continuously differentiable in $\boldsymbol{\vartheta}$, we can select sufficiently small $\chi_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ such that all the components of $\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})$ are nonzero for any $\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}_{*}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$. For any $\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}_{*}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$, let $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}) \in \mathbb{R}^{r}$ satisfy $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}, \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})=\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})$ and $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}, \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\circ}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})=\mathbf{0}$. By Lemma 8, $\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}}|\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right)$ and $\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}}|\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})| \leq \ell_{n}$ w.p.a.1, which imply

$$
\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}} \sup _{\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}_{*}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}\left|\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})\right|_{2} \leq \sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}} \sup _{\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}_{*}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}\left|\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})-\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|_{2}+\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}}\left|\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right)
$$

Using the same arguments in the proof of Lemma 4 for proving that $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ and $\boldsymbol{\theta}$ satisfy the score equation $\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}} f_{n}\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\}=\mathbf{0}$ w.p.a. 1 there, we can prove $\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}} f_{n}\left\{\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta}) ; \boldsymbol{\vartheta}\right\}=\mathbf{0}$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$ and $\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}_{*}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ w.p.a.1. By the concavity of $f_{n}(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\vartheta})$ w.r.t $\boldsymbol{\lambda}$, we have $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})=\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})=$

$\arg _{\lambda \in \hat{\lambda}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta})} f_{n}(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\vartheta})$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$ and $\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}_{*}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ w.p.a.1. Recall $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})$ is continuously differentiable in $\boldsymbol{\vartheta} \in \mathcal{U}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$. Hence, $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ is continuously differentiable at $\boldsymbol{\theta}$ and $\left[\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right]_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\nu},[p]}=\mathbf{0}$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$ w.p.a.1. Write $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\left\{\tilde{\lambda}_{1}(\boldsymbol{\theta}), \ldots, \tilde{\lambda}_{|\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})|}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}^{\top}$. Since $\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$, it holds that

$$
\begin{aligned}
{\left[\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right]_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta}),[p]=} & \left.\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\vartheta}} \boldsymbol{\zeta}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\vartheta})\right|_{\boldsymbol{\vartheta}=\boldsymbol{\theta}}=-\left.\left\{\frac{\partial \mathbf{m}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\zeta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})}{\partial \boldsymbol{\zeta}}\right\}^{-1} \frac{\partial \mathbf{m}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\zeta}, \boldsymbol{\vartheta})}{\partial \boldsymbol{\vartheta}}\right|_{\boldsymbol{\vartheta}=\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\zeta}=\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})} \\
= & \left(\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\otimes 2}}{\left\{1+\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}^{2}}+\nu \operatorname{diag}\left[\rho^{\prime \prime}\left\{\left|\tilde{\lambda}_{1}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right| ; \nu\right\}, \ldots, \rho^{\prime \prime}\left\{\left|\tilde{\lambda}_{|\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})|}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right| ; \nu\right\}\right]\right)^{-1} \\
& \times\left\{\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\left[\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \mathbf{g}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right]_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta}),[p]}}{1+\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}-\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top}\left[\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \mathbf{g}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right]_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta}),[p]}}{\left\{1+\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}^{2}}\right\} .
\end{aligned}
$$

We complete the proof of Lemma 9.

# J. 10 Proof of Lemma 10 

Recall $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\arg \max _{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \hat{\lambda}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta})} f_{n}(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta}), \mathcal{R}_{n}=\operatorname{supp}\left\{\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}$ and $\mathcal{C}_{1}=\left\{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}:\left|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right|_{2} \leq \alpha_{n}\right\}$. By Lemma 3, $\left|\mathcal{R}_{n}\right| \leq \ell_{n}$ w.p.a.1. Select $\delta_{n}$ satisfying $\delta_{n}=o\left(\ell_{n}^{-1 / 2} n^{-1 / \gamma}\right)$ and $\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}=o\left(\delta_{n}\right)$, which can be guaranteed by $\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}=o\left(n^{-1 / \gamma}\right)$. For any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$, let $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\arg \max _{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \hat{\lambda}_{n}} f_{n}(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})$, where $\hat{\Lambda}_{n}=\left\{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \mathbb{R}^{r}:\left|\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}\right|_{2} \leq \delta_{n}, \boldsymbol{\lambda}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}^{r}}=\mathbf{0}\right\}$. Similar to (J.7) and the arguments below (J.7), if $\log r=o\left(n^{1 / 3}\right), \ell_{n} \alpha_{n}=o\left[\min \left\{\nu, n^{-1 / \gamma}\right\}\right]$ and $\ell_{n} \nu^{2}=o(1)$, we have $\left|\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|_{2} \leq 4 K_{3}^{-1}\left|\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\right.$ $\left.\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}\right|_{2}$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$ w.p.a.1, where $K_{3}$ is specified in Condition 2(b). By Lemma 3 , we have $\mathcal{R}_{n} \subset \mathcal{M}_{\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}}(\tilde{c})$ w.p.a.1, where $\tilde{c}$ is specified in Condition 4(a). Using the arguments for deriving (J.11), we have

$$
\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}}\left|\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right) \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\overline{\mathbf{g}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}\right|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right)
$$

which implies $\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}}\left|\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right)=o_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\delta_{n}\right)$. Write $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\left\{\dot{\lambda}_{1}(\boldsymbol{\theta}), \ldots, \dot{\lambda}_{\left|\mathcal{R}_{n}\right|}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}^{\top}$. By the first-order condition, for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$, we have

$$
\mathbf{0}=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{1+\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}_{n}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}-\tilde{\boldsymbol{\eta}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})
$$

where $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\eta}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\left\{\tilde{\eta}_{1}(\boldsymbol{\theta}), \ldots, \tilde{\eta}_{\left|\mathcal{R}_{n}\right|}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}^{\top}$ with $\tilde{\eta}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\nu \rho^{\prime}\left\{\left|\dot{\lambda}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right| ; \nu\right\} \operatorname{sgn}\left\{\dot{\lambda}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}$ for $\dot{\lambda}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \neq 0$ and $\tilde{\eta}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \in\left[-\nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right), \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)\right]$for $\dot{\lambda}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=0$. Using the same arguments for addressing the remainder terms in (J.10), for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$ and $j \in \mathcal{R}_{n}^{c}$, it holds that

$$
\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{g_{i, j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{1+\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}=\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{g_{i, j}\left(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)}{1+\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i}\left(\tilde{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)}+o_{\mathrm{p}}(\nu)
$$

where the term $o_{\mathrm{p}}(\nu)$ holds uniformly over $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$ and $j \in \mathcal{R}_{n}^{r}$. Together with Condition 5(a), we have that

$$
\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}} \max _{j \in \mathcal{R}_{n}^{r}}\left|\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{g_{i, j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{1+\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{+} \mathbf{g}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}\right| \leq \nu \rho^{\prime}\left(0^{+}\right)
$$

w.p.a.1. Therefore, $\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ and $\boldsymbol{\theta}$ satisfy the score equation $\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}} f_{n}\{\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) ; \boldsymbol{\theta}\}=\mathbf{0}$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$ w.p.a.1. By the concavity of $f_{n}(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})$ w.r.t $\boldsymbol{\lambda}$, it holds that $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\arg \max _{\boldsymbol{\lambda} \in \tilde{\lambda}_{n}(\boldsymbol{\theta})} f_{n}(\boldsymbol{\lambda} ; \boldsymbol{\theta})$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$ w.p.a.1, which implies $\operatorname{supp}\{\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\} \subset \operatorname{supp}\left\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$ w.p.a.1. Select $\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$ such that $\left|\operatorname{supp}\left\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}\right)\right\}\right| \leq\left|\operatorname{supp}\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\}\right|$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$, and define $\mathcal{B}_{2}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}, 2 \alpha_{n}\right)=\left\{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in\right.$ $\boldsymbol{\Theta}:\left|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}\right|_{2} \leq 2 \alpha_{n}\}$. Using the same arguments above for proving $\operatorname{supp}\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\} \subset \operatorname{supp}\left\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}\right)\right\}$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$ w.p.a.1, we have $\operatorname{supp}\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\} \subset \operatorname{supp}\left\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}\right)\right\}$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{B}_{2}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}, 2 \alpha_{n}\right)$ w.p.a.1. Since $\mathcal{C}_{1} \subset \mathcal{B}_{2}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}, 2 \alpha_{n}\right)$, then $\operatorname{supp}\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\} \subset \operatorname{supp}\left\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}\right)\right\}$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$ w.p.a.1. Due to $\left|\operatorname{supp}\left\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}\right)\right\}\right| \leq\left|\operatorname{supp}\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\}\right|$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$, we have $\operatorname{supp}\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\}=\operatorname{supp}\left\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}\right)\right\}$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$ w.p.a.1. We complete the proof of Lemma 10.

# J. 11 Proof of Lemma 11 

By Lemma 8, we have $\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}}|\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})| \leq \ell_{n}$ w.p.a. 1 and $\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}}|\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{1 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right)$. Under Condition 2(a), if $\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}=o\left(n^{-1 / \gamma}\right)$, then $\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}} \max _{i \in[n]}\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{+} \mathbf{g}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$. Write $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\left\{\tilde{\lambda}_{1}(\boldsymbol{\theta}), \ldots, \tilde{\lambda}_{r}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}^{\top}$ and $\mathbf{t}=\left(t_{1}, \ldots, t_{p}\right)^{\top}$. For $T_{\boldsymbol{\theta}, 1}$, by the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality and Condition 2(c), we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\mathbf{t}^{\top} T_{\boldsymbol{\theta}, 1} \mathbf{t}\right| & \leq \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\{\sum_{k=1}^{p} \sum_{j \in \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})} t_{k} \frac{\partial g_{i, j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{\partial \theta_{k}} \tilde{\lambda}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}^{2} \cdot\left\{1+o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)\right\} \\
& \leq\left\{1+o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)\right\} \cdot \ell_{n} p \cdot|\mathbf{t}|_{2}^{2}|\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})|_{2}^{2} \cdot \max _{j \in \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})} \max _{k \in[p]} \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left|\frac{\partial g_{i, j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{\partial \theta_{k}}\right|^{2}=|\mathbf{t}|_{2}^{2} \cdot O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{2} \alpha_{n}^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

holds uniformly over $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$ and $\mathbf{t} \in \mathbb{R}^{p}$. For $T_{\boldsymbol{\theta}, 3}$, by Condition 2(c), we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\mathbf{t}^{\top} T_{\boldsymbol{\theta}, 3} \mathbf{t}\right| & =\left|\sum_{k_{1}, k_{2}=1}^{p} t_{k_{1}} t_{k_{2}} \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{1}{1+\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{+} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}\left\{\sum_{j \in \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})} \frac{\partial^{2} g_{i, j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{\partial \theta_{k_{1}} \partial \theta_{k_{2}}} \tilde{\lambda}_{j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}\right| \\
& \leq\left\{1+o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)\right\} \cdot|\mathbf{t}|_{1}^{2}|\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})|_{1} \max _{j \in \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})} \max _{k_{1}, k_{2} \in[p]} \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left|\frac{\partial^{2} g_{i, j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{\partial \theta_{k_{1}} \partial \theta_{k_{2}}}\right|=|\mathbf{t}|_{2}^{2} \cdot O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

holds uniformly over $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$ and $\mathbf{t} \in \mathbb{R}^{p}$. Let $\hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\left\{\tilde{\lambda}_{1}(\boldsymbol{\theta}), \ldots, \tilde{\lambda}_{|\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})|}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}^{\top}$. By the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, Conditions 2(a) and 2(c), if $\log r=o\left(n^{1 / 3}\right), \ell_{n} \alpha_{n}=o\left[\min \left\{\nu, n^{-1 / \gamma}\right\}\right]$

and $\ell_{n} \nu^{2}=o(1)$, then

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\lvert\,\left(\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top}\left[\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \mathbf{g}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right]_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta}),[p]}}{\left\{1+\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}^{2}}\right) \mathbf{t}\right|_{2}^{2} \\
& \quad \leq\left\{1+o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)\right\} \cdot \sum_{j \in \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}\left\{\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left|g_{i, j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right| \sum_{l \in \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})} \sum_{k=1}^{p}\left|\tilde{\lambda}_{l}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|\left|\frac{\partial g_{i, l}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{\partial \theta_{k}}\right|\left|t_{k}\right|\right\}^{2} \\
& \quad \leq\left\{1+o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)\right\} \cdot \sum_{j \in \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}\left\{\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left|g_{i, j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|^{2}\right\}\left[\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left\{\sum_{l \in \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})} \sum_{k=1}^{p}\left|\tilde{\lambda}_{l}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|\left|\frac{\partial g_{i, l}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{\partial \theta_{k}}\right|\left|t_{k}\right|\right\}^{2}\right] \\
& \quad \leq\left\{1+o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)\right\} \cdot|\mathbf{t}|_{2}^{2}|\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})|_{2}^{2} \cdot \ell_{n} p \cdot \max _{j \in \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})} \max _{k \in[p]} \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left|\frac{\partial g_{i, j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}{\partial \theta_{k}}\right|^{2} \cdot \sum_{j \in \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}\left\{\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n}\left|g_{i, j}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|^{2}\right\} \\
& =|\mathbf{t}|_{2}^{2} \cdot O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{3} \alpha_{n}^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

holds uniformly over $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$ and $\mathbf{t} \in \mathbb{R}^{p}$. Recall $\alpha_{n}=o(\nu)$. By Proposition 1, Lemma 1 and Condition 2(b), if $\log r=o\left(n^{1 / 3}\right), \ell_{n} \alpha_{n}=o\left[\min \left\{\nu, n^{-1 / \gamma}\right\}\right]$ and $\ell_{n} \nu^{2}=o(1)$, we know that $\inf _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}} \lambda_{\min }\left\{\widehat{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}$ and $\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}} \lambda_{\max }\left\{\widehat{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}$ are uniformly bounded away from zero and infinity w.p.a.1. Using the same arguments in the proof of Lemma 5, if $\log r=o\left(n^{1 / 3}\right)$, $\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}=o\left[\min \left\{\nu, n^{-1 / \gamma}\right\}\right]$ and $\ell_{n} \nu^{2}=o(1)$, it holds that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}}\left\|\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\otimes 2}}{\left\{1+\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}^{2}}-\widehat{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n} n^{1 / \gamma} \alpha_{n}\right) \\
& \sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}}\left|\left\{\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\left[\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \mathbf{g}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right]_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta}),[p]}}{1+\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}-\widehat{\mathbf{T}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}_{2}=|\mathbf{t}|_{2} \cdot O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n} \alpha_{n}\right)\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

By Condition 3 and the same arguments in the proof of Lemma 6, if $\log r=o\left(n^{1 / 3}\right), \ell_{n} \alpha_{n}=\rightleftharpoons$ $o\left[\min \left\{\nu, n^{-1 / \gamma}\right\}\right]$ and $\ell_{n} \nu^{2}=o(1)$, we have $\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}}\left\|\widehat{\mathbf{T}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$. Notice that $\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}}\left\|\widehat{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}^{-1}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\|_{2}=$ $O_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$ and $\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}}\left\|\nu \operatorname{diag}\left[\rho^{\prime \prime}\left\{\left|\tilde{\lambda}_{1}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right| ; \nu\right\}, \ldots, \rho^{\prime \prime}\left\{\left|\tilde{\lambda}_{|\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})|}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right| ; \nu\right\}\right]\right\|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}(\nu)$. Thus,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}}\left\|\left(\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\otimes 2}}{\left\{1+\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}^{2}}+\nu \operatorname{diag}\left[\rho^{\prime \prime}\left\{\left|\tilde{\lambda}_{1}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right| ; \nu\right\}, \ldots, \rho^{\prime \prime}\left\{\left|\tilde{\lambda}_{|\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})|}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right| ; \nu\right\}\right\}\right)^{-1} \\
& \left.-\widehat{\mathbf{V}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}^{-1}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|_{2}=O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n} n^{1 / \gamma} \alpha_{n}\right)+O_{\mathrm{p}}(\nu)
\end{aligned}
$$

Combining (J.13), (J.14) and (J.15), by Lemma 9, we know $\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}}\left|\left[\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right]_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta}),[p]} \mathbf{t}\right|_{2}=|\mathbf{t}|_{2} \cdot$ $O_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$ holds uniformly over $\mathbf{t} \in \mathbb{R}^{p}$, which implies

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}}\left|\mathbf{t}^{\top} T_{\boldsymbol{\theta}, 2} \mathbf{t}\right| \leq \sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}}\left|\left(\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta}) \tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top}\left[\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \mathbf{g}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right]_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta}),[p]}}{\left\{1+\tilde{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}^{2}}\right) \mathbf{t}\right|_{2}\left|\left[\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \hat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right]_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta}),[p]} \mathbf{t}\right|_{2} \\
& =|\mathbf{t}|_{2}^{2} \cdot O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{3 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

holds uniformly over $\mathbf{t} \in \mathbb{R}^{p}$. For $T_{\boldsymbol{\theta}, A}$, by (J.13), (J.14) and (J.15), Lemma 9 implies

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{t}^{\top} T_{\boldsymbol{\theta}, A} \mathbf{t} & =\mathbf{t}^{\top}\left\{\frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{\left[\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \mathbf{g}_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right]_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta}),[p]}^{\top}}{1+\hat{\mathbf{A}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \mathbf{g}_{i, \mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}\right\}\left[\nabla_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \hat{\boldsymbol{\Lambda}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right]_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta}),[p]} \mathbf{t} \\
& =\mathbf{t}^{\top}\left\{\widehat{\boldsymbol{\Gamma}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}(\boldsymbol{\theta})^{\top} \widehat{\boldsymbol{\nabla}}_{\mathcal{R}(\boldsymbol{\theta})}^{-1 / 2}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right\}^{\otimes 2} \mathbf{t}+|\mathbf{t}|_{2}^{2} \cdot\left\{O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n}^{3 / 2} \alpha_{n}\right)+O_{\mathrm{p}}\left(\ell_{n} n^{1 / \gamma} \alpha_{n}\right)+O_{\mathrm{p}}(\nu)\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

holds uniformly over $\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathcal{C}_{1}$ and $\mathbf{t} \in \mathbb{R}^{p}$. We then obtain the result by (F.1).

# J. 12 Proof of Lemma 12 

Denote by $\mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}(\cdot)$ and $\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}(\cdot)$, respectively, the conditional probability and conditional expectation given $\mathcal{X}_{n}$. For any integer $k \geq 1$, recall $\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k+1}=N_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{N_{k}} \omega_{i}^{k} \mathbf{h}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}^{k}\right)$ only depends on the $N_{k}$ samples $\left\{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}^{k}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{\theta}_{N_{k}}^{k}\right\}$ generated from the proposal distribution with density $\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)$, where $\omega_{i}^{k}=\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}^{k} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right) / \varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}^{k} ; \hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)$. Thus, the random sequence $\left\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right\}_{k \geq 1}$ forms a Markov chain. Recall that $\boldsymbol{\Theta} \subset \mathbb{R}^{p}$ is a compact set with fixed $p$. Since $\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}}|\mathbf{h}(\boldsymbol{\theta})|_{\infty} \leq K_{9}$ for some universal constant $K_{9}>0$, and $\varphi(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta})$ is positive and continuous on $(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\zeta}) \in \boldsymbol{\Theta} \times \mathbb{R}^{s}$, there exists a positive and continuous function $\varrho(\cdot)$ such that

$$
\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}} \frac{\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)|\mathbf{h}(\boldsymbol{\theta})|_{\infty}}{\varphi(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta})} \leq \varrho(\boldsymbol{\zeta})
$$

for any $\boldsymbol{\zeta} \in \mathbb{R}^{s}$. Since $\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)=0$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \notin \boldsymbol{\Theta}$, then

$$
\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}^{s}} \frac{\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)|\mathbf{h}(\boldsymbol{\theta})|_{\infty}}{\varphi(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta})}=0
$$

for any $\boldsymbol{\zeta} \in \mathbb{R}^{s}$. Notice that $\mathbb{E}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k+1} \mid \hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)=\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}=\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\theta} \sim \pi^{\dagger}}\{\mathbf{h}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\}$. Write $\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k+1}=\left(\hat{\zeta}_{k+1,1}, \ldots, \hat{\zeta}_{k+1, s}\right)^{\top}$ and $\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}=\left(\zeta_{1}^{*}, \ldots, \zeta_{s}^{*}\right)^{\top}$. For any $\varepsilon>0$, by the Hoeffding's inequality, we have

$$
\mathbb{P}\left(\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k+1}-\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right|_{\infty}>\varepsilon \mid \hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right) \leq s \max _{j \in[s]} \mathbb{P}\left(\left|\hat{\zeta}_{k+1, j}-\zeta_{j}^{*}\right|>\varepsilon \mid \hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right) \leq 2 s \exp \left\{-\frac{N_{k} \varepsilon^{2}}{2 \varrho^{2}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)}\right\}
$$

Let $C_{\varepsilon}=\sup _{\boldsymbol{\zeta} \in \mathbb{R}^{s}:\left|\boldsymbol{\zeta}-\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right|_{\infty} \leq \varepsilon} \varrho^{2}(\boldsymbol{\zeta})$. By (J.16), we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left(\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k+1}-\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right|_{\infty}>\varepsilon,\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}-\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right|_{\infty} \leq \varepsilon\right) & =\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left[I\left(\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}-\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right|_{\infty} \leq \varepsilon\right) \mathbb{E}\left\{I\left(\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k+1}-\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right|_{\infty}>\varepsilon\right) \mid \hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right\}\right] \\
& \leq 2 s \exp \left(-\frac{N_{k} \varepsilon^{2}}{2 C_{\varepsilon}}\right) \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left(\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}-\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right|_{\infty} \leq \varepsilon\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

which implies

$$
\mathbb{P}\left(\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k+1}-\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right|_{\infty}>\varepsilon \mid\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}-\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right|_{\infty} \leq \varepsilon\right) \leq 2 s \exp \left(-\frac{N_{k} \varepsilon^{2}}{2 C_{\varepsilon}}\right)
$$

For any integer $k^{\prime} \geq k$, by the Markov property of $\left\{\hat{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{k}\right\}_{k \geq 1}$, it then holds that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left(\bigcap_{t=k}^{k^{\prime}}\left\{\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{t+1}-\zeta^{*}\right|_{\infty} \leq \varepsilon\right\}\right) & =\mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left(\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{k+1}-\zeta^{*}\right|_{\infty} \leq \varepsilon\right) \prod_{t=k+1}^{k^{\prime}} \mathbb{P}\left(\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{t+1}-\zeta^{*}\right|_{\infty} \leq \varepsilon \mid\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{t}-\zeta^{*}\right|_{\infty} \leq \varepsilon\right) \\
& \geq \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left(\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{k+1}-\zeta^{*}\right|_{\infty} \leq \varepsilon\right) \prod_{t=k+1}^{k^{\prime}}\left\{1-2 s \exp \left(-\frac{N_{t} \varepsilon^{2}}{2 C_{z}}\right)\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

Letting $k^{\prime} \rightarrow \infty$, then

$$
\mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left(\bigcap_{t=k}^{\infty}\left\{\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{t+1}-\zeta^{*}\right|_{\infty} \leq \varepsilon\right\}\right) \geq \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left(\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{k+1}-\zeta^{*}\right|_{\infty} \leq \varepsilon\right) \prod_{t=k+1}^{\infty}\left\{1-2 s \exp \left(-\frac{N_{t} \varepsilon^{2}}{2 C_{z}}\right)\right\}
$$

Since $s$ is fixed and $\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \exp \left(-C N_{k}\right)<\infty$ for any $C>0$, we have

$$
\liminf _{k \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left(\bigcap_{t=k}^{\infty}\left\{\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{t+1}-\zeta^{*}\right|_{\infty} \leq \varepsilon\right\}\right) \geq \liminf _{k \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left(\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{k+1}-\zeta^{*}\right|_{\infty} \leq \varepsilon\right)
$$

For any $z>0$, let $\bar{C}_{z}=\sup _{\zeta \in \mathbb{R}^{z}:\|\zeta\|_{\infty} \leq z} \varrho^{2}(\boldsymbol{\zeta})$. Using the same arguments for (J.17), it holds that

$$
\mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left(\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{k+1}-\zeta^{*}\right|_{\infty}>\varepsilon,\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{k}\right|_{\infty} \leq z\right) \leq 2 s \exp \left(-\frac{N_{k} \varepsilon^{2}}{2 C_{z}}\right) \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left(\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{k}\right|_{\infty} \leq z\right) \leq 2 s \exp \left(-\frac{N_{k} \varepsilon^{2}}{2 C_{z}}\right)
$$

By the Markov's inequality and triangle inequality,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left(\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{k}\right|_{\infty}>z\right) & \leq z^{-1} \mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left(\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{k}\right|_{\infty}\right) \leq z^{-1} \mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left\{\frac{1}{N_{k-1}} \sum_{i=1}^{N_{k-1}} \omega_{i}^{k-1}\left|\mathbf{h}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}^{k-1}\right)\right|_{\infty}\right\} \\
& =z^{-1} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{p}} \frac{\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)}{\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \hat{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{k-1}\right)}|\mathbf{h}(\boldsymbol{\theta})|_{\infty} \varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \hat{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{k-1}\right) \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{\theta}=z^{-1} \mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\theta} \sim \pi^{\dagger}}\left\{|\mathbf{h}(\boldsymbol{\theta})|_{\infty}\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

which implies $\mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left(\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{k+1}-\zeta^{*}\right|_{\infty}>\varepsilon\right) \leq 2 s \exp \left\{-\left(2 C_{z}\right)^{-1} N_{k} \varepsilon^{2}\right\}+z^{-1} \mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\theta} \sim \pi^{\dagger}}\left\{|\mathbf{h}(\boldsymbol{\theta})|_{\infty}\right\}$. Due to $N_{k} \rightarrow \infty$ as $k \rightarrow \infty$, we know $\lim \sup _{k \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left(\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{k+1}-\zeta^{*}\right|_{\infty}>\varepsilon\right) \leq z^{-1} \mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\theta} \sim \pi^{\dagger}}\left\{|\mathbf{h}(\boldsymbol{\theta})|_{\infty}\right\}$. Notice that $\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}}|\mathbf{h}(\boldsymbol{\theta})|_{\infty} \leq K_{9}$ for some universal constant $K_{9}>0$. Letting $z \rightarrow \infty$, it holds that $\lim \sup _{k \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left(\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{k+1}-\zeta^{*}\right|_{\infty}>\varepsilon\right)=0$, which implies $\liminf _{k \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left(\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{k+1}-\zeta^{*}\right|_{\infty} \leq \varepsilon\right)=1$. Together with (J.18), we have

$$
\liminf _{k \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left(\bigcap_{t=k}^{\infty}\left\{\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{t+1}-\zeta^{*}\right|_{\infty} \leq \varepsilon\right\}\right)=1
$$

Since $\varepsilon>0$ is arbitrary, we then obtain that, conditional on $\mathcal{X}_{n},\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\xi}}_{k+1}-\zeta^{*}\right|_{\infty} \rightarrow 0$ almost surely as $k \rightarrow \infty$. We complete the proof of Lemma 12 .

# J. 13 Proof of Lemma 13 

Denote by $\mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}(\cdot)$ and $\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}(\cdot)$, respectively, the conditional probability and conditional expectation given $\mathcal{X}_{n}$. Recall $\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}=\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\theta} \sim \pi^{\dagger}}\{\mathbf{h}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\}$. Let $\widehat{\mathbf{Z}}_{k+1}=N_{k}^{-1} \sum_{i=1}^{N_{k}} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}^{k} \pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}^{k} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right) / \varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}^{k} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right)$ for any integer $k \geq 2$ and

$$
\mathbf{Z}(\boldsymbol{\zeta})=\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\theta} \sim \varphi(\cdot ; \boldsymbol{\zeta})}\left\{\frac{\boldsymbol{\theta} \pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)}{\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right)}\right\}=\int_{\mathbb{R}^{p}} \frac{\boldsymbol{\theta} \pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)}{\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right)} \varphi(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta}) \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{\theta}
$$

for any $\boldsymbol{\zeta} \in \mathbb{R}^{s}$, where $\left\{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}^{1}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{\theta}_{N_{1}}^{1}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}^{k}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{\theta}_{N_{k}}^{k}\right\}$ are generated via Algorithm 2.
Our first step is to show that conditional on $\mathcal{X}_{n}$, we have $\left|\widehat{\mathbf{Z}}_{k+1}-\mathbf{Z}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)\right|_{\infty} \rightarrow 0$ almost surely as $k \rightarrow \infty$. Notice that $\boldsymbol{\Theta} \subset \mathbb{R}^{p}$ is a compact set with fixed $p$ and $\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)=0$ for any $\boldsymbol{\theta} \notin \boldsymbol{\Theta}$. Since $\varphi(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta})$ is positive and continuous on $(\boldsymbol{\theta}, \boldsymbol{\zeta}) \in \boldsymbol{\Theta} \times \mathbb{R}^{s}$, we know

$$
\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}} \frac{\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)|\boldsymbol{\theta}|_{\infty}}{\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right)} \leq \tilde{C} \text { and } \sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}^{*}} \frac{\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)|\boldsymbol{\theta}|_{\infty}}{\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right)}=0
$$

for some universal constant $\tilde{C}>0$. Recall that $\widehat{\mathbf{Z}}_{k+1}$ depends on the $N_{k}$ samples $\left\{\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}^{k}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{\theta}_{N_{k}}^{k}\right\}$ generated from the proposal distribution with density $\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)$. Then $\mathbb{E}\left(\widehat{\mathbf{Z}}_{k+1} \mid \hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)=\mathbf{Z}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)$. For any $\varepsilon>0$, using the same arguments for (J.16), we have

$$
\mathbb{P}\left\{\left|\widehat{\mathbf{Z}}_{k+1}-\mathbf{Z}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)\right|_{\infty}>\varepsilon\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right\} \leq 2 p \exp \left(-\frac{N_{k} \varepsilon^{2}}{2 \tilde{C}^{2}}\right)\right.
$$

Define the event $A_{k+1}=\left\{\left|\widehat{\mathbf{Z}}_{k+1}-\mathbf{Z}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)\right|_{\infty} \leq \varepsilon,\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k+1}-\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right|_{\infty} \leq \varepsilon\right\}$. Note that $A_{k} \in \sigma\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}^{k-1}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{\theta}_{N_{k-1}}^{k-1}, \hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k-1}\right)$ and the conditional joint distribution of $\left(\widehat{\mathbf{Z}}_{k+1}, \hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k+1}\right)$ given $\mathcal{X}_{n}$ is fully determined by $\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}$. By (J.16) and (J.21), it holds that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left(A_{k+1}^{c} \cap A_{k}\right) & =\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left[\mathbb{E}\left\{I\left(A_{k+1}^{c}\right) I\left(A_{k}\right) \mid \boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}^{k-1}, \ldots, \boldsymbol{\theta}_{N_{k-1}}^{k-1}, \hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k-1}, \hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right\}\right]=\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left[I\left(A_{k}\right) \mathbb{E}\left\{I\left(A_{k+1}^{c}\right) \mid \hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right\}\right] \\
& \leq \mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left\{I\left(A_{k}\right) \mathbb{E}\left[I\left\{\left|\widehat{\mathbf{Z}}_{k+1}-\mathbf{Z}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)\right|_{\infty}>\varepsilon\right\} \mid \hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right]\right\}+\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left[I\left(A_{k}\right) \mathbb{E}\left\{I\left(\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k+1}-\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right|_{\infty}>\varepsilon\right) \mid \hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right\}\right] \\
& =\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left[I\left(A_{k}\right) \mathbb{P}\left\{\left|\widehat{\mathbf{Z}}_{k+1}-\mathbf{Z}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)\right|_{\infty}>\varepsilon\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right\}\right]+\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left\{I\left(A_{k}\right) \mathbb{P}\left(\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k+1}-\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right|_{\infty}>\varepsilon\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)\right\}\right. \\
& \leq\left\{2 p \exp \left(-\frac{N_{k} \varepsilon^{2}}{2 \tilde{C}^{2}}\right)+2 s \exp \left(-\frac{N_{k} \varepsilon^{2}}{2 C_{\varepsilon}}\right)\right\} \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left(A_{k}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $C_{\varepsilon}=\sup _{\boldsymbol{\zeta} \in \mathbb{R}^{s}:\left|\boldsymbol{\zeta}-\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right|_{\infty} \leq \varepsilon} \varrho^{2}(\boldsymbol{\zeta})$ with the function $\varrho(\cdot)$ specified in the proof of Lemma 12. Then

$$
\mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left(A_{k+1}^{c} \mid A_{k}\right) \leq 2 p \exp \left(-\frac{N_{k} \varepsilon^{2}}{2 \tilde{C}^{2}}\right)+2 s \exp \left(-\frac{N_{k} \varepsilon^{2}}{2 C_{\varepsilon}}\right) \leq 2(p+s) \exp \left(-\frac{N_{k} \varepsilon^{2}}{\tilde{C}_{\varepsilon}}\right)
$$

for some $\hat{C}_{\varepsilon}>0$ depending on $\varepsilon$. For any integer $k^{\prime} \geq k$, by the Markov property of $\left\{\left(\widehat{\mathbf{Z}}_{k}, \hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)\right\}_{k \geq 2}$, it then holds that
$\mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left(\bigcap_{t=k}^{k^{\prime}} A_{t+1}\right)=\mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left(A_{k+1}\right) \prod_{t=k+1}^{k^{\prime}} \mathbb{P}\left(A_{t+1} \mid A_{t}\right) \geq \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left(A_{k+1}\right) \prod_{t=k+1}^{k^{\prime}}\left\{1-2(p+s) \exp \left(-\frac{N_{t} \varepsilon^{2}}{\hat{C}_{\varepsilon}}\right)\right\}$.
Letting $k^{\prime} \rightarrow \infty$, then

$$
\mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left(\bigcap_{t=k}^{\infty} A_{t+1}\right) \geq \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left(A_{k+1}\right) \prod_{t=k+1}^{\infty}\left\{1-2(p+s) \exp \left(-\frac{N_{t} \varepsilon^{2}}{\hat{C}_{\varepsilon}}\right)\right\}
$$

Since $p$ and $s$ are fixed constants and $\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \exp \left(-C N_{k}\right)<\infty$ for any $C>0$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\liminf _{k \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left(\bigcap_{t=k}^{\infty} A_{t+1}\right) & \geq \liminf _{k \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left(A_{k+1}\right) \\
& \geq 1-\limsup _{k \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left\{\left|\widehat{\mathbf{Z}}_{k+1}-\mathbf{Z}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)\right|_{\infty}>\varepsilon\right\}-\limsup _{k \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left(\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k+1}-\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right|_{\infty}>\varepsilon\right) \\
& =1-\limsup _{k \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left\{\left|\widehat{\mathbf{Z}}_{k+1}-\mathbf{Z}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)\right|_{\infty}>\varepsilon\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

where the last step is due to the fact $\lim \sup _{k \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left(\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k+1}-\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right|_{\infty}>\varepsilon\right)=0$ as shown in the proof of Lemma 12. For any $z>0$, by (J.21), it holds that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left\{\left|\widehat{\mathbf{Z}}_{k+1}-\mathbf{Z}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)\right|_{\infty}>\varepsilon,\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right|_{\infty} \leq z\right\} & =\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left\{I\left(\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right|_{\infty} \leq z\right) \mathbb{E}\left[I\left\{\left|\widehat{\mathbf{Z}}_{k+1}-\mathbf{Z}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)\right|_{\infty}>\varepsilon\right\} \mid \hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right]\right\} \\
& \leq 2 p \exp \left(-\frac{N_{k} \varepsilon^{2}}{2 \widehat{C}^{2}}\right) \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left(\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right|_{\infty} \leq z\right) \leq 2 p \exp \left(-\frac{N_{k} \varepsilon^{2}}{2 \widehat{C}^{2}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Together with (J.19), we have

$$
\mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left\{\left|\widehat{\mathbf{Z}}_{k+1}-\mathbf{Z}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)\right|_{\infty}>\varepsilon\right\} \leq 2 p \exp \left(-\frac{N_{k} \varepsilon^{2}}{2 \widehat{C}^{2}}\right)+z^{-1} \mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\theta} \sim \pi^{\dagger}}\left\{|\mathbf{h}(\boldsymbol{\theta})|_{\infty}\right\}
$$

Due to $N_{k} \rightarrow \infty$ as $k \rightarrow \infty$, we know $\lim \sup _{k \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left\{\left|\widehat{\mathbf{Z}}_{k+1}-\mathbf{Z}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)\right|_{\infty}>\varepsilon\right\} \leq z^{-1} \mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\theta} \sim \pi^{\dagger}}\left\{|\mathbf{h}(\boldsymbol{\theta})|_{\infty}\right\}$. Notice that $\sup _{\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \boldsymbol{\Theta}}|\mathbf{h}(\boldsymbol{\theta})|_{\infty} \leq K_{9}$ for some universal constant $K_{9}>0$. Letting $z \rightarrow \infty$, it holds that $\lim \sup _{k \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left\{\left|\widehat{\mathbf{Z}}_{k+1}-\mathbf{Z}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)\right|_{\infty}>\varepsilon\right\}=0$. Together with (J.22), we have

$$
\liminf _{k \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left[\bigcap_{t=k}^{\infty}\left\{\left|\widehat{\mathbf{Z}}_{t+1}-\mathbf{Z}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{t}\right)\right|_{\infty} \leq \varepsilon\right\}\right] \geq \liminf _{k \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left(\bigcap_{t=k}^{\infty} A_{t+1}\right)=1
$$

Since $\varepsilon>0$ is arbitrary, conditional on $\mathcal{X}_{n}$, we have $\left|\widehat{\mathbf{Z}}_{k+1}-\mathbf{Z}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)\right|_{\infty} \rightarrow 0$ almost surely as $k \rightarrow \infty$.
Our second step is to show that conditional on $\mathcal{X}_{n}$, we have $\left|\mathbf{Z}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)-\mathbf{Z}\left(\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right)\right|_{\infty} \rightarrow 0$ almost surely as $k \rightarrow \infty$. By (J.20), we have $\left|\mathbf{Z}(\boldsymbol{\zeta})\right|_{\infty}<\infty$ for any $\boldsymbol{\zeta} \in \mathbb{R}^{*}$, and
$\left|\mathbf{Z}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)-\mathbf{Z}\left(\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right)\right|_{\infty} \leq \int_{\mathbb{R}^{p}} \frac{\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)\left|\boldsymbol{\theta}\right|_{\infty}}{\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right)}\left|\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)-\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right)\right| \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{\theta} \leq \tilde{C} \int_{\boldsymbol{\Theta}}\left|\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)-\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right)\right| \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{\theta}$.

For some sufficiently large $M>0$, since conditional on $\mathcal{X}_{n}$, we have $\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}-\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right|_{\infty} \rightarrow 0$ almost surely as $k \rightarrow \infty$, then for any $\epsilon>0$ there exists a sufficiently large integer $k_{\epsilon}$ such that $\mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}(\mathcal{A}) \leq \epsilon$ with $\mathcal{A}=\bigcup_{t=k_{\epsilon}}^{\infty}\left\{\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{t}-\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right|_{\infty}>M\right\}$. Define a compact set $\mathcal{B}=\left\{\boldsymbol{\zeta} \in \mathbb{R}^{s}:\left|\boldsymbol{\zeta}-\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right|_{\infty} \leq M\right\}$. Recall $\boldsymbol{\Theta} \subset \mathbb{R}^{p}$ is a compact set with fixed $p$. Due to the continuity of $\varphi(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta})$, we know $\varphi(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta})$ is uniformly continuous on $(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta}) \in \boldsymbol{\Theta} \times \mathcal{B}$. For any $\varepsilon>0$, there exists $\delta(\varepsilon)>0$ such that $\left|\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta}_{1}\right)-\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{2} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta}_{2}\right)\right|<\tilde{C}^{-1} \varepsilon / \mathbb{L}(\boldsymbol{\Theta})$ for any $\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}, \boldsymbol{\zeta}_{1}\right),\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{2}, \boldsymbol{\zeta}_{2}\right) \in \boldsymbol{\Theta} \times \mathcal{B}$ satisfying $\left|\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}-\boldsymbol{\theta}_{2}\right|_{\infty} \leq \delta(\varepsilon)$ and $\left|\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{1}-\boldsymbol{\zeta}_{2}\right|_{\infty} \leq \delta(\varepsilon)$, where $\mathbb{L}(\cdot)$ is the Lebesgue measure on $\mathbb{R}^{p}$. Since

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\{\left|\mathbf{Z}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{t}\right)-\mathbf{Z}\left(\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right)\right|_{\infty}>\varepsilon, \mathcal{A}^{\varepsilon}\right\} & \subset\left\{\int_{\boldsymbol{\Theta}}\left|\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{t}\right)-\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right)\right| \mathrm{d} \boldsymbol{\theta}>\frac{\varepsilon}{\tilde{C}}, \mathcal{A}^{\varepsilon}\right\} \\
& \subset\left\{\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{t}-\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right|_{\infty}>\delta(\varepsilon), \mathcal{A}^{\varepsilon}\right\} \subset\left\{\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{t}-\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right|_{\infty}>\delta(\varepsilon)\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

we then have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\limsup _{k \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left[\bigcup_{t=k}^{\infty}\left\{\left|\mathbf{Z}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{t}\right)-\mathbf{Z}\left(\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right)\right|_{\infty}>\varepsilon\right\}\right] & \leq \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}(\mathcal{A})+\limsup _{k \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left[\bigcup_{t=k}^{\infty}\left\{\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{t}-\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right|_{\infty}>\delta(\varepsilon)\right\}\right] \\
& =\mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}(\mathcal{A}) \leq \epsilon
\end{aligned}
$$

where the second step is due to the fact that conditional on $\mathcal{X}_{n}$ we have $\left|\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}-\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right|_{\infty} \rightarrow 0$ almost surely as $k \rightarrow \infty$. Letting $\epsilon \rightarrow 0$, we know that conditional on $\mathcal{X}_{n}$, we have $\left|\mathbf{Z}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)-\mathbf{Z}\left(\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right)\right|_{\infty} \rightarrow 0$ almost surely as $k \rightarrow \infty$.

Our third step is to show that conditional on $\mathcal{X}_{n}$, we have $\left|\widehat{\mathbb{E}}_{\pi^{\dagger}, K}^{*}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\theta} \sim \pi^{\dagger}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|_{\infty} \rightarrow 0$ almost surely as $K \rightarrow \infty$. By the triangle inequality, $\left|\widehat{\mathbf{Z}}_{k+1}-\mathbf{Z}\left(\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right)\right|_{\infty} \leq\left|\widehat{\mathbf{Z}}_{k+1}-\mathbf{Z}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)\right|_{\infty}+\left|\mathbf{Z}\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\zeta}}_{k}\right)-\right.$ $\left.\mathbf{Z}\left(\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right)\right|_{\infty}$. Based on the results shown in Steps 1 and 2 above, it holds that conditional on $\mathcal{X}_{n}$, we have $\left|\widehat{\mathbf{Z}}_{k+1}-\mathbf{Z}\left(\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right)\right|_{\infty} \rightarrow 0$ almost surely as $k \rightarrow \infty$. Notice that $\mathbf{Z}\left(\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right)=\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\theta} \sim \pi^{\dagger}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})$ and

$$
\widehat{\mathbb{E}}_{\pi^{\dagger}, K}^{*}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=\frac{1}{S_{K}} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \sum_{i=1}^{N_{k}} \frac{\pi^{\dagger}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}^{k} \mid \mathcal{X}_{n}\right)}{\varphi\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}^{k} ; \boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right)} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{i}^{k}=\frac{1}{S_{K}} \sum_{k=1}^{K} N_{k} \widehat{\mathbf{Z}}_{k+1}
$$

with $S_{K}=N_{1}+\cdots+N_{K}$. Notice that conditional on $\mathcal{X}_{n},\left|\widehat{\mathbf{Z}}_{k+1}-\mathbf{Z}\left(\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right)\right|_{\infty} \rightarrow 0$ almost surely as $k \rightarrow \infty$. Given a constant $\varepsilon>0$, for any $\epsilon>0$ there exists a sufficiently large integer $\tilde{k}_{\epsilon}$ such that $\mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}(\mathcal{C}) \leq \epsilon$ with $\mathcal{C}=\bigcup_{k=\tilde{k}_{\epsilon}}^{\infty}\left\{\left|\widehat{\mathbf{Z}}_{k+1}-\mathbf{Z}\left(\boldsymbol{\zeta}^{*}\right)\right|_{\infty}>\varepsilon / 2\right\}$. Due to $S_{K}=N_{1}+\cdots+N_{K}$ with $N_{K} \rightarrow \infty$ as $K \rightarrow \infty$ and

$$
\left\{\left|\widehat{\mathbb{E}}_{\pi^{\dagger}, t}^{*}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\theta} \sim \pi^{\dagger}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|_{\infty}>\varepsilon, \mathcal{C}^{\varepsilon}\right\}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \subset\left\{\frac{1}{S_{t}} \sum_{k=1}^{\tilde{k}_{\epsilon}} N_{k}\left|\widehat{\mathbf{Z}}_{k+1}-\mathbf{Z}\left(\zeta^{*}\right)\right|_{\infty}>\frac{\varepsilon}{2}, \mathcal{C}^{\mathrm{c}}\right\} \bigcup\left\{\frac{1}{S_{t}} \sum_{k=\tilde{k}_{\epsilon}+1}^{t} N_{k}\left|\widehat{\mathbf{Z}}_{k+1}-\mathbf{Z}\left(\zeta^{*}\right)\right|_{\infty}>\frac{\varepsilon}{2}, \mathcal{C}^{\mathrm{c}}\right\} \\
& \subset\left\{\frac{1}{S_{t}} \sum_{k=1}^{\tilde{k}_{\epsilon}} N_{k}\left|\widehat{\mathbf{Z}}_{k+1}-\mathbf{Z}\left(\zeta^{*}\right)\right|_{\infty}>\frac{\varepsilon}{2}\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

for any integer $t>\tilde{k}_{\epsilon}$, we then have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \limsup _{K \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left[\bigcup_{t=K}^{\infty}\left\{\left|\widehat{\mathbb{E}}_{\pi^{\dagger}, t}^{*}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\theta} \sim \pi^{\dagger}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|_{\infty}>\varepsilon\right\}\right] \\
& \quad \leq \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}(\mathcal{C})+\limsup _{K \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left[\bigcup_{t=K}^{\infty}\left\{\frac{1}{S_{t}} \sum_{k=1}^{\tilde{k}_{\epsilon}} N_{k}\left|\widehat{\mathbf{Z}}_{k+1}-\mathbf{Z}\left(\zeta^{*}\right)\right|_{\infty}>\frac{\varepsilon}{2}\right\}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Notice that

$$
\bigcup_{t=K}^{\infty}\left\{\frac{1}{S_{t}} \sum_{k=1}^{\tilde{k}_{\epsilon}} N_{k}\left|\widehat{\mathbf{Z}}_{k+1}-\mathbf{Z}\left(\zeta^{*}\right)\right|_{\infty}>\frac{\varepsilon}{2}\right\}=\left\{\frac{1}{S_{K}} \sum_{k=1}^{\tilde{k}_{\epsilon}} N_{k}\left|\widehat{\mathbf{Z}}_{k+1}-\mathbf{Z}\left(\zeta^{*}\right)\right|_{\infty}>\frac{\varepsilon}{2}\right\}
$$

and $S_{K}^{-1} \sum_{k=1}^{\tilde{k}_{\epsilon}} N_{k}\left|\widehat{\mathbf{Z}}_{k+1}-\mathbf{Z}\left(\zeta^{*}\right)\right|_{\infty}=o_{\mathrm{p}}(1)$ as $K \rightarrow \infty$ for given $(\epsilon, \varepsilon)$. Then

$$
\limsup _{K \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left[\bigcup_{t=K}^{\infty}\left\{\frac{1}{S_{t}} \sum_{k=1}^{\tilde{k}_{\epsilon}} N_{k}\left|\widehat{\mathbf{Z}}_{k+1}-\mathbf{Z}\left(\zeta^{*}\right)\right|_{\infty}>\frac{\varepsilon}{2}\right\}\right]=0
$$

which implies

$$
\limsup _{K \rightarrow \infty} \mathbb{P}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}\left[\bigcup_{t=K}^{\infty}\left\{\left|\widehat{\mathbb{E}}_{\pi^{\dagger}, t}^{*}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\theta} \sim \pi^{\dagger}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|_{\infty}>\varepsilon\right\}\right] \leq \epsilon
$$

Letting $\epsilon \rightarrow 0$, we know that conditional on $\mathcal{X}_{n},\left|\widehat{\mathbb{E}}_{\pi^{\dagger}, K}^{*}(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\mathbb{E}_{\boldsymbol{\theta} \sim \pi^{\dagger}}(\boldsymbol{\theta})\right|_{\infty} \rightarrow 0$ almost surely as $K \rightarrow \infty$. We complete the proof of Lemma 13.

abstract:
In this study, we introduce a novel methodological framework called Bayesian
Penalized Empirical Likelihood (BPEL), designed to address the computational
challenges inherent in empirical likelihood (EL) approaches. Our approach has
two primary objectives: (i) to enhance the inherent flexibility of EL in
accommodating diverse model conditions, and (ii) to facilitate the use of
well-established Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) sampling schemes as a
convenient alternative to the complex optimization typically required for
statistical inference using EL. To achieve the first objective, we propose a
penalized approach that regularizes the Lagrange multipliers, significantly
reducing the dimensionality of the problem while accommodating a comprehensive
set of model conditions. For the second objective, our study designs and
thoroughly investigates two popular sampling schemes within the BPEL context.
We demonstrate that the BPEL framework is highly flexible and efficient,
enhancing the adaptability and practicality of EL methods. Our study highlights
the practical advantages of using sampling techniques over traditional
optimization methods for EL problems, showing rapid convergence to the global
optima of posterior distributions and ensuring the effective resolution of
complex statistical inference challenges.
